urn:contentItem:5Y9V-0GF1-DY7P-T0PW-00000-00Get to know the Democrat, Republican candidates on ballot in Ohio primary2020-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Get to know the Democrat, Republican candidates on ballot in Ohio primary

Meet the candidates:

Pete Buttigieg, former mayor  

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: One of the understructures of Buttigieg's campaign is the need for generational change. As the youngest candidate, he aims to kickstart a fresh, young era of politics. A central part of his campaign is reforming the Supreme Court to 15 justices, with five Democrats, five Republicans and five apolitical judges comprising the seats. One of the many Deomcratic candidates to support capitalism, Buttigieg's economic platform aims to reinforce strong relations with labor unions and separate money from politics. On immigration, he supports DACA and the rights of Dreamers, opposes Trump's harsh deportation policies and considers sending troops to the border a waste of time. As former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, from 2012 to Jan. 1, 2020, Buttigieg had a complex relationship with police and the black community in the city. After controversially firing South Bend's first black police chief and refusing to release the recorded phone calls at the center of the debacle, the incident has been used as a criticism of his campaign.

Supporter demographic: Buttigieg's primary support comes from white, college-educated men and women, typically middle-aged and older. 

For more information on Buttigieg's policies, visit www.peteforamerica.com/issues.

 

Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-V.T. 

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political Affiliation: Democrat/Independent 

Major platform points: Sanders is an Independent senator from Vermont who is running for president in the 2020 Democratic Presidential Primary. Sanders has won the popular vote in the first three primary contests so far and has emerged nationally as the front-runner in the race, consistently ahead of former Vice President Joe Biden and former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg. The key policies that Sanders is running on are Medicare-for-All, The Green New Deal and tuition-free public college. These policies have all had wide-spread support among democratic voters and slim majorities of voters overall.  

Supporter demographic: Bernie has the most support, with The Economist citing him as being supported by 29% of the population. Demographic groups with the highest percentage of support for Bernie are voters under the age of 30, hispanic voters with and without a college education and voters who don't identify racially as white, black or hispanic. 

For more information on Sanders' policies, visit www.berniesanders.com/issues.

 

Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-M.A.

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Warren has released 76 plans on her website detailing her vision for the U.S. if she wins the presidency. Included in these plans is a 2% wealth tax, the cancelation of student loan debt, the break up of big-tech and Medicare for All. 

Supporter demographic: Warren's core support comes from college-educated white people, often with postgraduate degrees. She is more popular among women than men and is more likely to attract voters who follow politics closely. Voters who identify as being liberal are more likely to support her than moderate voters. 

For more information on Warren's policies, visit elizabethwarren.com/plans.

 

Mike Bloomberg, former mayor 

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Party affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Mike Bloomberg was the 108th mayor of New York City from 2002 until 2013 and is now making a big splash as a potential Democratic party nominee. Bloomberg's campaign has a lot of money behind it, and it isn't uncommon to see plenty of Bloomberg 2020 advertisements while scrolling through the internet.

According to Aljazeera, "Bloomberg has promised to reverse the Trump administration's tax cuts for wealthy Americans, and to impose a 5 percent surtax on taxpayers who earn more than five million dollars annually." Along with that, Bloomberg also wants to combat climate change by using clean energy sources as it pertains to transportation, rejoin the Paris agreement and has also consistently boasted his record when it comes to gun control and immigration reform, two hot topics pressing America right now. 

Supporter demographic: Bloomberg is currently supported by 18% of the population that has voted thus far. The demographic groups bringing in the most support for Bloomberg are voters aged 45-64, 65 plus and black voters without a college education. 

For more information on Bloomberg's policies, visit www.mikebloomberg.com/getting-it-done.

 

Gov. Bill Weld, R-M.A. 

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Republican

Major platform points: Weld has released 11 policy statements to his website, with more detailed plans on taxes and spending, healthcare and education. Weld is in favor of cutting both taxes and cutting overall government spending, slowing the rise in prices of healthcare like medication and procedures, in addition to being pro-school choice. Other topics Weld is in favor of is legislating no jail time for nonviolent criminal offenses and simplifying the immigration process.  

Supporter demographic: Weld has failed to gain much popularity among the Republican party, having only 1% of the population in support of him and his policies.

For more information on Weld's policies, visitwww.weld2020.org/policies.

 

President Donald Trump

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Republican

Major platform points: As the incumbent president, Trump will continue working toward the plans and goals from his first administration including improving the economy, cracking down on immigration reform and removing regulations he deems unnecessary.

Supporter demographic: Trump is supported by a majority of the Republican party, which is comprised of many different demographics of people.

For more information on Trump's policies, visitwww.promiseskept.com.

 

Amy Klobuchar, D-M.N.

U.S. Senate Photographic Studio-Frank Fey Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Klobuchar supports the expansion of Medicare/Medicaid, raising the minimum wage, comprehensive immigration reform and climate change. Klobuchar is a long-time Democratic senator who has a lengthy background of working on legislation. She currently has released a set of 19 plans if elected president.

Supporter demographic: Klobuchar is most popular among white voters with a college degree and with females aged 65 or older.

For more information on Klobuchar's policies, visitamyklobuchar.com/issues.

 

Joe Biden, former vice president

Photo by David Lienemann via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Biden supports eliminating private prisons, raising minimum wage, expanding Medicare coverage and increasing taxes on the wealthy. Biden has released over 30 policies detailing what he would do if elected president.

Supporter demographic: Biden is most popular among black voters both with and without a college degree. Biden is also heavily supported by all demographics of voters aged 65 or older.

For more information about Biden's policies, visitjoebiden.com/joes-vision.

 

Tom Steyer, businessman

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Steyer is a huge proponent of combating climate change, which was his strong point when he first declared candidacy. Steyer has now released 26 plans on a variety of topics, including universal health care, paid family leave and comprehensive immigration reform. 

Supporter demographic: Of the 2% of people supporting Tom Steyer, according to The Economist, those that most support him include black voters with a college education and voters aged 30-44. 

For more information about Steyer's policies, visit www.tomsteyer.com/policies. 

 

Tulsi Gabbard, D-H.I.

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Gabbard emphasizes veteran services such as veteran's healthcare, civil liberties, like the right of privacy, and criminal justice reform. She also supports a single-payer healthcare system. 

Supporter demographic: Gabbard polls under 1% with support centering around hispanic voters and conservative Democrats. 

For more information about Gabbard's policies, visit www.tulsi2020.com/issues.

Meet the candidates:

Pete Buttigieg, former mayor  

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: One of the understructures of Buttigieg's campaign is the need for generational change. As the youngest candidate, he aims to kickstart a fresh, young era of politics. A central part of his campaign is reforming the Supreme Court to 15 justices, with five Democrats, five Republicans and five apolitical judges comprising the seats. One of the many Deomcratic candidates to support capitalism, Buttigieg's economic platform aims to reinforce strong relations with labor unions and separate money from politics. On immigration, he supports DACA and the rights of Dreamers, opposes Trump's harsh deportation policies and considers sending troops to the border a waste of time. As former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, from 2012 to Jan. 1, 2020, Buttigieg had a complex relationship with police and the black community in the city. After controversially firing South Bend's first black police chief and refusing to release the recorded phone calls at the center of the debacle, the incident has been used as a criticism of his campaign.

Supporter demographic: Buttigieg's primary support comes from white, college-educated men and women, typically middle-aged and older. 

For more information on Buttigieg's policies, visit www.peteforamerica.com/issues.

 

Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-V.T. 

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political Affiliation: Democrat/Independent 

Major platform points: Sanders is an Independent senator from Vermont who is running for president in the 2020 Democratic Presidential Primary. Sanders has won the popular vote in the first three primary contests so far and has emerged nationally as the front-runner in the race, consistently ahead of former Vice President Joe Biden and former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg. The key policies that Sanders is running on are Medicare-for-All, The Green New Deal and tuition-free public college. These policies have all had wide-spread support among democratic voters and slim majorities of voters overall.  

Supporter demographic: Bernie has the most support, with The Economist citing him as being supported by 29% of the population. Demographic groups with the highest percentage of support for Bernie are voters under the age of 30, hispanic voters with and without a college education and voters who don't identify racially as white, black or hispanic. 

For more information on Sanders' policies, visit www.berniesanders.com/issues.

 

Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-M.A.

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Warren has released 76 plans on her website detailing her vision for the U.S. if she wins the presidency. Included in these plans is a 2% wealth tax, the cancelation of student loan debt, the break up of big-tech and Medicare for All. 

Supporter demographic: Warren's core support comes from college-educated white people, often with postgraduate degrees. She is more popular among women than men and is more likely to attract voters who follow politics closely. Voters who identify as being liberal are more likely to support her than moderate voters. 

For more information on Warren's policies, visit elizabethwarren.com/plans.

 

Mike Bloomberg, former mayor 

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Party affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Mike Bloomberg was the 108th mayor of New York City from 2002 until 2013 and is now making a big splash as a potential Democratic party nominee. Bloomberg's campaign has a lot of money behind it, and it isn't uncommon to see plenty of Bloomberg 2020 advertisements while scrolling through the internet.

According to Aljazeera, "Bloomberg has promised to reverse the Trump administration's tax cuts for wealthy Americans, and to impose a 5 percent surtax on taxpayers who earn more than five million dollars annually." Along with that, Bloomberg also wants to combat climate change by using clean energy sources as it pertains to transportation, rejoin the Paris agreement and has also consistently boasted his record when it comes to gun control and immigration reform, two hot topics pressing America right now. 

Supporter demographic: Bloomberg is currently supported by 18% of the population that has voted thus far. The demographic groups bringing in the most support for Bloomberg are voters aged 45-64, 65 plus and black voters without a college education. 

For more information on Bloomberg's policies, visit www.mikebloomberg.com/getting-it-done.

 

Gov. Bill Weld, R-M.A. 

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Republican

Major platform points: Weld has released 11 policy statements to his website, with more detailed plans on taxes and spending, healthcare and education. Weld is in favor of cutting both taxes and cutting overall government spending, slowing the rise in prices of healthcare like medication and procedures, in addition to being pro-school choice. Other topics Weld is in favor of is legislating no jail time for nonviolent criminal offenses and simplifying the immigration process.  

Supporter demographic: Weld has failed to gain much popularity among the Republican party, having only 1% of the population in support of him and his policies.

For more information on Weld's policies, visitwww.weld2020.org/policies.

 

President Donald Trump

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Republican

Major platform points: As the incumbent president, Trump will continue working toward the plans and goals from his first administration including improving the economy, cracking down on immigration reform and removing regulations he deems unnecessary.

Supporter demographic: Trump is supported by a majority of the Republican party, which is comprised of many different demographics of people.

For more information on Trump's policies, visitwww.promiseskept.com.

 

Amy Klobuchar, D-M.N.

U.S. Senate Photographic Studio-Frank Fey Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Klobuchar supports the expansion of Medicare/Medicaid, raising the minimum wage, comprehensive immigration reform and climate change. Klobuchar is a long-time Democratic senator who has a lengthy background of working on legislation. She currently has released a set of 19 plans if elected president.

Supporter demographic: Klobuchar is most popular among white voters with a college degree and with females aged 65 or older.

For more information on Klobuchar's policies, visitamyklobuchar.com/issues.

 

Joe Biden, former vice president

Photo by David Lienemann via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Biden supports eliminating private prisons, raising minimum wage, expanding Medicare coverage and increasing taxes on the wealthy. Biden has released over 30 policies detailing what he would do if elected president.

Supporter demographic: Biden is most popular among black voters both with and without a college degree. Biden is also heavily supported by all demographics of voters aged 65 or older.

For more information about Biden's policies, visitjoebiden.com/joes-vision.

 

Tom Steyer, businessman

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Steyer is a huge proponent of combating climate change, which was his strong point when he first declared candidacy. Steyer has now released 26 plans on a variety of topics, including universal health care, paid family leave and comprehensive immigration reform. 

Supporter demographic: Of the 2% of people supporting Tom Steyer, according to The Economist, those that most support him include black voters with a college education and voters aged 30-44. 

For more information about Steyer's policies, visit www.tomsteyer.com/policies. 

 

Tulsi Gabbard, D-H.I.

Photo via Wikimedia Commons

Political affiliation: Democrat

Major platform points: Gabbard emphasizes veteran services such as veteran's healthcare, civil liberties, like the right of privacy, and criminal justice reform. She also supports a single-payer healthcare system. 

Supporter demographic: Gabbard polls under 1% with support centering around hispanic voters and conservative Democrats. 

For more information about Gabbard's policies, visit www.tulsi2020.com/issues.

urn:contentItem:5XVV-91V1-JCBW-N0D2-00000-00Get tough on Big Tech2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:03ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 61Get tough on Big TechAlex Brummer

BRITAIN'S regulators don't have a great reputation. If utility enforcers had done a better job of getting trains to run on time, fix water leaks and come down heavily on rigged standard tariff energy prices then Labour's public ownership plans might have attracted more opprobrium.

But one regulator which has figured out that consumer interest and national interest are one and the same, is the Competition and Markets Authority.

The CMA's holiday season intervention against Amazon's effort to gain a foothold in the UK's restaurant delivery market by making a £442m investment in Deliveroo is a significant moment.

It reinforces the CMA's robust approach to making sure that, when it comes to food, citizens have choice and the best prices.

Critically, the CMA is not prepared to give Silicon Valley giants the benefit of the doubt. It is terrific that Amazon, Google and Apple regard the UK as a great place to invest and create high-tech jobs. But Britain also needs to know they will be good corporate citizens.

The main complaint is that big-tech fails to pay its fair share of taxes on vast UK turnovers. Our biggest grocers have been outspoken critics of how those who undercut the High Street pay pitiful amounts of business rates because of operations run from out-of-town warehouses. There is a bigger threat. The digital giants - which were the biggest movers on the US markets last year, advancing 40pc with a combined valuation of $5 trillion - are natural monopolists which seek to wipe out competition. Amazon's impact on the book trade is well documented. And Facebook, with its 2.45bn users, should never have been permitted to dominate social media by owning both WhatsApp and Instagram, giving it a stranglehold on digital advertising.

WHEN it comes to food, the CMA demonstrated in April 2019, when it blocked the merger of Sainsbury's and Asda, how it values the consumer and supplier interest above all else.

There is no substitute for good, focused management. Tesco (Chinese Christmas cards notwithstanding) demonstrated that it is possible to give consumers a good deal and treat suppliers fairly.

The Co-op has made a comeback by focusing on community services and produce.

And Aldi and Lidl are gaining market share by offering value across a narrow range.

There is no reason why Sainsbury's - with its Argos subsidiary - and Asda - with Walmart-scale ownership - should not do well as standalones.

Britain is a digital leader when it comes to the algorithms and logistics powering food services Deliveroo and Just Eat. That is why Amazon wants backdoor control over Deliveroo, and Just Eat finds itself facing two competing £4.9bn takeovers from Dutch rival www.Takeaway.com and South African-controlled Naspers.

This paper has favoured the Dutch offer for Just Eat partly because of the pledge to keep a London quotation. It would be far preferable were Just Eat the buyer, giving the UK the chance to build something global off its own bat.

Now that the CMA has intervened against Amazon, the competition regulator should also probe what a Just Eat takeover would mean for consumers, suppliers, UK technology and the public interest.

Deals involving food prices and services should never go through on the nod.

Wage to $13; Facebook Records Exposed; Carlos Ghosn RearrestedLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, April 4th, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Investors are waiting on any news out of the China trade talks. The president will meet with China's top negotiator at the White House this afternoon.

Futures are lower but just by a fraction. Dow Industrials down four points, S&P down 2-1/4, NASDAQ down 16. This after the markets were a little changed yesterday as well. The NASDAQ was the top performer. It was up two-thirds of one percent, 46 points higher. The Dow Industrials were up 39 at 4:00 on Wall Street yesterday. In Europe this morning, the major indices are mostly lower. The FT-100 is down 38 points, half a percent.

The CAC Quarante in Paris is down 17. The DAX is higher, although well off the highs of the morning. We did have had weaker-than-expected factory orders data out, and the GDP forecast, for ItalyGermany this morning, were downgraded. In Asia overnight, markets are mostly higher, as you can see there: Shanghai was the performer, China up almost one percent. Startling new details this morning. The Ethiopian Airlines crash; preliminary results of the investigation blamed Boeing 737 Max flight control system for the fatal crash.

Carlos Ghosn is back behind bars as I was about to start an exclusive interview with the former Nissan CEO last night, 10 agents walked into his house and took him away in a car. We've got full details this morning. Now, the interrogation has moved to his wife. They would not leave her alone last night; she could not go to the ladies' room alone. She said she had to go to the bathroom, an agent left the door open, and waited right there while she was in the bathed. She wanted to take a shower, a female agent stayed in the shower while she took a shower.

It's pretty extraordinary what's going on. He is now back behind bars. And, by the way, an update for you, prosecutors will not tell his lawyers why he was rearrested. We don't know. Google's voice assistant is getting some celebrity help. Find out who's lending their voice. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; The Wall Street Journal Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman; and Republican Strategist Erin Elmore. Good to see everybody this morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Well, this Ghosn story is just incredible, in my view. I don't know that it hampered any foreign investment into Japan, but you have to question the judicial system in Japan throwing somebody in jail without having his say or his chance, to explain himself. Just to be clear, he says he's innocent and that this was a coup, as I've been reporting for a hundred days now, that the people at Nissan teamed up with the Ministers of Industry to take him down so that Renault would not acquire Nissan. Pretty extraordinary stuff.

ERIN ELMORE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: This is the fourth time he's been re-arrested since December, which is very unusual in the Japanese legal system, which also has a 99 percent conviction rate.

BARTIROMO: Yes, this is all about squeezing Carlos Ghosn so much, so he admits to crimes that he did not do.

FREEMAN: Well, they'll get to make their case but obviously, the Japanese executives did not want this European control of the business. And you know, we'll see what their case is when they lay it out, but this kind of over the top series of actions, 10 agents, to capture Carlos Ghosn, as if he's some sort of -- you know -- crime -- chieftain, who's going to be fighting with them and they need 10 guys to restrain him. The bathroom sequence with his wife, you mentioned, it just -- it's a series of things that make you wonder: what is the point here other than to intimidate as opposed to search for justice? Well, eventually, we'll get to hear his side of the story, he was going to give his side to you --

BARTIROMO: Yes, he was.

FREEMAN: He wanted to then later have a larger press conference. This seems to have disrupted that and we've learned with the Japanese legal system, they may be able to keep him in jail quite a while now without being able to talk further to his attorneys -- very different from United States. I think we're all eager to finally hear his unfiltered account of events.

BARTIROMO: Right, and just to be clear, I did speak with Carlos Ghosn last week. And he says that this was a coup, his number two was afraid that he was going to get fired because the company was simply not doing well. And they had missed expectations, and revenue declines for four straight quarters, and he was getting ready to announce some consolidation. He said, he was not going to announce an out-and-out merger with Renault, but he was certainly going to make some big changes, and they didn't like that.

And so, they lured him to Japan, and they he arrested him with the help of the minister of industry in Japan. I'm hearing now that there is a back-and-forth between prime minister's office and the prosecutor's office. The prime minister's office did not want him rearrested. They thought -- he thought that this would be a stain on Japan, but the prosecutor went ahead and did it. 10 agents showing up last night, like I said, right before we were about to do an interview, which leads me to question whether or not her phone is tapped as well.

We know that he has a government phone, the lawyer gave him the phone to use, while he was in this apartment in Tokyo. But you know, I had been communicating with her, and her phone must be tapped. So, they showed up right before the interview to shut him down. They don't want him giving a press conference either; he said he wanted a press conference on April 11th. They don't want the news out; they don't want to hear his plea for innocence. So, there you go you go.

We'll follow that. Meanwhile, there is trouble for Tesla this morning. The stock is sliding nearly 10 percent, following weak deliver numbers. This is coming ahead of Elon Musk's SEC battle. He's headed to the SEC in court with him today. The stock is down 10 percent, as you can see. Kristina Partsinevelos is outside the court house. She's in downtown New York City. And Kristina, are you expecting to see Elon Musk today?

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: No, it seems like the rumor is that he probably won't show up, but you never know in these types of situations. The SEC. the Security Exchange Commission will be debating here behind me against Elon Musk. They're going to be squaring off at 2:00 p.m. time. They're going to be giving their oral arguments which have already been received by the judge. And what are they debating? They are debating whether Elon Musk is in contempt for a tweet, that he sent out on February 19.

This tweet reads: "Tesla made zero cars in 2011, but we'll make around 500,000 in 2019." This tweet was later updated. However, the SEC arguing that Musk infringed on his settlement with the SEC for a previous tweet in August where misled investors that he was going to take the company private. What we know from that settlement is that he had to pay $20 million; Tesla had to pays $20 million. He had to step down as chairman for three years, and he had to get his tweets preapproved. And that's the major debate today.

Musk, though, his legal team, are saying in his defense, two reasons. First, one, that his tweet on February 19th was a not material. All of that information about production rate was already in the earnings report, was already discussed on conference call. The second point is that all of this infringed on Elon Musk's freedom of speech. This is going to be debated, Maria, today at 2:00 p.m. The judge is -- according to legal experts we spoke to, not likely to come to a decision today, but could side with SEC, could side with Elon Musk, or scrap out the settlement altogether and start back at zero. So, we'll find out around 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time.

BARTIROMO: Wow! All right, Kristina, we'll be watching you all day today, ahead of that. Kristina Partsinevelos in New York. Meanwhile, we're going to turn to U.S.-China trade. President Trump just tweeted moments ago he says this: "Despite the unnecessary and destructive actions taken by the Fed, the economy is looking very strong, and China and USMCA deals are moving along nicely. There is little or no inflation and USA optimism is very high." President Trump meeting with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He at the White House.

The president is likely to announce as summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping later today, according to the Wall Street Journal. We are expecting that to be either later April or early May. Joining me right now is the Author of "The Coming Collapse of China," Gordon Chang. And Gordon, it's always a pleasure to see you. First, let's talk about the trade deal, what are you expecting in terms of the main tenants of any deal? Do you think we'll get to a deal between the U.S. and China?

GORDON CHANG, AUTHOR: Well, everyone says there will be a deal that they've settled 90 percent of the points. I'm not so sure that we're going to hear a deal announced in next day or so, you know, but next couple of months. The question, though, is you know we've had a decades of failed trade agreements with China. The question is do you remedy that with another deal? So, we'll see how this goes, but, clearly, you know, this is heading in that direction.

BARTIROMO: Well, it looks like the Chinese are willing to open up its markets, they're opening up the markets to financial services companies in the U.S. among other industries, and they're willing to buy more commodities. What about the big-ticket items, the I.P. theft, the forced transfer of technology?

CHANG: You know, that's the real (INAUDIBLE) of the problem. You know, people say: well, look, we're close to a deal, but they have not yet decided on the enforcement mechanisms that can get China to agree to. And so, that is really going to be the critical thing. And if President Trump doesn't agree to tough enforcement mechanisms, then clearly, this is not going to be a good deal for us. But if there are tough enforcement mechanisms, Xi Jinping, the Chinese ruler has a lot of incentive to say "no," because they're building up this narrative of national humiliation in China. And whenever they start talking about that, that's not a good thing.

BARTIROMO: Then, there's Huawei. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT, announcing it is ending collaborations with, and ZTE over alleged violations of U.S. sanctions. MIT also said it's reviewing the school's collaborations with China, Russia, and Saudi Arabia. This is really getting dicey around Huawei. I've spoken with the Secretary of State Mike Pompeo about this. He's trying to tell the Europeans: Look, you know, if you're going to use Huawei telecom, we're going to not share as much information with you. This is high stakes on Huawei.

CHANG: Well, it certainly is. You know, and one of the arguments that the United States has been making is that, that the 2017 national intelligence law in China requires Chinese parties to spy on others if China demands it. And certainly, you know, we've seen Huawei spy on the African Union, they did that for 12 -- for five years. And so, clearly, there's a strong case there, but, you know, Huawei is really supported by the Chinese Diplomatic Corps. Beijing has gotten behind this company, and that really should tell us a lot because this is a geopolitical issue for China, not just an economic one.

BARTIROMO: So, you do think that the president will be able to put in some kind of an enforcement mechanism? Should the Chinese not keep up their promises, not to steal from United States if there is more stealing of I.P., they snap back more tariffs, or what? What is the enforcement mechanism to get Beijing to keep the promises?

CHANG: They're going to keep some tariffs on, and President Trump has been very clear about that for last month. So, that looks like going it's to be the case.

BARTIROMO: I agree with you.

CHANG: And the Chinese have been saying: look, that's unacceptable to them. Now, I don't know where the middle ground here is -- you know, but clearly, this is where we either have a trade deal or we don't have one. And I sort of think that, you know, it's up to the president to just sort of increase the tariffs until the Chinese stop stealing our I.P. Because, really, you know, we've had agreements with China and very detailed agreements with China, and they have just dishonored all them.

BARTIROMO: Right, like the time they said they were going to buy all those beefs, and then they never bought the beef. I got to get your take on swine flu outbreak in China. China is not talking about this at all. But I was talking to an American businessman last night and he was telling me that China consumes and produces 50 percent of the world's pork. And right now, 20 percent of the pigs are diseased with swine flu. So, they are dying -- 20 percent of the pigs in China means that is a 100 million dead pigs. What are they going to do with a 100 million dead pigs? How do you dispose of 100 million dead pigs?

CHANG: You know, in previous instances like this, they just dump them in the river.

BARTIROMO: Right, exactly! But they can't dump 100 million dead pigs in the river, right?

CHANG: Yes, there's going to be a lot of burning of pigs and the rest of it. The issue here for the United States is that China has agreed to buy more soybeans, but with fewer pigs, they're not going to need soybeans as much as, you know, had anticipated. So, this is going to be another one of those difficult issues between China and U.S. Do they actually buy commodities in the amounts agreed?

BARTIROMO: Earlier, I spoke with New Jersey Congressman Jeff Van Drew about this very issue. Watch what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JEFF VAN DREW (D), NEW JERSEY: Well, it's definitely going to push some prices higher. There's no question -- when you're going to have a shortage of meat, and you're going to certainly going have a shortage of pork, and the prices are going up -- number one. Secondly, you know, we just have to make sure and thank God, we have got a good Department of Ags to make sure that we keep everything safe over here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, the source that I was talking to last night said it's not just pork prices that are going up, it's going to ripple throughout meat. It will go chicken prices, and meat prices as well, what do you think?

CHANG: Yes. Well, certainly, because, you know, pork is such an important staple in China. If you don't have it, you're going to have to eat something else. And so, this is going to affect prices in Asia, and which means it's going to affect prices here. It's going to have a knock-on effect, as I mentioned on soybeans and other commodities. So, this is going to be felt worldwide. Because I'm actually surprised that it's only 50 percent of the world's pork. I think that it's actually higher --

BARTIROMO: It's more than 50 percent.

CHANG: I thought so --

BARTIROMO: Wow! How come nobody talking about the swine flu? You don't see this reported anywhere? I mean, I didn't.

CHANG: This -- there was a little bit of reporting about two weeks ago, because the U.S. Department of Agriculture confiscated Chinese pork coming into U.S., which was diseased. And so, that obviously was important to the A.G. markets here. But you're right, for the most part, this is a story which no one is really talking about, and it does have effect through both the markets and the trade talks.

BARTIROMO: I'm glad that we discussed it. Gordon, it's good to see you.

CHANG: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: That you so much. Gordon Chang joining us. Coming up, startling new developments in the case against Boeing. The very latest on the Ethiopian Airlines crash investigation, that's next. And then, Carlos Ghosn back behind bars -- I was about to start an exclusive interview with him last night, and as we were about to start the call, 10 agents walked in, took him away. More on the story coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The 737 Max jet, the crash in Ethiopia last month reportedly had a damaged sensor. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Learning some new things here, Maria. The angle of an attack sensor on the Boeing 737 Max was reportedly damaged during takeoff, by a foreign object or a bird. That is according to ABC News right now. Sources are saying that the sensor then sent false readings to the plane's anti-stall system, as the pilots tried desperately to keep it from pushing the plane nose down. Meanwhile, the preliminary report on the crash from the Ethiopian government that came out this morning, is taking aim at Boeing, finding that the Ethiopian jet apparently nose-dived before it went down and the flight crew performed, according to this report, all the procedures recommended by Boeing, but still could not control that plane.

Well, Target raising its minimum wage. The retailer announcing workers are going to now earn $13.00 an hour. This starts in June, that is up from $12.00. The move coming as retailers have been finding it tougher to attract workers. Target employs over 300,000 people right now.

Well, Google Assistant launching its first celebrity voice today, and here you go, it starts with singer, John legend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN LEGEND, SINGER: Whoa. I am feeling this new voice. You can find me on all kinds of devices: phones, Google Home, and if I'm lucky, in your heart.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Yes.

(LAUGHTER).

CASONE: You bet, you John! The musician is going to give you the weather, maybe sing you happy birthday, tell you a joke. This voice is only available for a limited time unfortunately. Google says, there are going to be some more celebrity cameos, thanks to approve voice synthesizing technology. I would love a little happy birthday from John Legend. Bring it on!

BARTIROMO: I like that, yes! Which celebrity voice do you guys want on your Google devices? James, what about you?

FREEMAN: I guess I'd go with Sinatra, If I had --

BARTIROMO: Good one, good one.

ELMORE: I would like Dolly Parton, right?

FREEMAN: Yes, I'll go with Dolly.

ELMORE: She's great.

BARTIROMO: OK.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes.

FREEMAN: Was I fortunate to meet her in the green room in this building a couple of years ago. And --

BARTIROMO: She's a doll, huh!

FREEMAN: She is just as wonderful, as you always hear about.

ELMORE: Good to wake up with a voice like that.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but when she comes in -- she comes in, I don't care what time of day it is, Dolly Parton is always extremely professional. And she looks you in the eye. I think of -- like a lot of people can learn from that. She's incredible.

BARTIROMO: She's real deal. And now, she's going to the racetrack.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly, you got to watch Dolly. I mean, she can dust anybody. That's been clear with her long career. But anyway, I'll do like, Gilbert Godfrey. Remember Geico -- that was not Geico.

BARTIROMO: The duck --

MCDOWELL: No, the duck -- the duck fired him.

BARTIROMO: That'd be a good one.

MCDOWELL: I would take Gilbert Godfrey. Not just because it'll make you pay attention.

BARTIROMO: Quick break, coming up, Carlos Ghosn back behind bars. I was about to start an exclusive interview with the former Nissan CEO when he was arrested again last night, the full story coming up. Then, privacy alert; Facebook leaving hundreds of millions of user data exposed on public Amazon servers. How the company is resolving that problem? Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Futures are quiet this morning pointing to a lower opening for the broader averages. We are waiting on any news out of the U.S.-China trade talks. JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon released his annual letter this morning, writing this: "There are legitimate concerns around China's economy in addition to trade, but they are manageable." He calls the U.S. trade issues China substantial and real.

Want to talk about, Jamie Dimon's letter and really the issues around China. He's right, and of course, business wants to get into China, and wants the Chinese to open up its markets so that American businesses can sell to the 1.4 billion people. That's one of the items on the list.

FREEMAN: Yes, and the question is, do they mean it this time? Because what the messages out of China, the formal statements, the new policies, new laws, they -- they have -- announced within the last few months, are all about solving this problem. Now, the question is are they going to mean it this time? Are they actually going to allow U.S. businesses to operate there in a -- fair manner? And we'll see when this trade deal.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and that's just one of several elements. You've also got China buying more commodities from the U.S., and of course the big-ticket items, the I.P. theft, and the forced transfer of technology, Erin.

ELMORE: Jamie Dimon is optimistic about China, but there are true concerns there, not just trade and soybeans. This is about a lot more. There are copyright infringement I.P. laws, there are no regulations in terms of business, there are no labor laws, there's no minimum wage. They don't care about pollution. So, there's a whole lot of issues going on in China, that are a lot bigger than, I think, people are getting credit for and there are concerns going into China.

FREEMAN: I think the president ought to really think about taking off the tariffs if he gets the deal he wants. Because if you leave the tariffs in place, pending a check of China's behavior in the future, what did we really accomplish here?

BARTIROMO: Not getting the deal that he wants because it seems like he is willing to keep some tariffs in place. I mean, that -- it seems like that's where this is going.

MCDOWELL: He is, clearly. The steel and aluminum tariffs are still in place and you're worried about the state of the U.S. auto industry -- well, you just drove up their costs by billions of dollars, and you're still basically putting a thumb down on our auto industry and our manufactures, and trying to blame somebody else for it. That's not -- that tariffs probably won't go away anytime soon.

FREEMAN: Which means that this drag on our economy may not be relieved by a deal if there's no relief from the essentially taxes on consumers.

BARTIROMO: Yes, even though, the economy seems to be holding up strongly in the face of weakness across the world. The unemployment numbers will be out tomorrow. We've got our jobs Friday tomorrow. Joining us to preview that and talk about, investing today is Federated Investor Senior Equity Strategist, Linda Duessel. Linda, good to see you this morning, thanks so much for weighing in here. First, the employment, the jobs number tomorrow; how much is priced into the market, what are you expecting from the jobs' report out tomorrow morning at 8:30 a.m. Eastern? We're expected to see the unemployment rate hold steady at 3.8 percent with 180,000 jobs added to the economy in the month of March.

LINDA DUESSEL, SENIOR EQUITY STRATEGIST, FEDERATED INVESTOR: Well, it's a fully employed economy. It doesn't seem to me that we should worry about it being too hot or even too cold. So, that should really not be a market moving event, I wouldn't think.

BARTIROMO: So, what do you think is going to drive markets then? How are you positioning clients? Do you want to buy stocks here or pull back?

DUESSEL: Well, we're bullish on the market. We think the S&P finishes the at 3100, and -- you know, that's based on just a reasonable earnings growth rate and the market deciding by the end of the year that actually, there's not an inflation problem, the fed could stay at bay for some time and we don't have to worry about unemployment rising dramatically and a recession on pace. However, we just ran too fast. Too fast on the way down last year the end, and too quickly on the way up this year. The bull, which we are, would like nice a consolidation in here.

ELMORE: Good morning, Linda, Erin Elmore here. Born and raised in Pittsburgh, so love your great city. But given this period of low volatility, it looks like Fed isn't going to raise interest rates anytime soon. What sectors, do you think, are still undervalued, that you think have an opportunity for a run-up?

DUESSEL: Well, you know, we like growth, we believe it's a back half of the cycle, and so that would mean, you want to get growth, you want to get more reliable growth. We really think that ought to have some have balance in your portfolio, because as we all know, there are a number of worries about trade around the globe, worries about China maybe falling into recession, worry about our own upcoming political season now, and what that might mean for the earnings outlooks. A lot of exposure out there, the binary evens that we don't know how they'll work out. And so, we think everybody ought to have some balance to their portfolio. And that means, really, the high-quality dividend paid stocks. I like it very much for income; they are not expensive right now.

BARTIROMO: All right, real quick before you go. We've got the calendar one first-quarter earnings coming out beginning on Friday, with the banks, the 12th. Would you put money to work in those areas ahead of earnings or are you expecting a tough earnings period here? Real quick, Linda.

DUESSEL: Well, I think that the earnings season to be tough in Q1 is already understood. Nobody cares about that as much as the outlook into the next quarter and rest of the year, and financial is really looking expensive to us, and that's one of our over weights.

BARTIROMO: All right. We leave it there. Linda, good to see you. Thanks so much. Linda Duessel joining us there from Federated. Don't miss our "Jobs in America" special tomorrow morning. It kicks off 8:00 a.m. Eastern. We are identifying where the jobs are in this economy right now, all hands-on deck for jobs in America tomorrow morning, 8:00 a.m. right here.

President Trump just tweeting on the Mueller investigation. Here's what he just said: "According to polling, few people seem to care about the Russian collusion hoax, but some Democrats are fighting hard to keep the witch hunt alive. They should focus on legislation, or even better in investigation of how ridiculous collusion delusion got started. So illegal," writes the president.

A quick break and then coming up next, the border battle: President Trump is preparing to visit southern border in California tomorrow as he eases back on the shutdown threats. The economic impact of an immigration debate, next. And then Facebook is under fire again; the networking giant leaving hundreds of millions of users' data exposed. The company's efforts to fix the breach, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, April 4th. Your top stories right now 8:33 a.m. on the East Coast. Markets are searching for direction this morning, take a look, Dow Industrials now up 18 points, the S&P 500 exactly where it closed yesterday, and the NASDAQ down 10 points right now. Investors are waiting on some news out of the China trade talks, and they are thinking that it could be good news, and it looks like the two are very disclose.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the indices, and we do see weakness there. FT-100 down 37 points, a half of a percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris is down 12, but the DAX Index is up 26 points, even though we did get weaker-than-expected economic data, factory orders down on -- in Germany this morning. In Asia overnight, markets finished mostly higher, with the exception of Hong Kong, as you can see.

Well, he is back behind bars, former Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn was rearrested last night moments before I was about to start an exclusive interview with him on the telephone. The very latest coming up. Privacy alert, Facebook reportedly leaving the data of millions of users exposed on Amazon servers. How the company hopes to fix it. Then the state of the housing market, it is getting a boost due to falling mortgage rates. We take a closer look there later this hour.

But first, our top story this half an hour, the battle at the border. President Trump headed to California, the California border tomorrow, as he eases back on the threat to shutdown border operations, this comes as Mexican officials are warning of port of entry delays, that's causing tens of millions of dollars in business losses. Joining us now is the former CEO of McDonald's, former Famous Dave's Barbecue CEO and FAT Brands International Chairman, Ed Rensi. Ed, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks for being here.

ED RENSI, CHAIRMAN, FAT BRANDS INTERNATIONAL: Good morning. Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: As a business guy, what is the impact of the border closing? Give us the news.

RENSI: Well, it's going to be -- it's going to be significant. I think Trump is using this as a negotiating ploy, frankly, because the impact would be staggering. You know, you're talking about $12 billion worth of just food and produce coming across that border annually. You look at all the car parts, medical supplies, and things of that nature, it's going to impact a lot of businesses in the United States. I know they're working right now to try to minimize some of that stuff, but the reality is we got a sovereignty issue and our border is being penetrated. If it were just people looking for an opportunity, that'd be one thing, but we got a lot of bad characters coming into this country and it's dangerous and we need to protect ourselves.

FREEMAN: Ed, hi. James Freeman here at The Wall Street Journal, and kudos on naming your company FAT Brands. Very strong. MCDOWELL: I'll weigh in on this, and I'll get into trouble, but I think it's always been the responsibility of a woman, if a man gets in your space, or another woman gets in your space, then you need to look at him and say, hey bud, you need to have an elbow here, and say, you know what, I'm not that kind of person, don't like, pinch my elbow, don't -- because I'm not that kind of person and --

BARTIROMO: I'll have what I would do, get off of me.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Just get off of me.

MCDOWELL: I have said that to people. There was a creepy guy who was on air, once, here, it's not anybody working in management or who was on staff, but he started giving me a shoulder rub in the hair room, and I turned around, I was like, you need to put it in reverse, buddy, and back this truck up.

BARTIROMO: Back off.

MCDOWELL: Don't put your hands on me. And you know what? If somebody like Joe Biden, like, put his arm around me, I would just think that that was just a sign of affection --

ELMORE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- in a very, excuse me, nonsexual way, Southerners are exactly like this, men and women, and I always hate it, because I encountered this in New York, where you would refer to somebody -- when I first started working here as, thanks, hon.

And then, the person would go around you, and go to management, and complain about you, rather than just looking you in the eye and saying, please, don't address me that way.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I'm not your honey.

MCDOWELL: You know what, that's why -- I

BARTIROMO: I think what I hear you saying is, he shouldn't get bullied out of this.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Just because he smells somebody's hair or kisses them, maybe he shouldn't get bullied by this, even though norms have changed.

MCDOWELL: I find it very --

BARTIROMO: And there's no tolerance --

MCDOWELL: -- suspect that these women come out now, and then complain about it publicly --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- when he's about to declare his run for the Democratic nomination. People who clearly, one of them, at least, a Bernie Sanders supporter. That they say it publicly, but never had -- never looked at him and said, you know, and said, I'm not comfortable with this.

ELMORE: But speaking of publicly, all of this conduct occurred in public. No one is alleging anything that wasn't on camera or in front of a big crowd. No one said things happened behind closed doors or in a bar or in a restaurant or in a hotel or on text. This was all conduct that occurred in the public eye. So, what could have really happened?

BARTIROMO: Having said that, will we be talking about Biden, as a 2020 contender, in six months?

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Will he be able to get over this?

MCDOWELL: The -- really quickly, the one thing that he does -- that Karl Rove writes about, which you mentioned, that he needs to stop apologizing. Remember, Cynthia Nixon called him out for referring to Vice President Mike Pence as being decent.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: We actually talked about that on the show.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And he needs to stop apologizing for that.

FREEMAN: Well, his only premise as a candidate is that he's going to chart a more moderate course. So, if he begins his candidacy, if he does become a candidate, and he spends all of this time trying to persuade people that he's just as woke, just as hard left as the other candidates, then there's no point in running.

BARTIROMO: I can tell you for sure that Congressman Tim Ryan, from Ohio, will enter the race. He is going to run for the presidency. So, this question about Joe Biden is opening up a whole new avenue for Tim Ryan. He could be a force because he's from Ohio, he's a working man's guy, he's not radical left, crazy idea Green New Deal, 70 percent tax rates. What do you think?

FREEMAN: Well, this does look like a bet that Biden's not running.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: But, you know, he's not --Ryan is not that moderate, so that's going to be a question, but definitely, striking a more moderate tone at least.

MCDOWELL: I know. They can't beat you on ideas. They'll try and shut down based on your personality, and I think Joe Biden's feeling that.

BARTIROMO: So, moderate relative to --

FREEMAN: Yes, right.

BARTIROMO: All right. Let's take a short break, then we've got to get to Cheryl. Markets are lower this morning after finishing higher yesterday. We'll tell you what's moving and we'll tell you the big news of the morning when we come right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A new CEO at PG&E. Cheryl Casone with headlines now. Cheryl, good morning.

CASONE: Maria, good morning again. PG&E tapping Bill Johnson, he is the current head of the Tennessee Valley Authority. He will now lead the troubled California utility. PG&E also announcing a new board as it looks for a way out of bankruptcy. They face billions of dollars in liabilities for their role in starting deadly wildfires in California.

Well, severe weather in the south to tell you about, after hitting Texas, a series of thunderstorms is ready to slam other southern states, including Oklahoma, Arkansas and Mississippi. Large hail and damaging winds expected across the region today. A few tornadoes could develop. Forecasters say the system is going to continue to move east tomorrow.

And finally, Maria, it is National Burrito Day. Mexican food chains from Chipotle, (INAUDIBLE) are offering deals to celebrate. And you can be, if you want, a human burrito. Yep. Tortilla blankets for babies and adults now viral. Now, if a burrito isn't your thing, Maria, and I have no idea if it's not, possibly more important, May 5th is National Enchilada Day. Let's get excited about that. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: I really want to wrap up like a burrito.

CASONE: Don't you?

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: All right, markets this morning seem to be searching for direction, of course we are waiting on news out of the China-U.S. trade talks. They are close. I understand that we got a market that is very close to where the indices closed yesterday. JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon out with this annual letter. In it he says this: "There are legitimate concerns around China's economy in addition trade but they are manageable." He also calls the U.S. trade issues with China substantial and real. Joining us right now the Kadina Group President, Gary B. Smith. Gary, good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

GARY B. SMITH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: How do you see markets today? Are you still bullish?

SMITH: I am getting less bullish, I'm afraid. You know, the times that we've been together in New York, I think I was very bullish. Hopefully at the right time. Now, as we start to get toward those old highs and the fact that volatility has dropped, back to where it was in last October, when there was really nothing on the horizon to bother it, bothers me. Because it tells me there might be something out there. We don't know what it is, some black swan event. Maybe it's in the investigation into Trump's tax returns, maybe it's the whole China thing going south. I get worried as we approach those old highs, especially as we've gone almost straight up since Christmas.

BARTIROMO: Anywhere to hide? Real quick. You're expecting a decline in stocks then?

SMITH: I think we go to the old highs. That's another 700 points. I guess if I was an investor, I'd probably start to take a little off the table, maybe go to 50 percent cash as we get there and kind of wait and see.

BARTIROMO: Gary, thanks for weighing in briefly. We appreciate it. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the Spurs' head coach ejected, just 63 seconds into the game. Jared Max on sports, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SPORTS REPORTER: Like they say, that escalated quickly. Gregg Popovich, the first NBA coach in seven years to get kicked out of the game in the opening two minutes, barely lasted one minute -- 63 seconds into the Spurs' eventual loss at Denver. Pop was gone after being issued a second technical foul. Maybe something with coach from Texas last night, because the Houston Astros' manager and head coach were both kicked out pitch apart in a loss to the Rangers.

If you like trying to hit a golf ball through a moving windmill, you are going to want to check out Steph Curry's new venture. Yes, the Golden State Warrior star is going to become the executive producer and resident golf pro for a 10-episode series on ABC called "Holy Moly." (INAUDIBLE) but are going together the best mini golf players to compete on epic course. Each episode has 12 contestants and $25,000 to the winner for each show.

What was it? Eight days ago? We told you that that ultimate fighting champ star, Conor McGregor, said he was retiring and now we suspected that it probably wouldn't the case. Well, last night, Conor McGregor pretty said he's unretiring, on the same day where had exchanged nasty tweets with fight rival, Khabib Nurmagomedov. Conor wrote on Twitter: "I want to move forward with my fans of all faiths and backgrounds. All faiths challenge us to be our best selves. It's one world and one for all. And now, we see you in the Octagon." So, he's going back.

And the queen of country is about to be the queen of the racetrack. Check this out! Dolly Parton is sponsoring her own race car driver. Tyler Reddick is going to speed off in the pink Chevy Camaro at a race this weekend. The Xfinity Series on Saturday in Dolly's home state of Tennessee in Bristol. Dolly Parton on a race, Maria. How cool is that?

BARTIROMO: I like it. Do you know anything about that, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: The Xfinity race, which is on Saturday, and it's at Bristol motor speedway's thunder dome. It's the greatest racetrack in racing, so everything should watch it and everybody loves Dolly, everybody.

BARTIROMO: And I like that pink car. Thank you, Jared. Jared's sports reports are on Fox News Headlines 24/7 or Sirius Radio XM 115. Still ahead, the Patagonia power suit no more; why you'll no longer see the iconic clothing brand at some top tech and finance companies? Right here, next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

Wage to $13; Facebook Records Exposed; Carlos Ghosn RearrestedLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, April 4th, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Investors are waiting on any news out of the China trade talks. The president will meet with China's top negotiator at the White House this afternoon.

Futures are lower but just by a fraction. Dow Industrials down four points, S&P down 2-1/4, NASDAQ down 16. This after the markets were a little changed yesterday as well. The NASDAQ was the top performer. It was up two-thirds of one percent, 46 points higher. The DowIndustrials were up 39 at 4:00 on Wall Street yesterday. In Europe this morning, the major indices are mostly lower. The FT-100 is down 38 points, half a percent.

The CAC Quarante in Paris is down 17. The DAX is higher, although well off the highs of the morning. We did have had weaker-than-expected factory orders data out, and the GDP forecast, for ItalyGermany this morning, were downgraded. In Asia overnight, markets are mostly higher, as you can see there: Shanghai was the performer, China up almost one percent. Startling new details this morning. The Ethiopian Airlines crash; preliminary results of the investigation blamed Boeing 737 Max flight control system for the fatal crash.

Carlos Ghosn is back behind bars as I was about to start an exclusive interview with the former Nissan CEO last night, 10 agents walked into his house and took him away in a car. We've got full details this morning. Now, the interrogation has moved to his wife. They would not leave her alone last night; she could not go to the ladies' room alone. She said she had to go to the bathroom, an agent left the door open, and waited right there while she was in the bathed. She wanted to take a shower, a female agent stayed in the shower while she took a shower.

It's pretty extraordinary what's going on. He is now back behind bars. And, by the way, an update for you, prosecutors will not tell his lawyers why he was rearrested. We don't know. Google's voice assistant is getting some celebrity help. Find out who's lending their voice. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; The Wall Street Journal Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman; and Republican Strategist Erin Elmore. Good to see everybody this morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Well, this Ghosn story is just incredible, in my view. I don't know that it hampered any foreign investment into Japan, but you have to question the judicial system in Japan throwing somebody in jail without having his say or his chance, to explain himself. Just to be clear, he says he's innocent and that this was a coup, as I've been reporting for a hundred days now, that the people at Nissan teamed up with the Ministers of Industry to take him down so that Renault would not acquire Nissan. Pretty extraordinary stuff.

ERIN ELMORE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: This is the fourth time he's been re-arrested since December, which is very unusual in the Japanese legal system, which also has a 99 percent conviction rate.

BARTIROMO: Yes, this is all about squeezing Carlos Ghosn so much, so he admits to crimes that he did not do.

FREEMAN: Well, they'll get to make their case but obviously, the Japanese executives did not want this European control of the business. And you know, we'll see what their case is when they lay it out, but this kind of over the top series of actions, 10 agents, to capture Carlos Ghosn, as if he's some sort of -- you know -- crime -- chieftain, who's going to be fighting with them and they need 10 guys to restrain him. The bathroom sequence with his wife, you mentioned, it just -- it's a series of things that make you wonder: what is the point here other than to intimidate as opposed to search for justice? Well, eventually, we'll get to hear his side of the story, he was going to give his side to you --

BARTIROMO: Yes, he was.

FREEMAN: He wanted to then later have a larger press conference. This seems to have disrupted that and we've learned with the Japanese legal system, they may be able to keep him in jail quite a while now without being able to talk further to his attorneys -- very different from United States. I think we're all eager to finally hear his unfiltered account of events.

BARTIROMO: Right, and just to be clear, I did speak with Carlos Ghosn last week. And he says that this was a coup, his number two was afraid that he was going to get fired because the company was simply not doing well. And they had missed expectations, and revenue declines for four straight quarters, and he was getting ready to announce some consolidation. He said, he was not going to announce an out-and-out merger with Renault, but he was certainly going to make some big changes, and they didn't like that.

And so, they lured him to Japan, and they he arrested him with the help of the minister of industry in Japan. I'm hearing now that there is a back-and-forth between prime minister's office and the prosecutor's office. The prime minister's office did not want him rearrested. They thought -- he thought that this would be a stain on Japan, but the prosecutor went ahead and did it. 10 agents showing up last night, like I said, right before we were about to do an interview, which leads me to question whether or not her phone is tapped as well.

We know that he has a government phone, the lawyer gave him the phone to use, while he was in this apartment in Tokyo. But you know, I had been communicating with her, and her phone must be tapped. So, they showed up right before the interview to shut him down. They don't want him giving a press conference either; he said he wanted a press conference on April 11th. They don't want the news out; they don't want to hear his plea for innocence. So, there you go you go.

We'll follow that. Meanwhile, there is trouble for Tesla this morning. The stock is sliding nearly 10 percent, following weak deliver numbers. This is coming ahead of Elon Musk's SEC battle. He's headed to the SEC in court with him today. The stock is down 10 percent, as you can see. Kristina Partsinevelos is outside the court house. She's in downtown New York City. And Kristina, are you expecting to see Elon Musk today?

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: No, it seems like the rumor is that he probably won't show up, but you never know in these types of situations. The SEC. the Security Exchange Commission will be debating here behind me against Elon Musk. They're going to be squaring off at 2:00 p.m. time. They're going to be giving their oral arguments which have already been received by the judge. And what are they debating? They are debating whether Elon Musk is in contempt for a tweet, that he sent out on February 19.

This tweet reads: "Tesla made zero cars in 2011, but we'll make around 500,000 in 2019." This tweet was later updated. However, the SEC arguing that Musk infringed on his settlement with the SEC for a previous tweet in August where misled investors that he was going to take the company private. What we know from that settlement is that he had to pay $20 million; Tesla had to pays $20 million. He had to step down as chairman for three years, and he had to get his tweets preapproved. And that's the major debate today.

Musk, though, his legal team, are saying in his defense, two reasons. First, one, that his tweet on February 19th was a not material. All of that information about production rate was already in the earnings report, was already discussed on conference call. The second point is that all of this infringed on Elon Musk's freedom of speech. This is going to be debated, Maria, today at 2:00 p.m. The judge is -- according to legal experts we spoke to, not likely to come to a decision today, but could side with SEC, could side with Elon Musk, or scrap out the settlement altogether and start back at zero. So, we'll find out around 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time.

BARTIROMO: Wow! All right, Kristina, we'll be watching you all day today, ahead of that. Kristina Partsinevelos in New York. Meanwhile, we're going to turn to U.S.-China trade. President Trump just tweeted moments ago he says this: "Despite the unnecessary and destructive actions taken by the Fed, the economy is looking very strong, and China and USMCA deals are moving along nicely. There is little or no inflation and USA optimism is very high." President Trump meeting with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He at the White House.

The president is likely to announce as summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping later today, according to the Wall Street Journal. We are expecting that to be either later April or early May.
