Wage to $13; Facebook Records Exposed; Carlos Ghosn RearrestedLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, April 4th, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Investors are waiting on any news out of the China trade talks. The president will meet with China's top negotiator at the White House this afternoon.

Futures are lower but just by a fraction. Dow Industrials down four points, S&P down 2-1/4, NASDAQ down 16. This after the markets were a little changed yesterday as well. The NASDAQ was the top performer. It was up two-thirds of one percent, 46 points higher. The Dow Industrials were up 39 at 4:00 on Wall Street yesterday. In Europe this morning, the major indices are mostly lower. The FT-100 is down 38 points, half a percent.

The CAC Quarante in Paris is down 17. The DAX is higher, although well off the highs of the morning. We did have had weaker-than-expected factory orders data out, and the GDP forecast, for ItalyGermany this morning, were downgraded. In Asia overnight, markets are mostly higher, as you can see there: Shanghai was the performer, China up almost one percent. Startling new details this morning. The Ethiopian Airlines crash; preliminary results of the investigation blamed Boeing 737 Max flight control system for the fatal crash.

Carlos Ghosn is back behind bars as I was about to start an exclusive interview with the former Nissan CEO last night, 10 agents walked into his house and took him away in a car. We've got full details this morning. Now, the interrogation has moved to his wife. They would not leave her alone last night; she could not go to the ladies' room alone. She said she had to go to the bathroom, an agent left the door open, and waited right there while she was in the bathed. She wanted to take a shower, a female agent stayed in the shower while she took a shower.

It's pretty extraordinary what's going on. He is now back behind bars. And, by the way, an update for you, prosecutors will not tell his lawyers why he was rearrested. We don't know. Google's voice assistant is getting some celebrity help. Find out who's lending their voice. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; The Wall Street Journal Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman; and Republican Strategist Erin Elmore. Good to see everybody this morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Well, this Ghosn story is just incredible, in my view. I don't know that it hampered any foreign investment into Japan, but you have to question the judicial system in Japan throwing somebody in jail without having his say or his chance, to explain himself. Just to be clear, he says he's innocent and that this was a coup, as I've been reporting for a hundred days now, that the people at Nissan teamed up with the Ministers of Industry to take him down so that Renault would not acquire Nissan. Pretty extraordinary stuff.

ERIN ELMORE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: This is the fourth time he's been re-arrested since December, which is very unusual in the Japanese legal system, which also has a 99 percent conviction rate.

BARTIROMO: Yes, this is all about squeezing Carlos Ghosn so much, so he admits to crimes that he did not do.

FREEMAN: Well, they'll get to make their case but obviously, the Japanese executives did not want this European control of the business. And you know, we'll see what their case is when they lay it out, but this kind of over the top series of actions, 10 agents, to capture Carlos Ghosn, as if he's some sort of -- you know -- crime -- chieftain, who's going to be fighting with them and they need 10 guys to restrain him. The bathroom sequence with his wife, you mentioned, it just -- it's a series of things that make you wonder: what is the point here other than to intimidate as opposed to search for justice? Well, eventually, we'll get to hear his side of the story, he was going to give his side to you --

BARTIROMO: Yes, he was.

FREEMAN: He wanted to then later have a larger press conference. This seems to have disrupted that and we've learned with the Japanese legal system, they may be able to keep him in jail quite a while now without being able to talk further to his attorneys -- very different from United States. I think we're all eager to finally hear his unfiltered account of events.

BARTIROMO: Right, and just to be clear, I did speak with Carlos Ghosn last week. And he says that this was a coup, his number two was afraid that he was going to get fired because the company was simply not doing well. And they had missed expectations, and revenue declines for four straight quarters, and he was getting ready to announce some consolidation. He said, he was not going to announce an out-and-out merger with Renault, but he was certainly going to make some big changes, and they didn't like that.

And so, they lured him to Japan, and they he arrested him with the help of the minister of industry in Japan. I'm hearing now that there is a back-and-forth between prime minister's office and the prosecutor's office. The prime minister's office did not want him rearrested. They thought -- he thought that this would be a stain on Japan, but the prosecutor went ahead and did it. 10 agents showing up last night, like I said, right before we were about to do an interview, which leads me to question whether or not her phone is tapped as well.

We know that he has a government phone, the lawyer gave him the phone to use, while he was in this apartment in Tokyo. But you know, I had been communicating with her, and her phone must be tapped. So, they showed up right before the interview to shut him down. They don't want him giving a press conference either; he said he wanted a press conference on April 11th. They don't want the news out; they don't want to hear his plea for innocence. So, there you go you go.

We'll follow that. Meanwhile, there is trouble for Tesla this morning. The stock is sliding nearly 10 percent, following weak deliver numbers. This is coming ahead of Elon Musk's SEC battle. He's headed to the SEC in court with him today. The stock is down 10 percent, as you can see. Kristina Partsinevelos is outside the court house. She's in downtown New York City. And Kristina, are you expecting to see Elon Musk today?

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: No, it seems like the rumor is that he probably won't show up, but you never know in these types of situations. The SEC. the Security Exchange Commission will be debating here behind me against Elon Musk. They're going to be squaring off at 2:00 p.m. time. They're going to be giving their oral arguments which have already been received by the judge. And what are they debating? They are debating whether Elon Musk is in contempt for a tweet, that he sent out on February 19.

This tweet reads: "Tesla made zero cars in 2011, but we'll make around 500,000 in 2019." This tweet was later updated. However, the SEC arguing that Musk infringed on his settlement with the SEC for a previous tweet in August where misled investors that he was going to take the company private. What we know from that settlement is that he had to pay $20 million; Tesla had to pays $20 million. He had to step down as chairman for three years, and he had to get his tweets preapproved. And that's the major debate today.

Musk, though, his legal team, are saying in his defense, two reasons. First, one, that his tweet on February 19th was a not material. All of that information about production rate was already in the earnings report, was already discussed on conference call. The second point is that all of this infringed on Elon Musk's freedom of speech. This is going to be debated, Maria, today at 2:00 p.m. The judge is -- according to legal experts we spoke to, not likely to come to a decision today, but could side with SEC, could side with Elon Musk, or scrap out the settlement altogether and start back at zero. So, we'll find out around 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time.

BARTIROMO: Wow! All right, Kristina, we'll be watching you all day today, ahead of that. Kristina Partsinevelos in New York. Meanwhile, we're going to turn to U.S.-China trade. President Trump just tweeted moments ago he says this: "Despite the unnecessary and destructive actions taken by the Fed, the economy is looking very strong, and China and USMCA deals are moving along nicely. There is little or no inflation and USA optimism is very high." President Trump meeting with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He at the White House.

The president is likely to announce as summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping later today, according to the Wall Street Journal. We are expecting that to be either later April or early May. Joining me right now is the Author of "The Coming Collapse of China," Gordon Chang. And Gordon, it's always a pleasure to see you. First, let's talk about the trade deal, what are you expecting in terms of the main tenants of any deal? Do you think we'll get to a deal between the U.S. and China?

GORDON CHANG, AUTHOR: Well, everyone says there will be a deal that they've settled 90 percent of the points. I'm not so sure that we're going to hear a deal announced in next day or so, you know, but next couple of months. The question, though, is you know we've had a decades of failed trade agreements with China. The question is do you remedy that with another deal? So, we'll see how this goes, but, clearly, you know, this is heading in that direction.

BARTIROMO: Well, it looks like the Chinese are willing to open up its markets, they're opening up the markets to financial services companies in the U.S. among other industries, and they're willing to buy more commodities. What about the big-ticket items, the I.P. theft, the forced transfer of technology?

CHANG: You know, that's the real (INAUDIBLE) of the problem. You know, people say: well, look, we're close to a deal, but they have not yet decided on the enforcement mechanisms that can get China to agree to. And so, that is really going to be the critical thing. And if President Trump doesn't agree to tough enforcement mechanisms, then clearly, this is not going to be a good deal for us. But if there are tough enforcement mechanisms, Xi Jinping, the Chinese ruler has a lot of incentive to say "no," because they're building up this narrative of national humiliation in China. And whenever they start talking about that, that's not a good thing.

BARTIROMO: Then, there's Huawei. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT, announcing it is ending collaborations with, and ZTE over alleged violations of U.S. sanctions. MIT also said it's reviewing the school's collaborations with China, Russia, and Saudi Arabia. This is really getting dicey around Huawei. I've spoken with the Secretary of State Mike Pompeo about this. He's trying to tell the Europeans: Look, you know, if you're going to use Huawei telecom, we're going to not share as much information with you. This is high stakes on Huawei.

CHANG: Well, it certainly is. You know, and one of the arguments that the United States has been making is that, that the 2017 national intelligence law in China requires Chinese parties to spy on others if China demands it. And certainly, you know, we've seen Huawei spy on the African Union, they did that for 12 -- for five years. And so, clearly, there's a strong case there, but, you know, Huawei is really supported by the Chinese Diplomatic Corps. Beijing has gotten behind this company, and that really should tell us a lot because this is a geopolitical issue for China, not just an economic one.

BARTIROMO: So, you do think that the president will be able to put in some kind of an enforcement mechanism? Should the Chinese not keep up their promises, not to steal from United States if there is more stealing of I.P., they snap back more tariffs, or what? What is the enforcement mechanism to get Beijing to keep the promises?

CHANG: They're going to keep some tariffs on, and President Trump has been very clear about that for last month. So, that looks like going it's to be the case.

BARTIROMO: I agree with you.

CHANG: And the Chinese have been saying: look, that's unacceptable to them. Now, I don't know where the middle ground here is -- you know, but clearly, this is where we either have a trade deal or we don't have one. And I sort of think that, you know, it's up to the president to just sort of increase the tariffs until the Chinese stop stealing our I.P. Because, really, you know, we've had agreements with China and very detailed agreements with China, and they have just dishonored all them.

BARTIROMO: Right, like the time they said they were going to buy all those beefs, and then they never bought the beef. I got to get your take on swine flu outbreak in China. China is not talking about this at all. But I was talking to an American businessman last night and he was telling me that China consumes and produces 50 percent of the world's pork. And right now, 20 percent of the pigs are diseased with swine flu. So, they are dying -- 20 percent of the pigs in China means that is a 100 million dead pigs. What are they going to do with a 100 million dead pigs? How do you dispose of 100 million dead pigs?

CHANG: You know, in previous instances like this, they just dump them in the river.

BARTIROMO: Right, exactly! But they can't dump 100 million dead pigs in the river, right?

CHANG: Yes, there's going to be a lot of burning of pigs and the rest of it. The issue here for the United States is that China has agreed to buy more soybeans, but with fewer pigs, they're not going to need soybeans as much as, you know, had anticipated. So, this is going to be another one of those difficult issues between China and U.S. Do they actually buy commodities in the amounts agreed?

BARTIROMO: Earlier, I spoke with New Jersey Congressman Jeff Van Drew about this very issue. Watch what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JEFF VAN DREW (D), NEW JERSEY: Well, it's definitely going to push some prices higher. There's no question -- when you're going to have a shortage of meat, and you're going to certainly going have a shortage of pork, and the prices are going up -- number one. Secondly, you know, we just have to make sure and thank God, we have got a good Department of Ags to make sure that we keep everything safe over here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, the source that I was talking to last night said it's not just pork prices that are going up, it's going to ripple throughout meat. It will go chicken prices, and meat prices as well, what do you think?

CHANG: Yes. Well, certainly, because, you know, pork is such an important staple in China. If you don't have it, you're going to have to eat something else. And so, this is going to affect prices in Asia, and which means it's going to affect prices here. It's going to have a knock-on effect, as I mentioned on soybeans and other commodities. So, this is going to be felt worldwide. Because I'm actually surprised that it's only 50 percent of the world's pork. I think that it's actually higher --

BARTIROMO: It's more than 50 percent.

CHANG: I thought so --

BARTIROMO: Wow! How come nobody talking about the swine flu? You don't see this reported anywhere? I mean, I didn't.

CHANG: This -- there was a little bit of reporting about two weeks ago, because the U.S. Department of Agriculture confiscated Chinese pork coming into U.S., which was diseased. And so, that obviously was important to the A.G. markets here. But you're right, for the most part, this is a story which no one is really talking about, and it does have effect through both the markets and the trade talks.

BARTIROMO: I'm glad that we discussed it. Gordon, it's good to see you.

CHANG: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: That you so much. Gordon Chang joining us. Coming up, startling new developments in the case against Boeing. The very latest on the Ethiopian Airlines crash investigation, that's next. And then, Carlos Ghosn back behind bars -- I was about to start an exclusive interview with him last night, and as we were about to start the call, 10 agents walked in, took him away. More on the story coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The 737 Max jet, the crash in Ethiopia last month reportedly had a damaged sensor. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Learning some new things here, Maria. The angle of an attack sensor on the Boeing 737 Max was reportedly damaged during takeoff, by a foreign object or a bird. That is according to ABC News right now. Sources are saying that the sensor then sent false readings to the plane's anti-stall system, as the pilots tried desperately to keep it from pushing the plane nose down. Meanwhile, the preliminary report on the crash from the Ethiopian government that came out this morning, is taking aim at Boeing, finding that the Ethiopian jet apparently nose-dived before it went down and the flight crew performed, according to this report, all the procedures recommended by Boeing, but still could not control that plane.

Well, Target raising its minimum wage. The retailer announcing workers are going to now earn $13.00 an hour. This starts in June, that is up from $12.00. The move coming as retailers have been finding it tougher to attract workers. Target employs over 300,000 people right now.

Well, Google Assistant launching its first celebrity voice today, and here you go, it starts with singer, John legend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN LEGEND, SINGER: Whoa. I am feeling this new voice. You can find me on all kinds of devices: phones, Google Home, and if I'm lucky, in your heart.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Yes.

(LAUGHTER).

CASONE: You bet, you John! The musician is going to give you the weather, maybe sing you happy birthday, tell you a joke. This voice is only available for a limited time unfortunately. Google says, there are going to be some more celebrity cameos, thanks to approve voice synthesizing technology. I would love a little happy birthday from John Legend. Bring it on!

BARTIROMO: I like that, yes! Which celebrity voice do you guys want on your Google devices? James, what about you?

FREEMAN: I guess I'd go with Sinatra, If I had --

BARTIROMO: Good one, good one.

ELMORE: I would like Dolly Parton, right?

FREEMAN: Yes, I'll go with Dolly.

ELMORE: She's great.

BARTIROMO: OK.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes.

FREEMAN: Was I fortunate to meet her in the green room in this building a couple of years ago. And --

BARTIROMO: She's a doll, huh!

FREEMAN: She is just as wonderful, as you always hear about.

ELMORE: Good to wake up with a voice like that.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but when she comes in -- she comes in, I don't care what time of day it is, Dolly Parton is always extremely professional. And she looks you in the eye. I think of -- like a lot of people can learn from that. She's incredible.

BARTIROMO: She's real deal. And now, she's going to the racetrack.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly, you got to watch Dolly. I mean, she can dust anybody. That's been clear with her long career. But anyway, I'll do like, Gilbert Godfrey. Remember Geico -- that was not Geico.

BARTIROMO: The duck --

MCDOWELL: No, the duck -- the duck fired him.

BARTIROMO: That'd be a good one.

MCDOWELL: I would take Gilbert Godfrey. Not just because it'll make you pay attention.

BARTIROMO: Quick break, coming up, Carlos Ghosn back behind bars. I was about to start an exclusive interview with the former Nissan CEO when he was arrested again last night, the full story coming up. Fires First Responders And C.A. Shooting Victims; Curling Under The InfluenceLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies. Thank you so much. Happy Tuesday to you. And good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

And it is Tuesday, November 20th, your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Global markets in selloff mode once again this morning. Take a look at futures, pointing to another day of loses on Wall Street extending yesterday's loses, down 164 points right now on the Dow Futures, two-thirds of one percent.

S&P 500 down three quarters of percent, 19 points lower, and the NASDAQ currently down 77 points, better than one percent lower on the NASDAQ this morning.

After yesterday's dropping, take a look at the sharp declines yesterday, and this wasn't even the worse. The markets actually closed off of the lows of the day.

The Dow and the S&P 500 both falling roughly one and a half percent on the session.

The real weakness was in technology. The NASDAQ was better than three percent on the session. That was 322 points lower yesterday.

Check out the declines in the biggest technology stocks yesterday, really the leadership on the downside yesterday, Facebook was down almost six percent, Netflix down four percent -- I'm sorry, almost six percent as well.

Those were the worst performers on the day.

Apple, Amazon, as well as Alphabet, all very low, sharply lower yesterday.

Global markets following the U.S. lower this morning. The FT-100 is down two-thirds of a percent, 42 points lower right now on the Financial Times.

The CAC Quarante in Paris is down about one percent, 45 points lower, and the Dax Index in Germany down 104 points lower, that's about one percent lower right now.

Overnight in Asia, declines across the board. Taking a cue from Wall Street, China was down better than two percent on the Shanghai Composite and the Hong Kong Hang Seng.

Well, the future of Renault-Nissan Alliance hangs in the balance. Leaders from France to Japan are looking to take action following the shocking arrest of Carlos Ghosn.

Retail earnings in focus this morning, major names including Target, Lowe's, Kohl's, Best Buy, all set to report their earnings this morning.

We will have those results and tell you what they say about the health of the consumer and the economy right now.

Plus crypto carnage, Bitcoin prices plunging below $5,000. What's behind this decline coming up.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Forbes Media Chairman and Former Republican Presidential Candidate, Steve Forbes, and CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell.

Good morning.

STEVE FORBES, FORBES MEDIA CHAIRMAN AND FORMER REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Good morning. Good to be with you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And now -- thank God you two are here to make sense on these markets this morning.

BARTIROMO: Another major selloff yesterday as these concerns continue, Lindsey. What do you think's behind it?

BELL: Yes. I mean I think it's really this growth concern that has been plaguing the market in the last several weeks, and obviously trade, that plays into the growth concern.

With Apple, you know, leading the tech sector lower, the concern really is with iPhone demand, but the consumers seem strong and I think that you're going to hear that what the retailers are going to report today.

BARTIROMO: Yes. What do you think, Steve?

FORBES: I think it boils down to that one word, "trade," having a real trade war with China, tariffs perhaps coming in January, but the uncertainty's starting to hurt business investment.

You don't know what the rules are, you can start to hold back. And that uncertainty's starting to creep around the U.S. economy. So the sooner --

BARTIROMO: Which is why CapEx spending is really -- we're looking at that, to see whether or not business managers are saying, "You know what, I don't know where this trade deal is going, let me just stop putting money to work, which --

FORBES: That's right. And that's why the meeting in Argentina between Xi and Trump is going to be critical.

Are they going to set the right tone so people feel, "Okay, they'll work this out in the next few months," or is the temperature going to get lower, colder?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And the problem, too, with the business investment side, and exactly what you're talking about, corporations are backing off on their investing and probably they're hiring as we go into year.

Because we don't have the wind at our backs of tax reform or fiscal stimulus. So, that's wearing off. So, we really need to come on to a conclusion.

BARTIROMO: And here's another earnings in the retail sector.

Lowe's just hitting the tape, earnings beating expectations with $1.04 share versus an estimate of $0.98 a share.

Pretty much when you look at all these retail earnings, they've been better than expected.

Revenue at 17.42 billion, versus an estimate at 17.36 billion, over and over we're seeing this trend, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: But L Brands got hammered yesterday. I think it was down two percent on the day, but that's an antiquated business model.

I think that they need to rethink the kind of underwear that they're selling to women.

That was my opinion yesterday.

Nordstrom though was a disappointment last week, so it's been hit or miss depending on the retail earnings and of course later today we do get Target, which is a -- kind of a little bit broader indicator of what's going on.

But if Lowe's does -- if Lowe's is doing well, it'll be interesting to see how the stock reacts because home builders have really been hammered in recent months, even this year because of the higher interest rate.

You saw sentiment come in yesterday as a disappointment for the home builders.

BARTIROMO: We had on the CEO of the International Shopping Centers.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: He was on about two weeks ago.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: And he said it's going to be a knock-out fourth quarter.

And anybody I've spoken with continues to say it's going to be a knockout fourth quarter in terms of consumer earnings.

I know that it's been hit and miss on some of these numbers, but for the most part, the consumer has been pretty song.

So, I think -- I think you're right, I think it's the trade, uncertainty, and that is keeping business spending at bay.

FORBES: You wave the magic wand and all these trade disputes disappear, the Dow would go up 5,000 points.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BELL: I agree with you a hundred percent on that.

And if you look at some of the retailers actually in the last week --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BELL: -- I know, you know, the tech wreck has a -- has a huge saying and some of those stocks are in bear market territory from their highs.

But the retailers --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

BELL: -- Macy down 11 percent in the last week, that's worse than some of those FAANG Stocks.

BARTIROMO: Huh. Yes.

BELL: Right? Walmart's down seven percent. So --

BARTIROMO: Okay. Okay.

BELL: -- they're reporting good numbers, but --

BARTIROMO: And yet they're not -- people are not reacting.

BELL: But the investors are worried.

FORBES: Yes.

BELL: The fourth quarter last year was so good --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

BELL: -- that even though it supposed to be good this year, they're worried that they're not going to be --

MCDOWELL: And I'll add, people who work for retail industry organizations tend to be a little more optimistic than investors.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Because they're not the owners of the stocks.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So, people will sell first and ask questions later.

FORBES: And then listen --

BARTIROMO: Well, it is about growth. It is about growth.

FORBES: (INAUDIBLE) caution out there.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: You see that automobile sales aren't quite as robust as people would like.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FORBES: So, people are just wanting to know, what's the future?

We know with the markets, it's not today, it's what they think might happen in the future.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: That's an --

BARTIROMO: And I will say this, the President of the Dallas Federal Reserve Bank joining me this weekend on Wall Street this upcoming Friday and he continues to believe that we may see three plus percent this year in growth.

But it's going to go all the way down to 1.9 percent at the end of '19 going into 2020. So, that'll be on this weekend.

MCDOWELL: And even though earnings are expected to grow next year, this is something Lindsey has pointed out.

We were expecting going into the third-quarter earnings season of double- digit growth in 2019, and now it's single-digit growth, right?

It's -- where is it now? Eight and a half percent roughly?

BELL: 7.9. It's coming back.

MCDOWELL: So it keeps coming down.

BARTIROMO: Wow. All right. We got a lot to talk about this morning.

And then of course there's the latest news on Carlos Ghosn, which we're going to get to as well.

Coming up this morning, joining the conversation, Texas Congressman and House Veterans' Affair Committee member, Jodey Arrington is here.

Former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer will join us along with Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst, General Jack Keane is here.

Former Toys"R"Us and HBC CEO, he's also the former Target Vice Chairman and Storch Advisors CEO, Jerry Storch is with us. He's going to give us a good window into what's going on.

And then media and tech, Activate Founder and Partner Michael Wolf here to talk about the carnage that we've been seeing in that sector.

Don't miss a moment of it, we have a big three hours coming up.

And we kick it off right here with our top story and that is tech tumbling.

Facebook, Netflix, Amazon, Apple, Alphabet, all take a dive yesterday and have been taking a dive in the last month coming in the heels of what has been a terrible month for the technology industry.

Both Facebook and Apple down better than 10 percent over the last month.

Joining us right now is SkyBridge Capital Senior Portfolio Manager, Troy Gayeski.

And Troy, good to see you this morning. Thank you so much.

TROY GAYESKI, SENIOR PORTFOLIO MANAGER, SKYBRIDGE CAPITAL: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to this carnage we've been seeing.

GAYESKI: Well, look, I think in regards to what you discussed on trade, there's one other factor to remember, and that -- and the big picture here, for quite some time, capital markets outperform corporate fundamentals which, in turn, outperform the real economy.

And a lot of that had to do with the Fed's hyper loose monetary policy, not only here but with ECB.

And so what you've seen this year is as the fed has tightened and obviously they're winding down their bond portfolio, we've seen a significant multiple compression in equity markets, which is very healthy for the longer term.

But in the shorter term, we think volatility will continue to be elevated and you've seen a lot of deleveraging, particularly in the hedge fund industry the last six weeks.

Which have added to this very ugly tape, not only in tech but across the board.

BARTIROMO: Well --

FORBES: Do you -- do you -- do you think the fed's going to go ahead with multiple rate increases next year or are they going to take a pause?

GAYESKI: So, look, they're going to go --

FORBES: Or are they going to indicate a pause in the next couple of weeks?

GAYESKI: The -- they're -- let's start with the probability of outcome.

So, December, they're more than likely going to hike.

FORBES: Right.

GAYESKI: And then (INAUDIBLE) Powell started to walk back, the potential for more aggressive hikes, so we would say next year is more like one to two hikes this stage, given the softness we've seen not only in the U.S. but overseas.

That onto itself, though, might not be enough to get the bull market really supercharged again unless you get a resolution for trade.

The broader point here is that the years of massive outperformance from equities versus corporate fundamentals and real economy are over.

And if you look at next year, if you're talking high-single-digit earnings growth, that's probably the high-end of return expectations unless the dollar really tanks, which could cause a little bit of upside from there.

FORBES: So are we going to see real slide on corporate buybacks of stock? Which was a huge mainstay the last (INAUDIBLE)

GAYESKI: Yes. So, in terms of buybacks, the pace has to come down, right? From where this will be the peak year in terms of buybacks.

Even though a quite a large amount of capital's gone into CapEx as you discussed before. That's trending down.

So that will be removed, one of the -- reduced the buying power of one of the most steady buyers throughout this whole bull market.

BARTIROMO: The Journal is reporting that Apple suppliers are facing turmoil. Let's take a look at Apple for a second because it's really been taking a massive decline.

The results of the technology giant's decision to cut production orders for all three of the iPhone models unveiled in September. Is this a sign of bigger problems?

I got to give Dan Niles credit again.

GAYESKI: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Because Dan Niles joined us back in October and he was very, you know, cautious on Apple. Before the company reported, he was right, he talked about a supply issue and that is an issue.

But now you see the suppliers having their own issues.

GAYESKI: Yes. The whole supply chain is getting hammered. So, you know, if you look through it, right? You had investors that were extrapolating several quarters of extremely strong numbers.

It -- basically not into infinity, but at least over the next several quarters.

Now what you've seen is you've had a global slowdown. Remember, not only in the U.S., but China slowed significantly. Europe's way off their growth rates of last year.

A lot of the topline numbers have not been hit and, you know, that's flowed through the stocks.

And the other point we made, you know, last time around the show was how crowded they were, right?

And not only Apple, but Netflix, et cetera, so, you know, the downside potential in heavily-crowded stocks that miss their fundamentals is rather enormous compared to uncrowded options.

BARTIROMO: And then there's Facebook at a critical turning point.

The Journal is reporting this morning that CEO Mark Zuckerberg plans to take a more aggressive approach given the recent scandals hitting the company.

What do you think about that?

GAYESKI: Well, look, so -- from a hedge fund standpoint, most hedge funds (INAUDIBLE) that position back in Q2.

The view was that we had peak social media back in Q1 and Q2

BARTIROMO: So have you been short, these stocks?

GAYESKI: We're not short, we've been out.

So, we had a little bit of exposure earlier in the year we've been out.

You know, right now, it's not quite a high -- a track of risk-reward to get overly short. You want to be defensive, you want to be in cash-flow oriented positions.

And you want to bide your time to start the Point Capital once we get a floor on the markets.

Because right now, we're about to retest lows and there's a chance we go through there.

If we do, sit back, wait for things to stabilize, and into early next year, it'd probably be a better buying point.

BELL: Yes, but if you look at Apple getting to your cash-flow point --

GAYESKI: Uh-hmm.

BELL: -- and quality, people want quality, especially in the tech space.

Looking at Apple trading it just over 13 times now, they have a ton of cash on the balance sheet, they're buying back a ton of their share, to Steve's point.

GAYESKI: Yes.

BELL: They're going to buy back about a quarter of their shares over the next -- over here for the next three years. Wouldn't this be a time to get into Apple?

GAYESKI: So --

MCDOWELL: Not unless you face tariff risk. And see, Apple has been immune from the tariffs so far and kind of been immune from the trade fight that the U.S. is having with China.

However, if we move ahead and there isn't a resolution, Apple has nowhere else essentially at this point to make that iPhone --

GAYESKI: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- but China.

GAYESKI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And so maybe that's part of the -- part of the reason people are selling.

FORBES: But a real fundamental problem with Apple is there's not the wow factor anymore. They got these nice little improvements on the 11, 12, and the 21, whatever else they're bringing out.

But what's the big leap forward, so to speak?

GAYESKI: We got some -- it's unclear what the next transformational technology will be.

To your point, every change they made is incremental, that's the point. You've brought up, remember, there's short, medium, and long-term, so as a long-term investor, this is a good entry point.

However --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

GAYESKI: -- you have to look at the short-term, and the technical still look pretty ugly, it's still heavily owned, and Apple, even though they've played their cards better than most of the FAANG Stocks in terms of the political environment in Washington --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

GAYESKI: -- you know, if the trade war takes a turn for the worse, there could be supply chain disruption as you've been highlighting.

MCDOWELL: Yes. One thing I'll point out about the whole Mark Zuckerberg fight. Again, the guy was busy learning Mandarin and reading a book every two weeks.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And essentially, it seems like now that he's angry about the response to all of the pressure from the outside of the company and the missteps within it, it seems it begs the question of where have you been the last couple of years? Number one.

And number two, you have the founders of Instagram who are really the reason for the success of that part of Facebook's business, they're gone.

And, again, will Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg fouled out up to is another question.

GAYESKI: Well, look, I think -- to be fair, you know --

FORBES: What's your point of view?

GAYESKI: Yes, no, no.

MCDOWELL: Well, it's a -- again --

GAYESKI: It's a great point.

MCDOWELL: I said this yesterday, a friend of mine said over the weekend when I was -- did you read -- I asked, "Did you read the New York Times article about Facebook?"

And he said, yes, have a drink and join the party. This is what everybody's known about the company, the way it's run --

GAYESKI: For a long time, yes.

MCDOWELL: -- and the way it operates for literally --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- oh, I don't know, over a decade.

GAYESKI: Yes, forever. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, they've been allowing this stuff to go by and not do anything.

GAYESKI: That's right.

BARTIROMO: I mean even when it comes to regulation, which is a point you've pointed out over and over again that they should have been policing themselves.

GAYESKI: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: But we were laughing about Sheryl Sandberg writing that book.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right.

MCDOWELL: Again, telling women how to live their -- live their lives --

BARTIROMO: Right (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: And it's like how about doing your job?

BARTIROMO: Yes (INAUDIBLE)

GAYESKI: Yes. No, one thing to say is to be fair, creating a successful tech company is very different than managing the political environment --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HIGGINS: -- and regulatory environment in Washington. Right? So that's a -- that's a tricky (INAUDIBLE) to negotiate as Steve can highlight, I'm sure.

BARTIROMO: Real quick before you. Lowe's, Kohl's, Best Buy, Target, all reporting earnings. What's your sense of the consumer?

GAYESKI: Oh, so the consumer is in fantastic shape. I mean even if you look at withholding data, which one -- is one of the most real-time indicators you have, there's a chance we hit the similar withholding this year as we did last year, which is remarkable.

Because even though the economy is doing better, remember, as the cycle matures, it's harder and harder to create more and more jobs with low unemployment.

So, we think consumers are in tremendous shape.

BARTIROMO: That's what I think, too.

GAYESKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I mean it -- but we'll see.

GAYESKI: Recession risk a low, but that doesn't mean markets are destined to go up.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, Troy.

GAYESKI: Great to see you, too.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Troy Gayeski there.

Coming up, a leadership crisis at Renault after Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn is arrested on a slew of alleged financial violations next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Fallout after the arrest of Nissan Chairman, Carlos Ghosn, Lauren Simonetti with all the details now. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: After that shock arrest yesterday for Carlos Ghosn, the French Finance Minister and the Wall Street Journal is reporting this.

"We'll ask Renault, the board there, to install interim leadership at the company as they continue to investigate what is going on." The Finance Minister did say that Carlos Ghosn has some nice qualities.

But obviously this is a -- this is a problem for Renault, for Nissan, and for Mitsubishi, that is a trio, a car conglomerate, that Carlos Ghosn forged.

And when he forged, it was all about scale. Now those companies produce one in nine cars worldwide. They make that many cars, really competing with the big player, which is Volkswagen.

So when he first created that that was about scale, but now -- because the question is, well, in the absence of leadership, what happens to that pact?

Well, now that pact has to compete with Silicon Valley, so the times have changed.

Of course, as you know, the shock arrest yesterday for Carlos Ghosn. He was arrested and jailed, accused of underreporting his pay for using company assets for private use.

We saw the stocks tank yesterday, Nissan stock was down six percent, Renault stock was down sharply.

Many of these stocks trading to the downside in Asia today as well.

So now they're looking for new leadership. In the meantime, at Renault -- and I do know that the Nissan Board will meet on Thursday. So --

FORBES: How much was this conglomeration just dependent on one person and how much of it was truly structural? Can it --

SIMONETTI: That's the question.

BARTIROMO: I think this is such an important question because --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- he was the Chairman of Nissan --

SIMONETTI: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- he was running Renault --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- and he was also overseeing Mitsubishi.

SIMONETTI: Yes, those three companies.

BARTIROMO: When you have that much power, that's what people worry about.

MCDOWELL: He was the Chairman, so it's Renault, Nissan, Mitsubishi Alliance. He was Chairman of the alliance and Chairman of each individual --

BELL: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- automaker on top of it. And then as Maria just said, the CEO of Renault.

And it looks like -- people on the outside, Steve, questioned, whether this was a tenable situation that it was solely dependent on him.

And right now it looks like how are they going to keep -- prevent it unraveling.

SIMONETTI: And that's where competing with tech, competing with Silicon Valley comes in, because, yes, he did architect, he was the architect of that alliance, but the times have changed.

And maybe somebody else can come in, or maybe the focus is different now for these companies because they're not just competing with Volkswagen, they're competing with, you know, Tesla and that sort of idea of electric and artificial intelligence.

FORBES: But how well would those companies survive if they weren't allied together?

SIMONETTI: Good question.

FORBES: It's a very, very competitive world.

SIMONETTI: We'd ask why the stocks are down.

BARTIROMO: I mean how ironic that Carlos Ghosn as one of the first people to bring an electric car to the table, okay?

And they didn't gain traction when he first came out with the electric car.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Relief for Nissan.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. And then all of these -- they never took -- it really did not gain traction, but he was really one of the first to come out and say, "This is where the market is going." It's a shame. It's a shame.

MCDOWELL: And Nissan was almost bankrupt when he moved in and bought a stake.

FORBES: But he saved it.

MCDOWELL: Right, he saved Nissan. So he is --

FORBES: (INAUDIBLE) bring Frenchman into a Japanese company.

BARTIROMO: But it -- he --

SIMONETTI: He was known for cost-cutting. That was his trademark.

FORBES: Extraordinary (INAUDIBLE)

SIMONETTI: That was his trademark, a brilliant mind, but really scared a lot of these companies with his aggressive cost cutting, too. That's how he got them, one of the ways he got them back on track.

BARTIROMO: It's extraordinary that he was arrested in Japan when Japan looked at -- lauded him I mean like a comic book figure was created around him.

BELL: Uh-hmm.

FORBES: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I mean he was big in pop culture, but it's really, what a comedown.

MCDOWELL: Astonishing.

BARTIROMO: What a comedown. Lauren, thank you. We'll keep watching that.

Coming up, caravan crisis, the federal court says no to enforcing President Trump's asylum ban as the fight over border wall funding continues in congress, that's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Futures this morning are indicating another decline at the start of trading this morning.

Take a look at markets, down 162 points on the Dow. Down 20 points on the S&P and the NASDAQ down 83 points right now.

Looks like another tough open this morning. Meanwhile a police officer attacked by a knife-wielding man in Belgium.

Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Maria. Good morning.

The suspect described only as male was shot by responders there. It happened outside the city's main police station around 5:30 a.m. local time.

The officer is in the hospital with none life-threatening injuries. Police say they don't have a official motive, they're not as of now calling it terrorism.

But a Belgian newspaper did report the man shouted, "Allahu Akbar."

Belgium has been under tight security since the 2016 terror attacks that killed 32 people.

Well, back here at home, three people are dead after a gunman opened fire at a Chicago hospital. The suspect, Juan Lopez, shooting and killing his ex-girlfriend in the parking lot before running inside and shooting two others.

Responding officer, Samuel Jimenez, was one of the victims killed. He was with the Chicago Police Department for just 18 months.

He leaves behind a wife and three children. Police say the gunman was also killed but it was unclear who pulled that trigger.

And then the value of Bitcoin continues to plummet. It's now hovering below $4,500 this morning. It hasn't been this low since October of 2017.

The selloff comes up in speculation that increased regulations are going to prompt (INAUDIBLE) to liquidate their holdings.

Bitcoin a notoriously volatile cryptocurrency at its peak, remember, that was last December.

Bitcoin hit nearly 20,000, which means the price has fallen, Maria.

About 75 percent, a lot of folks are not looking for risk right now and Bitcoin's kind of a good

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a great point. All right. Thank you so much, Cheryl.

Coming up, budget showdown, the Trump Administration fighting military programs that they're really to sacrifice in the face of the looming budget battle.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

WOLF: And lot of it's going in to the processing using A.I., so you know what's going on but you also can do a bunch of things that are predicting the camera in your kitchen that helps you cook. It's going to be --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's incredible. So the cameras talking to each other and that's forming an intelligent network.

WOLF: And intelligent network, so it's not just the cameras in your homes, the cameras in the car, so they go together, to all the cars can talk to each other, they can talk to the cameras on light poles, they can talk to the camera on your phone. We're going to see a lot more intelligence in the network and it's going to enable things like self-driving cars.

BARTIROMO: What about E-commerce? Let's talk there because E-commerce growth dollars will surpass physical growth dollars from three trillion to six trillion you write by 2022.

WOLF: It -- this year is the inflection point. And so we've got e- commerce got dollars that are growing about 20 percent. We've got physical retail which continues to grow but only around two percent. So we're going to see consumers are going to be buying a lot more and the we've got -- if you look at the biggest companies, it's -- the biggest is Alibaba, it's followed by Amazon, then you go JD.com, and then you've got eBay.

And all of them are going -- are going to continue to see growth. What's fascinating is they're all marketplaces. They're really not --

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's interesting.

WOLF: They're not actually holding inventory, they're just selling other people's stuff.

BARTIROMO: That's fascinating actually. All right. Online betting is another item that's highlighted in the -- in the report. Online sports betting projected the industry to explode from six billion to 119 billion?

WOLF: 119 billion, a lot of it is money that was illegally bet, and now it's going to be coming online. This is all the big tech companies are going to benefit as well. So sports leagues and E-sports, and by the way, even the enterprise companies like Oracle. So it's going to end up being within three years about $35 billion in incremental revenue for tech and media. None of which is there -- so it -- today, so it really reflects my optimism for the stocks and the growth in these companies.

BARTIROMO: So where is the growth? When you look at this whole space of technology and media, what do you think are the most important growth takeaways that we should understand about where this industry is going?

WOLF: So, I think that we're still going to see a lot of advertising going from traditional media into these -- into these companies. We're -- it certainly going to be E-commerce, it's going to be new devices like the smart camera, still more home speakers and then finally we're going to see a lot of video out there. People -- we -- it's not just Netflix, it's Amazon, it's Hulu, so many of these companies.

BARTIROMO: Even Apple.

WOLF: Apple.

BARTIROMO: They're starting a streaming service.

WOLF: They're starting a streaming service. I'm not -- I'm not convinced that Apple is truly going to be a competitor to these others but YouTube with Google is already -- they're already starting YouTube premium and so it -- in each case it's new revenue streams coming in. I mean, betting is going to be enormous and we don't see this today in anybody's P&L.

BARTIROMO: Do you see new policies, regulations putting a hamper on any of this? I mean, the growth stories are still in place, and yet these stocks are falling out of bed because I think some people are worried about regulation because these companies keep getting more powerful and more powerful.

WOLF: It's not clear that regulation can do much, I mean, we -- I recall myself a technology determinist, which is anything people can do with technology, they're going to do, so there can be regulations but these industries are different, they're not like telecom where you're regulating a pipe. So, there's going to be some things I think that Facebook and others are going to identify where advertisements come from because there is this concern about people hacking elections, and it's not just foreign or -- foreign companies or government, it's also within the country.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WOLF: But I'm not convinced there's going to be a lot of regulation, the main thing is going to be the antitrust concerns, and the Time Warner merger ultimately has gone through. And a lot of that isn't just about concerns about monopolies and control, a lot of it is just political.

BARTIROMO: You doubt -- I mean, I would expect that this is not going to impact the innovation story because the innovation story is very much in place. I mean, the things that you've just brought up in terms of your report show real innovation, whether it's smart cameras, the online betting, or e-commerce.

WOLF: Artificial intelligence is going to be a massive enabler across most of these industries. I think we're going to see a great deal more functionality, even the phones. We're at a point where the phone has gotten very sophisticated would you could do with the phone is going to continue to grow and continue to play a bigger part on people's lives. And there's a lot of money that's going to flow from other places that hasn't been there.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Michael, it's great to see you so.

WOLF: Great to be here. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Congratulations on another fantastic report. Michael Wolf, a founder of Activate. We'll see you soon, Michael.

Coming up, technology titans tumbling. We're watching Silicon Valley giants this morning after yesterday's big selloff, and more selling this morning. And then, gift-giving guilt next. Thank you so much.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, November 20th, your top stories right now 8:35 a.m. on the East Coast. Futures headed lower this morning. Again, we're at the lows of the morning with a decline of almost 300 points right now on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, down one percent. We're expecting the S&P to be down one percent as well. And the NASDAQ to be down almost two percent, out of the open, this morning. NASDAQ is down 115 points right now.

Technologies stocks bringing the markets down, that's what happened yesterday. Google parent, Alphabet joining Facebook, Amazon, and Netflix in bear market territory. Apple, also, very close to bear market territory this morning. The technology giants hit in the premarket. Goldman Sachs cutting its price target on Apple from 209 to 182. I'm not sure how to get to 122 at Goldman, but stock is down 2-2/3 percent on that news this morning.

European indices down across the board as well. Take a look, we're looking at selling, it's getting worse, down 33 points on the FT-100, half a percent. CAC Quarante in Paris down better than one percent. And the DAX Index in Germany down 1-1/4 percent right now, 135 points lower there. We are looking at Asian markets, also down across the board, closing lower overnight, as you can see, down two percent apiece on Shanghai and Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

Retailers are reporting today, and the reaction from investors is not good. Best Buy out with its better-than-expected numbers that beat both on earnings and revenue compared to estimates. TJX Companies also hitting the tape moments ago, the company behind TJ Maxx, Marshalls, and HomeGoods also missed on earnings expectations. TJX is down three percent, and Ross Stores is down almost eight percent. We are also looking at the rest of the sector, down across the board.

Meanwhile, we just got a look at the housing market, the October housing starts coming in slightly higher than expected, the building permit number is slightly lower than expected. We've got housing starts looking -- we were expecting a weak showing here, Steve Forbes, but it looks to me like it's a miss in terms of housing starts. What's your take?

FORBES: It is -- it is a mix, and once interest rates -- once people can get used to four, five percent mortgages and this economy continues to grow, so we get China out of the way, which I think we will, that market will recover. We forget we grew up with four or five percent mortgages. And once that shock is over, I think housing will come back as the economy comes back.

BELL: I think, though, that the problem is that you have first-time buyers going out there, and we've seen interest rates -- Dagen always point this out -- in the mid-2016, the 10-year was at 1.16, something like that. Now, we're twice that. So, that moved up so quickly makes a difference. And if you're a first-time buyer, you're looking at that change in interest rates, and it makes a difference on your mortgage payments. So, this isn't the weakness in the housing market. It isn't -- this is kind of a reminder, it's nothing new. The existing home sales we get tomorrow have been down year-over-year for seven months in a row now. And that the decline is increasing.

MCDOWELL: In order for like these houses to make sense at higher mortgage rates, you look at a house like in Connecticut, it's for sale for a million and a half dollars. If you go back to mortgage rates that were eight percent which is kind of the longer -- about in the ballpark of the longer- term average over the last several decades, eight percent mortgage takes that home price -- what did it sell for in the early 90s -- less than $400,000. It was like a $300,000 house is now selling for a million and a half dollars, so I think that you have to -- that's the grave worry here is that housing prices, in order to move the inventory that's piling up in a lot of places, they've got to come down.

BARTIROMO: Are you saying put it in perspective, you're coming off at such a rich time for prices.

FORBES: But you're also going to see I think a real sharper divergence between red states, blue states, i.e., high-tax states versus low-tax states in this region, tri-state region. Forget it. You're just going to be worse and worse. You go to place like Texas, Florida --

BARTIROMO: Because you've lost your deduction in the high-tax states.

FORBES: You've lost your deduction, and -- but Texas, Florida, I think those places are going to still boom.

BELL: It's just like the equity market, as interest rates go up, when you have some of these assets that prices have gone up so significantly, so quickly, they have to come back down, you know, when you have interest rates rising.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, what about this market in terms of retail, Lowe's out earlier this morning beating expectations but Futures on the decline. Look at the stock here, Lindsey, down 7-1/3 percent on lows, and you've got all of the majors, even when it was a double beat or earnings better, even a revenue was light, it was same-store sales that really triggered the move, but they're all down across the board.

BELL: Yes. And same-store sales is a key. When you look at Lowe's, their same-store sales is up I think 1.5 percent. Look at Home Depot in the U.S., 5.4 percent same-store sales. Meanwhile, Home Depot is also down. I think it was down three percent in the last week. Lowe's was down nine percent going into this earnings report, I think.

BARTIROMO: Well, the NASDAQ is down, what, almost 14 percent from the highs, on the NASDAQ. So, we're seeing, I mean, a serious correction happening as we speak.

MCDOWELL: So Amazon was in bear market, and it entered a bear market in October. Alphabet, Google's parent company also in a bear market now. And if you're talking about -- but this is -- this is moved way outside of technology. You were talking about how hard these retail stocks have been hit going into this earnings report, Target since November, like early November 11-9 is down -- was already down 10-1/2 percent, and then it's down another almost 10 percent in premarket trading. And this is for -- Kohl's was down 14 percent before today, Lowe's down, 12 percent decline for TJX, Ross Stores down more than 11 percent. This is before the rout that you're seeing this morning, which is astonishing.

BELL: But this morning, Kohl's -- like Target was still off like 20 percent going into this morning. Kohl's was still up 30 percent year-to- date, going into this morning, so look at that versus the market. And some of these other sectors, and they were looking pretty good and maybe still highfliers, so they're being brought down, too. Even -- so, even the good quality names. And look, Target five percent comp that it's slightly missed. It was a -- that's an amazing number like Gerri said earlier.

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: Well, the market tries to anticipate the future, and the future, next year for the consumers is not going to be so good as this tariff thing kicks in.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's the issue. And if you're worried about growth going forward and you want to get out of some of these stocks and you want to just allocation shift, you're going to sell what you can sell. So, you've got, what, Apple still up whatever you said, 30 percent.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, where's money been going or what have people been buying, they've been buying treasuries which does seem to suggest people are worried about what the economy and growth looks like moving into next year. So, they were -- the yield was down I think through yesterday, six days in a row, and that's the longest winning streak for the 10-year treasury, I believe in more than two years. Let me go back 2016.

BARTIROMO: You're worried about growth, you're going to sell what you can sell and if you've got gains of 40 percent as some of these retail names or tech names, well, take some profits. Even in the face of good consumer and a good economy now, there's a new Gallup Poll showing the approval of President Trump handling of the economy is up, 53 percent of Americans approve how the President is handling the economy. Those are his best numbers yet, up from a previous high of 51 percent. So, how many people have come on this show, Dagen, and said that things are going really well? You had the head of shop -- international shopping says, it's going to be a blowout fourth-quarter. You had Jerry Stork (ph) saying it's going to be a terrific Black Friday. And yet, people are selling their holdings.

MCDOWELL: And I -- but some of what's going on, some of the nervousness, some of the uncertainty among businesses is this self-inflicted wound by this administration. And Steve has talked about that all-year long, and it is a -- trade is the problem.

FORBES: We're talking during the break about Larry Kudlow that's going on Stuart Varney.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: He says nice things about maybe something is going to happen with China, you'll see this reverse. If something does happen in that meeting in a few days between Xi and Trump --

BARTIROMO: The G20.

FORBES: (INAUDIBLE) framework that they might negotiate, sentiment can turn pretty quickly.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true.

BELL: The market needs to see more though than just talk, they need action, they need a game plan on trade. I think that the market is not going to believe like some positive rhetoric out of the G20.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a break. When we come back, Stuart Varney is going to weigh in on the technology titans' tumbling this morning. Plus, gift-giving guilt. Check this out, the shocking study on the pressure to overspend during the holidays. That's up next. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We want to give you this market alert because Futures are near the lows of the morning, again, just shy of them, Dow Industrials down 350 points, 1-1/3 percent. The NASDAQ is down 145 points right now, that's better than two percent lower. Yesterday, of course, the NASDAQ was down three percent, the Dow was down two percent.

Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in. And Stu, you say all of the news is bad news for the market.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, it's a perfect storm of bad news, isn't it? I mean, let me list some of the items here. Number one, the Democrats have won the house, so you're not going to get any new stimulus for the economy for next year. Number two, you got a global slowdown, that is going to hurt us. Three, no good news at this point from the trade talks with China, that is a negative. Four, Goldman Sachs says that by the end of next year, we'll be growing at a less than two percent growth rate. That's not good. Number five, most important, you've got a tech sell-off and then some. They did lead the market, now they don't, now they're leading it down. If you add them all up, we could be facing one of those blowout situations, and if we are, maybe that sets up a buying opportunity. But everything points south at this moment.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it seems like, at some point, it's going to be a big buying opportunity, Stu. I think you're right about that. I mean, we're seeing expectations of a slowdown in the economy, but how much slower -- I mean, how significant will that slowdown be? I mean, this has been the issue for about a year now that people are saying things will slow down considerably going into 2020.

VARNEY: Well, the people that we're talking to and you're talking to, are looking more towards a 2-1/2 percent growth rate for next year. That's nowhere near recession, and it's not that bad. It's a slowdown but it's not that bad. So, I think we may be setting up a really good buying opportunity but we're not quite there yet.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

VARNEY: You've got to see that just -- I forget the exact word for it, but you got a blowout of sort -- capitulation.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: We haven't got that yet, but when we do, then maybe you see the (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: No, it's not capitulation when a market closes off of the lows, we were down better than 500 yesterday and we closed down 395. So, I know you're going to have a lot more on it in about 10 minutes, Stu, we'll see you then.

VARNEY: Oh, yes, Larry Kudlow, by the way.

BARTIROMO: Larry Kudlow is coming up. That's going to be such an important interview. Join "VARNEY & COMPANY" as Larry Kudlow join Stuart to talk about where we are in this economic story.

First though, a news alert as we go to break, Boeing reportedly canceling a conference call on the 737 Max jet to discuss the systems on the model. This is the same model involved in a Lion Aircraft that crashed. Here's what Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg told me in exclusive interview earlier this month.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DENNIS MUILENBURG, CEO, BOEING: This is an ongoing investigation, so it will take whatever time is necessary to make sure it's done thoroughly, again, we participate fully in these investigations, we provided technical assistance, we'll continue to do that until the work is complete. The bottom line here is the 737 Max is safe.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Boeing shares up -- down 3.8 percent right now. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Holiday shopping headache, a new bank rate survey claims nearly half of Americans feel pressure to overspend during the holiday season. Parents feel the pinch even more with over half of respondents with kids overspending. Joining us now is Ramsey Solutions' financial expert, author of the upcoming book, "Everyday Millionaires," Chris Hogan is here. Chris, good to see you.

CHRIS HOGAN, FINANCIAL EXPERT, RAMSEY SOLUTIONS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you avoid overspending?

HOGAN: Well, Maria, you have to start off with a plan. Make a list of the people that you're going to shop for, assign a dollar amount on what you can afford to spend for that individual, and only spend that amount. I don't want people to wake up in January and have a holiday hangover for the next 18 months, trying to pay off credit card debt when they bought things they couldn't afford.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That makes sense. Lindsey?

BELL: Yes. Well, what about the ability to just take some people off your list and just not get gifts?

HOGAN: I don't think there's a problem with that at all, Lindsey, I really don't. If you can't afford to buy a gift, then be creative, think of ways you can make a gift. If they have kids, gift them with babysitting, take them out for a dinner, or make someone a dinner. We've got this mind-set in America that we have to buy a gift in order to give a gift. We can give the gift of time or we can use our talents to be creative.

MCDOWELL: Because when you give people something like I'll babysit your kids, the recipient of that gift knows that that babysitter is never going to show up, and then they're going to have a problem. Again, it's the fact that like at least a gift that you bought in a store is something tangible that like, oh, I can use this bath bomb, not something that, you know, well, I'm going to -- you know, I'll drive you to the mall when you need me to. It just never materializes.

HOGAN: Dagen, you sound like you've stood some people up with babysitting before.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: I don't -- I don't babysit.

HOGAN: But I think -- I think if you --

BELL: You're cracking me up. You're cracking me up.

HOGAN: Yes, I think if you give them a certificate or something. I just don't want people to dig themselves further into a hole. Spending in our debt (INAUDIBLE) situation is pushing toward a trillion dollars. This holiday season is a season where people dig themselves into a hole, that some of them still haven't crawled out from for the last three to four years. So, the definition of insanity is to keep doing the same thing over and over and expecting a different result.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HOGAN: Let's approach this Christmas with cash, make this a cash Christmas, and don't have financial regret.

FORBES: Well, one way to do it, I won't mention a family member who does it, and that is -- he has a great gift for recycling. So, recycle some of the presents --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Oh, recycled gift. You mean, regift?

FORBES: Regift.

MCDOWELL: Steve Forbes, I know who it is. Should I say who it is on television? It's --

FORBES: No.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: The Forbes name has nothing to do -- it doesn't represent like somebody who has an endless supply of money, they'll regift something that they got in previous holiday.

BARTIROMO: Well, what's wrong with regifting if it wasn't used?

MCDOWELL: Well, you were the --

FORBES: It's the thought that counts.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: It's like I gave Steve a gift and he gives it back to me the following Christmas, it's a little bit --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes, that's a problem. Chris, thank you, sir. Happy Thanksgiving, Chris Hogan. We'll be right back.

HOGAN: Happy Thanksgiving.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Thanks, everybody, great show.

MCDOWELL: Great show.

FORBES: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day, everybody. Let's get to "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stuart, take it away.

END

Dec 19, 2019( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Ghostery[1], a popular privacy- and security-focused browser extension[2] and mobile browser app, has officially launched for desktop users. The New York-based company announced[3] a pilot program for Ghostery Midnight[4] in late October, and the subscription-based desktop app is now ready for prime time. Ghostery Midnight comes with a slew of features to protect users at the device level across all applications — including an ad blocker, tracker protection and monitoring, and — for the very first time in a Ghostery product — a virtual private network (VPN). While this launch is an indication of Ghostery's efforts to build a sustainable business model, it also signals changes in the browser landscape that have necessitated a shift to device-level protection. Google, in particular, has proposed major changes ('Manifest V3[5]') that would impact how third-party extensions work inside Chrome and Chromium-based browsers, sparking complaints that it will become much more difficult for ad blockers and privacy-protection tools to dynamically respond to threats at the browser level.

According to Ghostery, it was already internally discussing a device-level privacy product before Google's new Chrome proposals came to light, but the news may have expedited Ghostery Midnight's launch. 'Tracker protection in Ghostery Midnight works very similarly to our extension by detecting and blocking trackers from third-party companies, but this time at the device level,' Ghostery president Jeremy Tillman told VentureBeat. 'Midnight monitors network activity on an app-by-app basis, needing only access to standard permissions in the operating system used by similar applications.'The story so farNew York-based Ghostery came to fruition back in 2008[6] as a FireFox add-on that analyzes web pages for trackers[7]. In 2010, Ghostery was acquired[8] by behavioral advertising regulatory platform Better Advertising, which introduced the Ghostery extension to all the major browsers,[9] followed later by a dedicated mobile browser app. Although Ghostery has garnered some high-profile fans over the years, including U.S. whistleblower Edward Snowden[10], it has also courted skepticism[11] for inviting users to opt into sharing ad-related data that it then sold to other companies. This business model was seen as problematic, given that Ghostery is built around privacy. So in 2017 Ghostery sold its trademark and main consumer technology to Cliqz[12], a Mozilla-backed[13] privacy-focused browser company based in Germany that later made Ghostery open source and announced a new business model[14]. For the past year or so, Ghostery has operated two new moneymaking schemes in beta. Ghostery Rewards[15] is an opt-in feature that notifies users about deals or special offers relevant to a site they're on — it's basically affiliate marketing, with Ghostery taking a cut of any sales it generates. Then there's Ghostery Insights[16], priced at $49 per month, which provides real-time web tracker analysis data for businesses. Back in January[17] Ghostery introduced its first consumer subscription plan in the form of Ghostery Plus, ushering in advanced features such as in-depth insights around trackers, priority support, and new themes for $2 per month. Ghostery Midnight builds on this with the introduction of a new premium subscription plan that costs $14 per month. It's worth noting that the service comes with a basic tier that protects up to two browsers for free. 'For years, we at Ghostery have been focused on protecting users and their data on the browser,' Tillman said. 'However, with impending changes in the browser landscape and privacy threats expanding at a device level, we're excited to debut Ghostery Midnight, featuring app-level tracker-blocking capabilities and our first ever VPN so users can feel protected at every level.' Here's a quick look at the main features Ghostery Midnight offers.Ghostery MidnightThrough the main Ghostery Midnight control panel, users can activate and deactivate the various features that work to protect the entire desktop. This includes a VPN, a tracker blocker, and an ad blocker, with additional 'quick stats' showing how many tracker requests have been blocked. Above: Ghostery Midnight control panel (Mac) Users can click on each desktop application to see what trackers are at play and which have been blocked. Above: Ghostery working with Chrome at the device level (Windows) Above: Ghostery detecting trackers inside Thunderbird The VPN offers six separate IP regions — two in the U.S. and individual ones for the U.K., Canada, Germany, and Singapore. Above: Ghostery VPN (Windows) If the user needs to temporarily deactivate their various blocking tools, they can choose to do so for 30 minutes, one hour, or 24 hours without having to manually turn off the features individually. Above: Pausing GhosteryThe privacy pushWhile cookies have served as an effective way of tracking users since the dawn of the modern web, they are easy to spot and block, which is why advertisers and other nefarious entities have sought new ways to identify and track users across websites. One such mechanism is 'fingerprinting,'[18] which works independently of cookies and allows advertisers (or anyone) to build a picture of an individual's browsing habits by monitoring signals such as the time zone of a machine, the screen resolution, HTTP headers, and more. Unlike cookies, fingerprinting is more difficult to spot, and anti-tracking tools typically feed from a database of known trackers. Ghostery maintains a proprietary tracker database that is updated regularly to detect and block trackers, and the company will leverage this same database for Ghostery Midnight. However, the Ghostery browser extension also uses more advanced anti-tracking technology[19] that leans on machine learning to spot new or otherwise unknown trackers that have yet to be added to any database. This isn't yet available inside Ghostery Midnight, but it will be thrown into the mix sometime next year. 'As everyday digital users, we're incredibly vulnerable,' Tillman added. 'Today's websites have dozens, if not hundreds of tracking technologies built into them. And, increasingly, modern desktop applications are using the same technologies to extend the reach of third-party tracking beyond your browser to include everything else you do on your device. This allows big tech companies like Google and Facebook, not to mention hundreds of smaller ones, to cast a bigger net to collect and monetize our data.' Ghostery Midnight is available to download now and comes with a free seven-day trial. urn:contentItem:5T9H-88V1-DYWH-9008-00000-00Ghost in the Machine2018-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisPROFILESPg. 32Ghost in the MachineEVAN OSNOS

Can Mark Zuckerberg fix Facebook before it breaks democracy?

At ten o'clock on a weekday morning in August, Mark Zuckerberg, the chairman and C.E.O. of Facebook, opened the front door of his house in Palo Alto, California, wearing the tight smile of obligation. He does not enjoy interviews, especially after two years of ceaseless controversy. Having got his start as a programmer with a nocturnal bent, he is also not a morning person. Walking toward the kitchen, which has a long farmhouse table and cabinets painted forest green, he said, "I haven't eaten breakfast yet. Have you?"

Since 2011, Zuckerberg has lived in a century-old white clapboard Craftsman in the Crescent Park neighborhood, an enclave of giant oaks and historic homes not far from Stanford University. The house, which cost seven million dollars, affords him a sense of sanctuary. It's set back from the road, shielded by hedges, a wall, and mature trees. Guests enter through an arched wooden gate and follow a long gravel path to a front lawn with a saltwater pool in the center. The year after Zuckerberg bought the house, he and his longtime girlfriend, Priscilla Chan, held their wedding in the back yard, which encompasses gardens, a pond, and a shaded pavilion. Since then, they have had two children, and acquired a seven-hundred-acre estate in Hawaii, a ski retreat in Montana, and a four-story town house on Liberty Hill, in San Francisco. But the family's full-time residence is here, a ten-minute drive from Facebook's headquarters.

Occasionally, Zuckerberg records a Facebook video from the back yard or the dinner table, as is expected of a man who built his fortune exhorting employees to keep "pushing the world in the direction of making it a more open and transparent place." But his appetite for personal openness is limited. Although Zuckerberg is the most famous entrepreneur of his generation, he remains elusive to everyone but a small circle of family and friends, and his efforts to protect his privacy inevitably attract attention. The local press has chronicled his feud with a developer who announced plans to build a mansion that would look into Zuckerberg's master bedroom. After a legal fight, the developer gave up, and Zuckerberg spent forty-four million dollars to buy the houses surrounding his. Over the years, he has come to believe that he will always be the subject of criticism.
