"I know a couple of guys who are color-blind," a prominent executive told me, "and their wives lay their clothes out for them in the morning if they don't want to go out every day looking like Bozo the Clown. Sheryl and the board are expected to lay the clothes out for Mark." He went on, "If you have blind spots, then you rely on the people around you to tell you where they are."

In one of our conversations, I asked Zuckerberg whether he finds it insulting when people speculate that he lacks emotions. "Insulting?" he asked, and then paused for several seconds to consider. "I don't find it insulting. I don't think it's accurate. I mean, I definitely care a lot. There's a difference between letting emotions drive impulsive decisions and caring." He went on, "Ultimately, I think the reason that we built this successful thing is because we just solve problem after problem after problem, and typically you don't do that by making impulsive, emotional decisions."

The caricature of Zuckerberg is that of an automaton with little regard for the human dimensions of his work. The truth is something else: he decided long ago that no historical change is painless. Like Augustus, he is at peace with his trade-offs. Between speech and truth, he chose speech. Between speed and perfection, he chose speed. Between scale and safety, he chose scale. His life thus far has convinced him that he can solve "problem after problem after problem," no matter the howling from the public it may cause.

At a certain point, the habits of mind that served Zuckerberg well on his ascent will start to work against him. To avoid further crises, he will have to embrace the fact that he's now a protector of the peace, not a disrupter of it. Facebook's colossal power of persuasion has delivered fortune but also peril. Like it or not, Zuckerberg is a gatekeeper. The era when Facebook could learn by doing, and fix the mistakes later, is over. The costs are too high, and idealism is not a defense against negligence.

In some sense, the "Mark Zuckerberg production"-as he called Facebook in its early years-has only just begun. Zuckerberg is not yet thirty-five, and the ambition with which he built his empire could well be directed toward shoring up his company, his country, and his name. The question is not whether Zuckerberg has the power to fix Facebook but whether he has the will; whether he will kick people out of his office-with the gusto that he once mustered for the pivot to mobile-if they don't bring him ideas for preventing violence in Myanmar, or protecting privacy, or mitigating the toxicity of social media. He succeeded, long ago, in making Facebook great. The challenge before him now is to make it good.

urn:contentItem:5VBN-PNH1-DYTY-C3KN-00000-00Giant insatiable data monsters;LETTERS TO THE EDITOR2019-02-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 20Giant insatiable data monstersLETTERS TO THE EDITOR

[Re: Should we worry that Facebook is integrating WhatsApp and Instagram?] Despite Facebook's outward attempts to regain user trust and assert its commitment to user privacy, this latest step to merge platforms reveals the systematic failure of the company and Silicon Valley to put the privacy of consumer data at the heart of what they do. I do understand the need for a company to make money to provide free services, but the abuse of privileges suggests that things have gone too far.

It is ironic that a social platform would be the most egregious abuser of social contracts. Time and time again, the tech giants operate under the assumption that misuse of data is acceptable. Big tech needs to understand that the spirit of the end user licence agreement is more important than just adhering to the letter of the law of the agreement. Crossing this social contract boundary with users can have significant costs.

Consumers - knowingly or unknowingly - often trade the privacy and security of their data for convenience offered, but the plan to merge platforms in this way equates to abuse of access and assumed trust. Trust is so important, now more than ever in our society. Facebook and Google have breached our trust multiple times over the past year by allowing users' personal data to be sold or stolen.

We need them to earn back that trust and it won't be an easy process. A multifaceted approach is needed, including government regulations, self-policing, and consumer vigilance.

The time is now for these giants to not only accept their monumental impact on society, but to act on this awareness by finally defining what acceptable use is, and sticking to it.

urn:contentItem:5V0V-96C1-JCJY-G3KF-00000-00Giant-killers needed in four sectors2018-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1Giant-killers needed in four sectorsVincent Boland

It sounds like a contradiction in terms. The auditing industry, supposedly the most staid of professions, may be on the brink of a revolution. Or rather, if proposals that emerged this week from two reviews of the sector are implemented, it is about to be cut down to size, perhaps literally.

The global auditing business is dominated by four companies, PWC, KPMG, EY and Deloitte. This is not a new phenomenon: the industry has been consolidating for decades. Yet it has become increasingly problematic. A series of corporate collapses over the past 20 years, including Enron, Worldcom and Carillion, have been blamed, in part, on failings by their auditors.

The problem is not that any one auditing company caused any one collapse. It is a more general malaise: that auditors did not spot the dangers, or warn of them, or underestimated or misunderstood the risks embedded in those companies. A corporate collapse is destructive of shareholders, employees and societies. Enron's collapse even led to the fall of its own auditor, Arthur Andersen, in 2002. That turned the Big Five, as it then was, into today's Big Four.

These four are now so dominant in that, according to the UK Competition and Markets Authority, 97 per cent of large UK companies are audited by one of them. That has led to allegations that they are an oligopoly. Moreover, they have consulting divisions that offer advice on matters such as corporate restructuring and strategy to those same companies, in return for lucrative fees. Critics have long seen that as a conflict of interest.

Now there are plans to address this undue concentration. The CMA, the UK regulator for competition, consumer protection and mergers and acquisitions, has proposed that consulting be separated from auditing, that the chairs of audit committees on corporate boards be made more accountable, and that a smaller auditing firm work alongside a Big Four member at large companies.

A separate review by John Kingman, chairman of Legal & General, recommends a thorough overhaul of the UK Financial Reporting Council, to give it sharper teeth in regulating the financial conduct of companies.

If these recommendations are carried out - as appears likely - the auditing industry could be in for a complete restructuring, not just in the UK but globally. The Big Four say they are not averse to change, though that may reflect the fact that it is inevitable rather than an enthusiastic embrace of reform.

The auditing industry may be an extreme example of corporate "gigantism". This is a tendency that leads to abusive behaviour and a lack of boardroom accountability, stifles innovation, and runs counter to the spirit of capitalism. I can think of three other industries that display elements of anti-competitive and oligopolistic behaviour.

One is banking. The root cause of the financial crisis of 2008 was that banks had become too big and concentrated. This was true of both high street banks and investment banks. In the latter case, the crisis led to the collapse of at least two fabled Wall Street names - Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns. Others have seen their investment banking business wither in the past decade, Deutsche Bank being perhaps the most notable example. To all intents and purposes, there are now only three investment banks with global heft: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JP Morgan.

At the same time, commercial banks are once again becoming concentrated. Competition appears to have vanished from the Irish banking market, if the controversy over mortgage interest rates, much higher here than elsewhere in the eurozone, is a guide. The European commercial banking market is concentrated in a shrinking pool of banks: HSBC, Société Générale, UniCredit and a handful of others. It is almost impossible to become a successful start-up bank, as the stuttering attempts of the UK's "challenger" banks to take on high street incumbents shows.

Another industry stifled by concentration is pharmaceuticals, dominated by a small number of very big firms: Glaxosmithkline, Pfizer, Merck, Roche and a few others. These companies used to be inventors of new drugs. Now, the emphasis on research and development is giving way to the tendency to buy new products from research-driven start-ups in the fields of biotech and "organic" medicines. There is still plenty of innovation in the industry, just not in Big Pharma.

The third example of gigantism is perhaps the most glaring: Big Tech. Silicon Valley has developed what appears to be a sense of entitlement to gigantism. This year, Apple became for a time the first American company to be valued on the stock market at a trillion dollars.

At least Apple has a degree of competition, from the likes of Samsung. That is not the case for Google and Facebook, which completely dominate the social media environment, and Amazon, the tech-retail giant that is disrupting the retail industry. Facebook has achieved this by scooping up potential competitors to its dominance of social media, such as Instagram and WhatsApp. Moreover, the emergence of the Silicon Valley giants has led to another unhealthy phenomenon - the concentration of stock market investment in the so-called FAANGs, the five tech companies that dominate the industry.

There was once a US tradition of trust-busting - breaking up huge companies to break monopolies. Those rules are still around, but the will to enforce them shrivelled as US politics was captured by corporate lobbying. Without an American lead, monopolies tend to flourish. The European Union talks, and sometimes acts, like a trust-buster. If the UK gets its way with the Big Four, this essential capitalist practice could be about to make a comeback.

urn:contentItem:5XR0-SS21-DXY4-X14G-00000-00Giant Stocks Shrug Off All Obstacles2019-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:03ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 1Giant Stocks Shrug Off All ObstaclesBy Matt Phillips

Giant tech stocks have posted a remarkable year, shrugging off the trade war, bipartisan political hostility and regulatory threats.

It was December 2018, and the towering giants of tech were looking wobbly.

Apple's shares were tumbling, and it hadn't yet delivered the bad news about a sales slowdown in China for the iPhone, a device that had helped make it the modern era's first trillion-dollar company. Facebook could not escape the shadow of the dueling electoral scandals of Cambridge Analytica and Russian disinformation. And Amazon's stock was sagging as the president of the United States regularly attacked the company.

Just as it appeared that the big tech companies' endless upward march had finally come to an end, they led a remarkable rally.

This year, the S&P 500 tech sector is up more than 40 percent, handily outpacing the 25 percent gain for the benchmark index over all, which is itself the third-best annual return of the past two decades.

Apple stock is up 70 percent, and it set a high-water mark last week. Google's parent company, Alphabet, is up 28.5 percent, and set its own record on Monday. Microsoft shares have soared 49 percent in 2019, and Amazon is up 16 percent.

And Facebook -- whose chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has spent much of the past two years telling lawmakers why his company can be trusted on issues as varied as personal data and cryptocurrency -- is up 53 percent.

Tech has surged in part thanks to the tide of rate cuts unleashed by the Federal Reserve, which has lifted all boats. The gains also reflect the relief investors are feeling that the trade war's worst outcomes haven't come to pass.

The trade-sensitive chip maker AMD more than doubled on such a swing in sentiment, making it the best-performing stock in the S&P 500 so far this year. Lam Research, which produces semiconductor manufacturing equipment, is up more than 90 percent, the second-best showing.

But the giants of technology -- companies like Apple, Alphabet, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft -- are the stocks that have made the market's year. Their bulk gives them outsize sway over indexes like the S&P 500, which are weighted by market capitalization. In other words, price moves of bigger companies move the index the most.

The rise in value of these five companies alone accounted for more than 20 percent of the total returns of the S&P 500 this year, through the end of November.

''It's been a great year for mega-cap tech for sure,'' said Richard Bodzy, a portfolio manager at Putnam Investments whose top two holdings are Microsoft and Apple.

Few would have predicted such robust results a year ago.

Between October 2018 and January, Apple's share price crashed roughly 40 percent. The stock plummeted nearly 10 percent in a single day -- Jan. 3 -- after the company cut its outlook for sales for the first time in over a decade, citing slowing iPhone sales in China.

Facebook's stock dropped 43 percent from its 2018 peak to the market's trough last December, as it faced months of scrutiny related to the use of its platform by Russians seeking to influence the 2016 American presidential campaign as well as the collection of users' data by the political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica. The tumble included a 19 percent nose dive -- the company's worst day ever -- on July 26, after executives said future profits would be hurt as it ramped up spending on security.

Amazon shares lost roughly 34 percent of their value between September 2018 and Christmas. President Trump has assailed the company and its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, who owns The Washington Post. Mr. Trump publicly accused Amazon of avoiding taxes and called The Post, which has aggressively covered the Trump administration, a lobbyist for the company. On Monday, Amazon said Mr. Trump had pressured the Pentagon to cut it out of a multibillion-dollar cloud computing contract.

With a slump of roughly 19 percent, Microsoft stood out for its relative resilience. Some investors dumped their shares late last year as the company's juggernaut web services division experienced a temporary deceleration in sales growth.

But, just when things looked bleakest, stocks began to rise.

In January, the Federal Reserve swiveled away from its 2018 policy of raising rates, toward its eventual decision to chop them three times in 2019. The Fed's efforts buoyed shares broadly, helping to set off the best start for the S&P 500 since the late 1980s.

The Fed chose to cut rates, in part, because of rising threats to economic growth. Those concerns also drove investors to buy shares in mega-cap tech companies.

''They are more economically resilient,'' said Jeb Breece, principal at Spears Abacus, an independent money management firm in Manhattan. ''A dollar of tech earnings seems like more of a sure bet than a dollar of Midwestern steel earnings.''

And earnings among the tech giants have held up better than some had feared. After ugly results in the first and second quarters, Facebook's third quarter topped expectations for profit and revenue.

Apple's results have also been better than expected recently, and Microsoft in particular has notched supercharged results. Its Azure cloud computing business has helped push the company's profit growth rate up to almost 30 percent for the last three quarters.

That has driven Apple and Microsoft -- which also happen to be the largest companies in the United States, by market cap -- to their best performances in a decade.

The recent climbs have left these tech giants with some of the largest market values on earth. Apple and Microsoft both have a market value of over $1 trillion. Alphabet is worth more than $900 billion.

The sheer scale of these companies is part of what makes their rise this year so remarkable. While huge share price surges are common in the market for smaller capitalization companies, these are giants.

The law of large numbers means it is far more difficult to generate large percentage increases in value. A unique confluence of factors allowed these companies to break that law this year. But observers say it's unlikely they will regularly clock such large gains.

''How does Microsoft double again? You're adding a trillion dollars,'' Mr. Breece said. ''You're just getting to huge numbers.''

PHOTO: Amazon's stock is up more than 16 percent this year, and relative to its tech peers, that rise is modest. (PHOTOGRAPH BY JEENAH MOON/BLOOMBERG) (B6)

urn:contentItem:5T3F-VCW1-F15W-H14B-00000-00GIDEON ROSE, CHIEF EDITOR, FOREIGN AFFAIRS, JOHN RYDING, CHIEF ECONOMIST, RDQ, GERRARD CASSIDY, HEAD OF U.S. BANK EQUITY STRATEGY, RBC ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG T.V.2018-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisGIDEON ROSE, CHIEF EDITOR, FOREIGN AFFAIRS, JOHN RYDING, CHIEF ECONOMIST, RDQ, GERRARD CASSIDY, HEAD OF U.S. BANK EQUITY STRATEGY, RBC ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG T.V.

August 21, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

JOHN RYDING, CHIEF ECONOMIST, RDQ; GIDEON ROSE, CHIEF EDITOR, FOREIGN AFFAIRS; GERARD CASSIDY, HEAD OF U.S. BANK EQUITY STRATEGY, RBC

KEENE: This is a wonderful hour, Gerard Cassidy to join us later on banking. We've got this incredibly important issue from Foreign Affairs. We'll get to that with Gideon Rose here a bit, but all of that is pushed aside by the President's comments in the last 24 hours on Fed independence.

We are thrilled to bring you this morning John Ryding of RDQ Economics. He is truly an expert on the Fed with his public service to the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve System.

John, how independent is the Federal Reserve this morning?

RYDING: eight says independent it was yesterday or last year or four or five years ago. In a similar way to the Supreme Court, obviously the President can influence the Fed by his nominations. And his nominations to the board have been strong.

Richard Clarida who you know very well is just an excellent choice for the Fed vice chair and I think his confirmation, you know, will go thread fairly soon.

So, we all know the President and his tendency to tweet one something or speak about something or complain about something. And maybe that's just because -- it's just the second time he's done this. It's not the normal protocol, but I don't think it influences Fed policy. But anything, the Fed may be more inclined to take a marginal action to raise rates.

And I don't think the decision to raise rates this year in September, December, you know, or even close decision. So I think two more rate hikes and we'll see by December the Fed policy was influenced.

KEENE: The team around him, David Malpass who you worked with for years at Bear Sterns. Mr. Kudlow and others, Secretary Mnuchin, did they have a voice to staunch the President's intentions whether someone politically sees them as good or bad?

RYDING: Well, they obviously have a voice. But, you know, we do have a President who at times can lash out or say things and there are also competing voices and obviously, you know, the biggest area of that is in the trade area where you've got, you know, Peter Navarro on one side of very protectionist trade agenda and Larry Kudlow with, you know, remains a free market guy. But he knows there a lot of, you know, China in particular being not a good actor on foreign policy --

LACQUA: Right, John?

RYDING: -- tariffs and free trade, you know, the President's taking actions against that.

LACQUA: Right. And John, for the moment, the President and his administration think that they're winning the trade war. Will China make them pay for it? Will they make them pay for it next to or closer to the midterm elections? And what would that do to big block buster U.S. companies?

RYDING: Well, Francine, nobody wins in a trade war. I think, you know, one of the almost universe if (ph) we propositions amongst most economists are the, you know, trade war's tariffs, they are welfare reducing on all sides.

So, it's not that I think that President Trump is a protectionist, it's that he thinks that tariffs because China has much larger exports to the U.S versus U.S. exports to China has more to lose. And therefore, by taking action and bringing them to the table and try and make progress in the same way that we had the start of a dialogue with the E.U.

So, I think if isn't trade war, it's not just the U.S. that pays. It's China that pays and we have to see how this plays out. I can't say I'm comfortable with it, but it's not that, you know, China can unilaterally damage the U.S. It would damage itself in the process.

LACQUA: Right, Gideon, do you think the U.S. cares?

ROSE: So, I go with everything John just said, except the President not being a protectionist. And from -- as a social scientist, what I find absolutely fascinating about the situation is I cannot remember a previous era in which we all sat around trying to predict what the government of the United States would do when the President of the United States, is it war with his own administration.

So we have no real models are precedent for understanding what happens when the government administration, the deep state, everything goes on and does its basic stuff as John was just talking about, the professional technocrats do their stuff, but then the guy at the top of the whole system who supposedly running things for the benefit of the country and the world and in sequence coordinating all the stuff goes off on a completely separate path and undermines his own administration actions.

Whether it's in the justice department, or whether it's in the economic policy department or whether it's in the security department. And so, we actually end up doing what John just said which is discounting the President's words, but then trying to figure what actually is going to be U.S. policy. So, we don't know.

KEENE: Right, I'll just tell you on this book here in a bit on the World War Web with Gideon Rose. It may be the issue ever for them. But right here, I'm going to hold this up, the unrestrained presidency within Gideon Rose's new effort. And within that on IR, but it can be on John's economics as well, the unconstrained presidencies because the legislatures is given up. Where is the legislature to push back against this debate on Fed independence?

ROSE: Well, so --

KEENE: Still nowhere.

ROSE: So, essentially, everything in U.S. politics has become subject to a partisan lens, right. You have Democrats and Republicans, the Republicans have aligned themselves at this point completely with the President who's is the head of their party of the leader office, and essentially now there is no Republican Party except on something, it's essentially Trump. And what Trump -- but he can't do anything.

So the question is, where does the President focus his attention in his discretionary powers? And then what happens with the rest of the government when they're doing the Donald Reagan cleaning up after the elephant phase? How does that all play out and what is the net result? We don't know.

KEENE: Lots tot talk about here with John Riding and Gideon Rose. This is an important segment on the World War Web here in a bit.

(BREAK)

KEENE: John Ryding with us of RDQ Economics. John, how many times has the Fed raised rates? Help the President here. You mentioned two rates earlier, but how many times do they raise rates through 2019? Were there?

RYDING: I think another four times in 2019. I mean --

KEENE: Two plus four equals six.

RYDING: Well, yes, two in 2000 and the rest of 2018 and four next year. I mean, look behind, you've got a charts on the real Fed funds rate if I'm looking at your wall correctly. And that's still negative which means to say that the inflation rate's still higher than the short-term interest rate. And that's normally consistent with accommodated conditions.

The equity market is within half a percent of record high. I don't see where we've had any tightening, reduced accommodation by the Fed with the rate hike so far.

KEENE: You have been the leading voice in market economics on the idea that higher rates is a good signal for this American economy. Can you say that right now with the debt that's coming on, the deficits that's coming on?

RYDING: Look, absolutely. I mean, you know, on the one hand and you had guest in your previous how you were talking about the yield curve and the flattening of the yield curve. You know, long term interest rates still remain very low. And monetary policy isn't about conducting interest rate policy to keep the cost of servicing the debt down.

Monetary policy is about maintaining stable prices and full employment as the Fed's mandated to and it's actually doing a pretty good job of doing that. But long-term, if inflations were to get out of hand and long term interest rates were to go up, that would be a lot more damaging for funding costs from the U.S. debt than the Fed rate hikes.

LACQUA: John, do you worry about where the U.S. economy is in, you know, the cycle effect, that late cycle and that there's a huge divergence with what, you know, BOJ are doing, ECB is doing?

RYDING: Well, in terms of where we are in the cycle, I was a lot more worried in 2016. In 2016, we're seeing a macroeconomic profit squeeze in the U.S. of the kind of magnitude that signaled a potential recession problem ahead. That's a far more important signal to me than the yield curve.

We had the corporate tax sculptures (ph) and reforms are absolutely essential for reinvigorating corporate America. And now we've seen pre-text macro-profit margins widen.

Now, that may be a problem down the road with inflation. And productivity of growth rates are too low, but in some ways with the way the stock markets moving, with the way it looks like corporate profits are shaping up in the second quarter, it may be that we had a growth recession in 2015, 2016 and we may be coming out of that with stronger growth. The problem is how much slack this was we saw the life in the labor market at a 3.9 percent unemployment rate?

But so I've been surprised at how many people we have drawn in. And now, it does seem that the U.S. economy is bring in people, more marginal people in terms of education and so on into labor force for a while.

KEENE: John Ryding with us who will return in the next half hour on the Central Bank.

Coming up, Gideon Rose will talk about the Web, look later today on Bloomberg Surveillance on Tesla, on governance. John Coffee, Professor Coffee of course with Columbia. This is Bloomberg, stay with us.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Let's get back to Gideon Rose of Foreign Affairs and John Ryding of RDQ Economics. John, when you look at China, I just don't believe there's not a slow down. I guess the question is how the authorities deal with it. It's by stimulating the economy so they stabilize it.

RYDING: Well, the angst say slow down from what rates. So China has been growing 6.5, seven percent at least in their efficient numbers. And if you project that out on compound growth rates and that kind of growth rate cannot be sustainable over a multi-decade period. The China has to slow eventually to the more normal global growth rate as China runs out of the ability to move population from the agricultural sector into the industrial sector.

So, I think we get too hung up on what China is growing at 6.7 percent or 6.5 percent or, you know, the reality is what China needs to reorientate scope (ph) economy away from being a primarily investment economy to more of a consumer economy. And that might end up being a healthier growth rate and development for the global economy then China simply growing at a faster pace with undertaking a lot of directed investments.

LACQUA: Gideon, how would you view Chinese politics right now and how bad it actually impacts the economy? If you can you hear me? Can you hear me?

ROSE: All right, a second, I can't hear you.

LACQUA: No, no one can hear me. Tom, translate for me.

KEENE: Well, we've got some audio problems going on right now. I mean, I look into the China and I look the -- well, we've got some on (ph) and we'll talk to Francine I guess is what we're going to do here across the transatlantic.

LACQUA: Can you hear me?

ROSE: Yes, I can hear you now Francine, sorry about that.

LACQUA: OK, I'm also hearing myself in Dolby stereo. Gideon, I was asking about Chinese politics and how Chinese politics actually influences the economy.

ROSE: So, it's actually a great question because what the Chinese actually understand I think far better than their Anglo-American counterparts is that the growth rates and the economic dynamism of the society and the progress toward on economic matters is situated within a political and social context. And so, what the Chinese government is trying to do is not just manage its growth rate and its economic policy, but also manage the entire polity of China in order to preserve the leadership of Xi Jinping and preserve stability within China and increase Chinese power.

And that broader context is actually really important because that's the kind of attention, not just to economic policy alone, but to the broader context of economics, society, and politics that economic policy makers in the west have basically intended to lose sight of which is producing a system in which there's a lot of push back and turmoil and people are getting that response (ph).

KEENE: We're going to have to leave it there. We'll get our audio straighten now and we thank you for being with us. With John Riding and Gideon Rose, please stay with us, this is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

KEENE: With us is Gideon Rose, he is of course the Editor in Chief of Foreign Affairs. Gideon, congratulations on this. Let me get right to it. The internet has lost its promise. Discuss.

ROSE: So, thank you very much for your kind words about the issue. Basically, think of this as a four at play. In the first act, the United States government creates the fundamentals of what we'll now call the internet.

KEENE: Right.

ROSE: The communication's network and a bunch of corporate (ph) of stuff --

(CROSSTALK)

ROSE: In act two, the United States government pairs with and partners with the private sector to develop this. It makes the infrastructure generally public and then allows private sector actors to develop all sorts of applications and so forth. This is the golden age of the internet in 1990's and things like that.

Act three, this starts to fray because the system goes on autopilot. And what happens is the large private tech companies take over large portions of the internet and become a sort of oligopoly running things on their own, government regulators really don't really get involved and the interne takes on its own life.

And during chapter three, the act three, various people start to push back against the problems with the internet. The Chinese try to succeed in a cyber sovereignty in their own sphere. The Europeans try to do regulations with GDPR. The Indians try to build a new internet from the ground up on more populist public good basis. And the Americans sit around wondering, can we control the tech companies? But Americans are so embedded in an Anglo-American view of liberal capitalism in which the government lets the private sector do its stuff that American policy has allowed the internet to create problems and now other people are stepping in to fix those problems.

KEENE: You really explained, then who has the power here? As you go chapter by chapter brilliantly, is it shining with the power or is it European regulatory structure that has --

ROSE: So the great question is we don't know who's going to have the power in act four. Because what happened in act one and two was the U.S. government created the infrastructure and turned it over to the private sector to help run. And in act three, we end up getting a lot of push back. And right now, you have governments like China, you have regional regulators like those in Europe, you have private sector companies like big tech, you have the citizens in general and nobody knows who is going to control the commanding heights of the digital economy.

Like for example, data regulation, who is going to get to keep and control and monetize the data? The individuals? The companies? The governments?

KEENE: Yes, but this is (INAUDIBLE). You mentioned commanding heights which is of course Daniel Yergin in his classic book on the 90s on the 20th century. Capitalism, there were two wars in the middle of Dan Yergin's commanding heights. What's going to be the warfare equivalent of this technology in our society?

ROSE: So, it's not going to be warfare in terms of geopolitical conflict between the major powers. What's going to happen is there was a common American sponsored liberal open order of the internet. Somewhat parallel to the globalization order and American officials move that forward to get all the benefits, but they forgot that the destruction part of created destruction creates pushback and people resist. And what you're seeing now in China, in Europe, in India even in the U.S. is people reacting against an unfettered private sector dominated internet but no one knows how to reestablish control because you don't want kill the goose that's laying the golden eggs.

So, what's happening right now is the question over the future control of the internet. It's not necessarily just going to be what it was in the last couple of decades which is, the United States debating whether or not to allow tech companies to have control over things.

Now, other global players are in fact going to be an important to this.

KEENE: Then how do you respond to the news just in the last 24 hours Apple limit x number of apps to China. I mean with their new chapter on China, they're making the rules, we're not. And even Tim Cook, Chief Operating officer of Tesla down Tim Cook has to vow to China.

ROSE: So what I feel about this is it's a little bit like the economic nationalism in other areas that we're seeing, right. Globalization races forward, it produces lots of wonderful things, lots of creative destruction and turmoil, but it also produces pushback and problems for people inside major developed western countries which causes them to want to put breaks in the process.

Take -- the fact is the Chinese are doing the same thing with the internet and just like American economic nationalist and populists and British wants and up places elsewhere want to hide off their economies from the globe and establish sovereignty, so the Chinese are trying to do the same thing for the internet.

LACQUA: Right, but we're talking about the different things, right. Gideon, on the one side, it's like cybersecurity and I guess, you know, the cyber race on who will have supremacy between China and the U.S. The other one is simply who is in the third act. It could be regulators, right. And this is Europe. Europe is leading a forefront regulation on automated (ph) passes pushback against it, but when it comes to data protection, these are the new people in town.

ROSE: Yes, but it's actually there are several competitors trying to do the same thing and we don't know which way of controlling the problems is going to win out. The European approach is regulation for the whole system, OK. The Chinese approaches secession from the system. Cyber sovereignty eventually the goal of that is to create essentially a splinternet in which there's a general public internet but the Chinese have build their own platforms, their own systems in 20 years in effect it'll be much more of a Chinese dominated internet than American dominated one.

The Indians want to reengineer the whole thing from the ground up. Fascinating article by Nandan Nilekani from emphasis abut what the Indians are doing in internet policy, maybe the most impressive and interesting of all the different approaches even though we don't hear much about it. And basically United States we're still wondering what to do because we don't basically have the conceptual ability to direct companies the way the government wants. And so, for the public ones.

LACQUA: OK. Talk to me about regulation because there's a great article in the latest edition of Foreign Affairs written by Helen Dixon saying regulate to liberate, can Europe save the internet? Can it?

ROSE: Well, so this is the great question. We tried to present a fair picture of this whole big debate. It's going forward on the future. So the lead piece in the package is by Adam Siegel talking about the transition of power from United States to China. Helen Dixon's article expresses the European approach which is no, it doesn't have to be the U.S. approach or the Chinese separate one, we can regulate it. Nandan Nilekani talks about the Indian one. We also have a number of different pieces on specific challenges of cyber security.

You should look at the European approach, the Chinese approach, the Indian approach and the American approach as variance of the same thing. Now that we've unleashed the wonderful creative destruction of digital technology, how do we keep it going forward in a positive way while controlling the social and political effects of all of this creative destruction?

LACQUA: Would these nations ever come together, Gideon? I don't know if whether it's a plaza accord for the internet. But, you know, that's the kind of idea.

ROSE: So, if people like John Ryding were controlling this stuff, then the answer would be yes because there's an obvious benefit for people to come together in a collective action coordination solution to read the benefits of a coordinated policy with central regulation.

But the problem is right now we have a tied international politics in the United States and elsewhere which is going inward rather than collective and I think the answer is we're moving towards a splinternet more than we are towards a new revelation.

KEENE: I love -- can we steal that words splinternet you get a royalty on that.

ROSE: It's not mine but it's a favorite --

(CROSSTALK)

KEENE: Here's the New York Times today folks, I'll read it for you. Russian hackers broaden the tax to consumers. First of all, I've got to make some news here with the counsel and foreign relations hack by Russians as well in this article?

ROSE: Like everybody else, we're constantly fished and attacked by various different actors. But that's just -- the Russians don't bother me as much. The Russians are like Butch Cassidy on the Sundance kid harassing the railroad.

KEENE: OK, who's the Katherine Losse (ph) of the World War Web? That's a Butch Cassidy.

ROSE: If the Chinese were going to be building a whole new railroad. So, we're worrying like E.H. Harriman in the Union percent (ph) of railroad about who's stealing our little -- we're worrying about who's stealing our safe. The Chinese are going around buying up the land and wanting them changed and developing engine technology 20 years from now, we're going to be running on Chinese trains and we're going to be wondering how did that happened.

KEENE: OK, then what is -- Francine's wonderful question about how do we get together on this, where is the unifying force particularly given the fractious politics our president's having with our allies?

ROSE: Karen Lornbluh and Michele Flournoy and Michael Somare have pieces in the article, in the package telling you what the United States should do and there are a lot of things.

Again, I would look to the Indian approach of the internet as a public good that may hold the best solution down the long road.

KEENE: Yes, but Tim Cook's stock options is not the public good.

ROSE: The question of the regulation of capitalism in a way that is beneficial economically, but also sustainable politically and socially is going to be that question of the mid 21st century.

LACQUA: Gideon, do you think any of these companies would self regulate for real?

ROSE: Yes, just like Martin Shkreli will self regulate.

LACQUA: It's respectively look?

ROSE: Yes, we can count on the tech companies to self regulate just like we can count on the pharmaceutical companies to provide low-cost medicines for everybody without regard to jacking up things when they have a cash monopoly like it ever been (ph).

LACQUA: All right, perfect. So, we do a little bit of, you know, that's a no. But why not? If you listen to the rationale of them regulating, it's either you regulate or you don't survive as people stop using you because you don't, you know, they don't trust. This -- they make money out of trusts, they don't make money out of selling drugs.

ROSE: Yes, in the long run. And in the short run, you make money by increasing your share of things, right. We have a president right now who is ignoring the entire cost of a global trade war to get some short term minor advantage in trivial little issues.

So, that kind of thinking if it can apply to the president of United States and the entire Republican Party, it also applies to individual private sector company managers. So we can't rely on them to be responsible for the entire global community down the road.

KEENE: Gideon, thank you so much. Your most important issue, I really mean this folks how dumb I am on our World War Web and I've to read it cover to cover. I can't say enough about it.

(BREAK)

KEENE: John Ryding with us with RDQ Economics and Gerard Cassidy joins from RBC Capital Markets and both of them have leaved every moment of this crisis. John, let me start with you as you go back and you look at where we are, can you say we're out of the crisis and it's a distant memory?

RYDING: We're out of the crisis and unfortunately it's a distant memory because by -- it become a distant memory, it's the way that some of the mistakes we make. But the difference between now and then is the degree of bank capital.

I think the unfortunate thing is in the re-regulation phase, some of the powers of the Fed intervened have been diminished sort of length of last resort which in the end is key when we get enterprises those -- some of those length of last resort facilities that powers been clipped.

But, yes, it's 10 years on, banks are well capitalized and this is when we make the mistakes that sow the seeds for the next problems.

KEENE: And Former Fed Official and Economist John Ryder, now we go to the trenches of securities analysis here. Do you agree that our banks are stronger and more resilient to the surprises that can come from 2006 and on to 2007?

CASSIDY: Absolutely Tom, what we've seen the banking industry has been recapitalized quite romantically. We haven't seen levels of capital like this in decades.

I would also point out what the Federal Reserve did though was they pushed the risk outside the commercial banking system. It is now in the shadow of banking industry. That's where the risk lies.

KEENE: It is amazing.

urn:contentItem:5T3F-VCW1-F15W-H14V-00000-00GIDEON ROSE, EDITOR, FOREIGN AFFAIRS IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE.2018-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisGIDEON ROSE, EDITOR, FOREIGN AFFAIRS IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE.

August 21, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

GIDEON ROSE, EDITOR, FOREIGN AFFAIRS

KEENE: The way you read Foreign Affairs Magazine, and everybody reads it differently, I started at the back and I glanced to the book reviews and then I'll go through and choose one, two, three articles that I have to read to get smarter. This issue is different, it's the most important issue Gideon Rose has ever done, "World War Web: The Fight for the Internet's Futures."

And, Jon Ferro, I'm so damn on all the stuff. I literally can admit I have to read it cover to cover.

FERRO: You and I both, I don't know anything about this.

KEENE: I mean there is a one issue he's ever done where I can I say I will come away from this more informed. Gideon Rose on the internet.

When you put this together, Adam Segal and all the other great writers and real heavy weights here, what was the biggest surprise, the outcome on our world war web?

ROSE: So, thank you very much for your kind words. I really love this issue too and this package was intellectually exciting to me. And I think the most interesting part of it is that as we put it together, we realized that there were two big stories that in effect the future of the internet was a microcosm of what's come to be known as the Post-American World.

The first big takeaway is that here as elsewhere, there is a transition of power going on between United States and China. But the long-term trend is of internet that started and was dominated by the United States and run according to U.S. principles and liberal, universal openness but that eventually is gradually moving towards either a separate Chinese sphere or a Chinese dominated main sphere in which they run things and you have a Chinese world that the America is living in rather than American world that China is living in.

KEENE: And, Jon, what's so interesting about this chapter to chapter is like every -- you know, it's Ian Bremmer, "Every Nation for Itself."

JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: So how much influence to the big internet businesses have over the rules of the game?

ROSE: Well, this a great question because it turns out that the reason why this power transition is happening is not what you might think. It is not simply a conversion of Chinese power into results, the way it would be in geopolitics or security or elsewhere or simply economics.

What happened is that the United States -- what's happening with the internet is a microcosm of what's happened with globalization more generally. The United States and western elites created a system, essentially a neoliberal system that liberated human potential, created a universal open playing field that allowed things to raise forward and they turned it over to the private sector having created a public infrastructure, they created a private sector competition to build things on top of that.

And that gave us the internet of the 1990s and more recent decades, basically a big open public infrastructure with lots of companies providing various goods and services for people and platforms to do it.

But that went on autopilot and those companies ended up becoming an oligopoly. And now the major experience of being online is mediated and infiltrated by those few big tech companies. And what turned out is that many people don't necessarily like that. And elsewhere in the Anglo-American world, elsewhere, I said the Anglo-American world, people have no qualms about controlling things.

And so the Europeans with GDPR are reasserting if they control. The Indians are trying to build a new internet from the ground up. And the Chinese are trying to stress cyber sovereignty. All of these are different approaches to reasserting political control over an unchecked real liberal internet going forward.

KEENE: Let me translate it to get to the, you know, the end of 200 pages of your magazine which is we're all a lot smarter now than we were 8, 9, 10, 12 years ago. Where are going to be in five years on this? Can you and your experts envision where the United States, where China, and as you mentioned repeatedly, where India will be on the internet?

ROSE: So the question here is hard to predict because right now there is a fight for the control over the basic rules of a game in cyberspace and digital stuff going online in the world going forward. Who will control things? Will it be governments like the Chinese government?

The Chinese version of cyber sovereignty is sort of like economic nationalism applied for the internet. They want their sphere to be controlled by the Chinese government by Beijing and they have no qualms or problems saying everybody else grew (ph) out. We don't care about the investors of the world. We don't care about private companies. We don't care about our people. We the Chinese government are going to control things.

Europe takes a different approach. They want to regulate the entire word, keep it a single system but have good strong regulation to make things OK. The Indians want something different and the Americans basically know there are problems but we don't have anything in place in United States for controlling tech companies. So right now, we just called them into Congress and drove on them while the problems continue to (INAUDIBLE).

KEENE: Well, this is going fabulous, Foreign Affairs "Word War Web," Adam Segal leads it off. Francine Lacqua loved Helen Dixon's article on Europe and regulation. If you have anything to do with technology, this is the must read into September, Foreign Affairs' "World War Web." I'll flag it to death out on social here as we can.

Gideon Rose with the Council on Foreign Relations and, of course, Foreign Affairs Magazine.

END
