urn:contentItem:5T3H-6JD1-DY0W-44XX-00000-00Gideon Rose, John Ryding, Gerrard Cassidy interviewed on BB TV2018-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisGideon Rose, John Ryding, Gerrard Cassidy interviewed on BB TVLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

35 minutes

(BREAK)

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: This is a wonderful hour, Gerard Cassidy to join us later on banking. We've got this incredibly important issue from Foreign Affairs. We'll get to that with Gideon Rose here a bit, but all of that is pushed aside by the President's comments in the last 24 hours on Fed independence.

We are thrilled to bring you this morning John Ryding of RDQ Economics. He is truly an expert on the Fed with his public service to the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve System.

John, how independent is the Federal Reserve this morning?

JOHN RYDING, CHIEF ECONOMIST, RDQ: eight says independent it was yesterday or last year or four or five years ago. In a similar way to the Supreme Court, obviously the President can influence the Fed by his nominations. And his nominations to the board have been strong.

Richard Clarida who you know very well is just an excellent choice for the Fed vice chair and I think his confirmation, you know, will go thread fairly soon.

So, we all know the President and his tendency to tweet one something or speak about something or complain about something. And maybe that's just because -- it's just the second time he's done this. It's not the normal protocol, but I don't think it influences Fed policy. But anything, the Fed may be more inclined to take a marginal action to raise rates.

And I don't think the decision to raise rates this year in September, December, you know, or even close decision. So I think two more rate hikes and we'll see by December the Fed policy was influenced.

KEENE: The team around him, David Malpass who you worked with for years at Bear Sterns. Mr. Kudlow and others, Secretary Mnuchin, did they have a voice to staunch the President's intentions whether someone politically sees them as good or bad?

RYDING: Well, they obviously have a voice. But, you know, we do have a President who at times can lash out or say things and there are also competing voices and obviously, you know, the biggest area of that is in the trade area where you've got, you know, Peter Navarro on one side of very protectionist trade agenda and Larry Kudlow with, you know, remains a free market guy. But he knows there a lot of, you know, China in particular being not a good actor on foreign policy --

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Right, John?

RYDING: -- tariffs and free trade, you know, the President's taking actions against that.

LACQUA: Right. And John, for the moment, the President and his administration think that they're winning the trade war. Will China make them pay for it? Will they make them pay for it next to or closer to the midterm elections? And what would that do to big block buster U.S. companies?

RYDING: Well, Francine, nobody wins in a trade war. I think, you know, one of the almost universe if (ph) we propositions amongst most economists are the, you know, trade war's tariffs, they are welfare reducing on all sides.

So, it's not that I think that President Trump is a protectionist, it's that he thinks that tariffs because China has much larger exports to the U.S versus U.S. exports to China has more to lose. And therefore, by taking action and bringing them to the table and try and make progress in the same way that we had the start of a dialogue with the E.U.

So, I think if isn't trade war, it's not just the U.S. that pays. It's China that pays and we have to see how this plays out. I can't say I'm comfortable with it, but it's not that, you know, China can unilaterally damage the U.S. It would damage itself in the process.

LACQUA: Right, Gideon, do you think the U.S. cares?

GIDEON ROSE, CHIEF EDITOR, FOREIGN AFFAIRS: So, I go with everything John just said, except the President not being a protectionist. And from -- as a social scientist, what I find absolutely fascinating about the situation is I cannot remember a previous era in which we all sat around trying to predict what the government of the United States would do when the President of the United States, is it war with his own administration.

So we have no real models are precedent for understanding what happens when the government administration, the deep state, everything goes on and does its basic stuff as John was just talking about, the professional technocrats do their stuff, but then the guy at the top of the whole system who supposedly running things for the benefit of the country and the world and in sequence coordinating all the stuff goes off on a completely separate path and undermines his own administration actions.

Whether it's in the justice department, or whether it's in the economic policy department or whether it's in the security department. And so, we actually end up doing what John just said which is discounting the President's words, but then trying to figure what actually is going to be U.S. policy. So, we don't know.

KEENE: Right, I'll just tell you on this book here in a bit on the World War Web with Gideon Rose. It may be the issue ever for them. But right here, I'm going to hold this up, the unrestrained presidency within Gideon Rose's new effort. And within that on IR, but it can be on John's economics as well, the unconstrained presidencies because the legislatures is given up. Where is the legislature to push back against this debate on Fed independence?

ROSE: Well, so --

KEENE: Still nowhere.

ROSE: So, essentially, everything in U.S. politics has become subject to a partisan lens, right. You have Democrats and Republicans, the Republicans have aligned themselves at this point completely with the President who's is the head of their party of the leader office, and essentially now there is no Republican Party except on something, it's essentially Trump. And what Trump -- but he can't do anything.

So the question is, where does the President focus his attention in his discretionary powers? And then what happens with the rest of the government when they're doing the Donald Reagan cleaning up after the elephant phase? How does that all play out and what is the net result? We don't know.

KEENE: Lots tot talk about here with John Riding and Gideon Rose. This is an important segment on the World War Web here in a bit.

(BREAK)

KEENE: John Ryding with us of RDQ Economics. John, how many times has the Fed raised rates? Help the President here. You mentioned two rates earlier, but how many times do they raise rates through 2019? Were there?

RYDING: I think another four times in 2019. I mean --

KEENE: Two plus four equals six.

RYDING: Well, yes, two in 2000 and the rest of 2018 and four next year. I mean, look behind, you've got a charts on the real Fed funds rate if I'm looking at your wall correctly. And that's still negative which means to say that the inflation rate's still higher than the short-term interest rate. And that's normally consistent with accommodated conditions.

The equity market is within half a percent of record high. I don't see where we've had any tightening, reduced accommodation by the Fed with the rate hike so far.

KEENE: You have been the leading voice in market economics on the idea that higher rates is a good signal for this American economy. Can you say that right now with the debt that's coming on, the deficits that's coming on?

RYDING: Look, absolutely. I mean, you know, on the one hand and you had guest in your previous how you were talking about the yield curve and the flattening of the yield curve. You know, long term interest rates still remain very low. And monetary policy isn't about conducting interest rate policy to keep the cost of servicing the debt down.

Monetary policy is about maintaining stable prices and full employment as the Fed's mandated to and it's actually doing a pretty good job of doing that. But long-term, if inflations were to get out of hand and long term interest rates were to go up, that would be a lot more damaging for funding costs from the U.S. debt than the Fed rate hikes.

LACQUA: John, do you worry about where the U.S. economy is in, you know, the cycle effect, that late cycle and that there's a huge divergence with what, you know, BOJ are doing, ECB is doing?

RYDING: Well, in terms of where we are in the cycle, I was a lot more worried in 2016. In 2016, we're seeing a macroeconomic profit squeeze in the U.S. of the kind of magnitude that signaled a potential recession problem ahead. That's a far more important signal to me than the yield curve.

We had the corporate tax sculptures (ph) and reforms are absolutely essential for reinvigorating corporate America. And now we've seen pre- text macro-profit margins widen.

Now, that may be a problem down the road with inflation. And productivity of growth rates are too low, but in some ways with the way the stock markets moving, with the way it looks like corporate profits are shaping up in the second quarter, it may be that we had a growth recession in 2015, 2016 and we may be coming out of that with stronger growth. The problem is how much slack this was we saw the life in the labor market at a 3.9 percent unemployment rate?

But so I've been surprised at how many people we have drawn in. And now, it does seem that the U.S. economy is bring in people, more marginal people in terms of education and so on into labor force for a while.

KEENE: John Ryding with us who will return in the next half hour on the Central Bank.

Coming up, Gideon Rose will talk about the Web, look later today on Bloomberg Surveillance on Tesla, on governance. John Coffee, Professor Coffee of course with Columbia. This is Bloomberg, stay with us.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Let's get back to Gideon Rose of Foreign Affairs and John Ryding of RDQ Economics. John, when you look at China, I just don't believe there's not a slow down. I guess the question is how the authorities deal with it. It's by stimulating the economy so they stabilize it.

RYDING: Well, the angst say slow down from what rates. So China has been growing 6.5, seven percent at least in their efficient numbers. And if you project that out on compound growth rates and that kind of growth rate cannot be sustainable over a multi-decade period. The China has to slow eventually to the more normal global growth rate as China runs out of the ability to move population from the agricultural sector into the industrial sector.

So, I think we get too hung up on what China is growing at 6.7 percent or 6.5 percent or, you know, the reality is what China needs to reorientate scope (ph) economy away from being a primarily investment economy to more of a consumer economy. And that might end up being a healthier growth rate and development for the global economy then China simply growing at a faster pace with undertaking a lot of directed investments.

LACQUA: Gideon, how would you view Chinese politics right now and how bad it actually impacts the economy? If you can you hear me? Can you hear me?

ROSE: All right, a second, I can't hear you.

LACQUA: No, no one can hear me. Tom, translate for me.

KEENE: Well, we've got some audio problems going on right now. I mean, I look into the China and I look the -- well, we've got some on (ph) and we'll talk to Francine I guess is what we're going to do here across the transatlantic.

LACQUA: Can you hear me?

ROSE: Yes, I can hear you now Francine, sorry about that.

LACQUA: OK, I'm also hearing myself in Dolby stereo. Gideon, I was asking about Chinese politics and how Chinese politics actually influences the economy.

ROSE: So, it's actually a great question because what the Chinese actually understand I think far better than their Anglo-American counterparts is that the growth rates and the economic dynamism of the society and the progress toward on economic matters is situated within a political and social context. And so, what the Chinese government is trying to do is not just manage its growth rate and its economic policy, but also manage the entire polity of China in order to preserve the leadership of Xi Jinping and preserve stability within China and increase Chinese power.

And that broader context is actually really important because that's the kind of attention, not just to economic policy alone, but to the broader context of economics, society, and politics that economic policy makers in the west have basically intended to lose sight of which is producing a system in which there's a lot of push back and turmoil and people are getting that response (ph).

KEENE: We're going to have to leave it there. We'll get our audio straighten now and we thank you for being with us. With John Riding and Gideon Rose, please stay with us, this is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

KEENE: With us is Gideon Rose, he is of course the Editor in Chief of Foreign Affairs. Gideon, congratulations on this. Let me get right to it. The internet has lost its promise. Discuss.

ROSE: So, thank you very much for your kind words about the issue. Basically, think of this as a four at play. In the first act, the United States government creates the fundamentals of what we'll now call the internet.

KEENE: Right.

ROSE: The communication's network and a bunch of corporate (ph) of stuff - -

(CROSSTALK)

ROSE: In act two, the United States government pairs with and partners with the private sector to develop this. It makes the infrastructure generally public and then allows private sector actors to develop all sorts of applications and so forth. This is the golden age of the internet in 1990's and things like that.

Act three, this starts to fray because the system goes on autopilot. And what happens is the large private tech companies take over large portions of the internet and become a sort of oligopoly running things on their own, government regulators really don't really get involved and the interne takes on its own life.

And during chapter three, the act three, various people start to push back against the problems with the internet. The Chinese try to succeed in a cyber sovereignty in their own sphere. The Europeans try to do regulations with GDPR. The Indians try to build a new internet from the ground up on more populist public good basis. And the Americans sit around wondering, can we control the tech companies? But Americans are so embedded in an Anglo-American view of liberal capitalism in which the government lets the private sector do its stuff that American policy has allowed the internet to create problems and now other people are stepping in to fix those problems.

KEENE: You really explained, then who has the power here? As you go chapter by chapter brilliantly, is it shining with the power or is it European regulatory structure that has --

ROSE: So the great question is we don't know who's going to have the power in act four. Because what happened in act one and two was the U.S. government created the infrastructure and turned it over to the private sector to help run. And in act three, we end up getting a lot of push back. And right now, you have governments like China, you have regional regulators like those in Europe, you have private sector companies like big tech, you have the citizens in general and nobody knows who is going to control the commanding heights of the digital economy.

Like for example, data regulation, who is going to get to keep and control and monetize the data? The individuals? The companies? The governments?

KEENE: Yes, but this is (INAUDIBLE). You mentioned commanding heights which is of course Daniel Yergin in his classic book on the 90s on the 20th century. Capitalism, there were two wars in the middle of Dan Yergin's commanding heights. What's going to be the warfare equivalent of this technology in our society?

ROSE: So, it's not going to be warfare in terms of geopolitical conflict between the major powers. What's going to happen is there was a common American sponsored liberal open order of the internet. Somewhat parallel to the globalization order and American officials move that forward to get all the benefits, but they forgot that the destruction part of created destruction creates pushback and people resist. And what you're seeing now in China, in Europe, in India even in the U.S. is people reacting against an unfettered private sector dominated internet but no one knows how to reestablish control because you don't want kill the goose that's laying the golden eggs.

So, what's happening right now is the question over the future control of the internet. It's not necessarily just going to be what it was in the last couple of decades which is, the United States debating whether or not to allow tech companies to have control over things.

Now, other global players are in fact going to be an important to this.

KEENE: Then how do you respond to the news just in the last 24 hours Apple limit x number of apps to China. I mean with their new chapter on China, they're making the rules, we're not. And even Tim Cook, Chief Operating officer of Tesla down Tim Cook has to vow to China.

ROSE: So what I feel about this is it's a little bit like the economic nationalism in other areas that we're seeing, right. Globalization races forward, it produces lots of wonderful things, lots of creative destruction and turmoil, but it also produces pushback and problems for people inside major developed western countries which causes them to want to put breaks in the process.

Take -- the fact is the Chinese are doing the same thing with the internet and just like American economic nationalist and populists and British wants and up places elsewhere want to hide off their economies from the globe and establish sovereignty, so the Chinese are trying to do the same thing for the internet.

LACQUA: Right, but we're talking about the different things, right. Gideon, on the one side, it's like cybersecurity and I guess, you know, the cyber race on who will have supremacy between China and the U.S. The other one is simply who is in the third act. It could be regulators, right. And this is Europe. Europe is leading a forefront regulation on automated (ph) passes pushback against it, but when it comes to data protection, these are the new people in town.

ROSE: Yes, but it's actually there are several competitors trying to do the same thing and we don't know which way of controlling the problems is going to win out. The European approach is regulation for the whole system, OK. The Chinese approaches secession from the system. Cyber sovereignty eventually the goal of that is to create essentially a splinternet in which there's a general public internet but the Chinese have build their own platforms, their own systems in 20 years in effect it'll be much more of a Chinese dominated internet than American dominated one.

The Indians want to reengineer the whole thing from the ground up. Fascinating article by Nandan Nilekani from emphasis abut what the Indians are doing in internet policy, maybe the most impressive and interesting of all the different approaches even though we don't hear much about it. And basically United States we're still wondering what to do because we don't basically have the conceptual ability to direct companies the way the government wants. And so, for the public ones.

LACQUA: OK. Talk to me about regulation because there's a great article in the latest edition of Foreign Affairs written by Helen Dixon saying regulate to liberate, can Europe save the internet? Can it?

ROSE: Well, so this is the great question. We tried to present a fair picture of this whole big debate. It's going forward on the future. So the lead piece in the package is by Adam Siegel talking about the transition of power from United States to China. Helen Dixon's article expresses the European approach which is no, it doesn't have to be the U.S. approach or the Chinese separate one, we can regulate it. Nandan Nilekani talks about the Indian one. We also have a number of different pieces on specific challenges of cyber security.

You should look at the European approach, the Chinese approach, the Indian approach and the American approach as variance of the same thing. Now that we've unleashed the wonderful creative destruction of digital technology, how do we keep it going forward in a positive way while controlling the social and political effects of all of this creative destruction?

LACQUA: Would these nations ever come together, Gideon? I don't know if whether it's a plaza accord for the internet. But, you know, that's the kind of idea.

ROSE: So, if people like John Ryding were controlling this stuff, then the answer would be yes because there's an obvious benefit for people to come together in a collective action coordination solution to read the benefits of a coordinated policy with central regulation.

But the problem is right now we have a tied international politics in the United States and elsewhere which is going inward rather than collective and I think the answer is we're moving towards a splinternet more than we are towards a new revelation.

KEENE: I love -- can we steal that words splinternet you get a royalty on that.

ROSE: It's not mine but it's a favorite --

(CROSSTALK)

KEENE: Here's the New York Times today folks, I'll read it for you. Russian hackers broaden the tax to consumers. First of all, I've got to make some news here with the counsel and foreign relations hack by Russians as well in this article?

ROSE: Like everybody else, we're constantly fished and attacked by various different actors. But that's just -- the Russians don't bother me as much. The Russians are like Butch Cassidy on the Sundance kid harassing the railroad.

KEENE: OK, who's the Katherine Losse (ph) of the World War Web? That's a Butch Cassidy.

ROSE: If the Chinese were going to be building a whole new railroad. So, we're worrying like E.H. Harriman in the Union percent (ph) of railroad about who's stealing our little -- we're worrying about who's stealing our safe. The Chinese are going around buying up the land and wanting them changed and developing engine technology 20 years from now, we're going to be running on Chinese trains and we're going to be wondering how did that happened.

KEENE: OK, then what is -- Francine's wonderful question about how do we get together on this, where is the unifying force particularly given the fractious politics our president's having with our allies?

ROSE: Karen Lornbluh and Michele Flournoy and Michael Somare have pieces in the article, in the package telling you what the United States should do and there are a lot of things.

Again, I would look to the Indian approach of the internet as a public good that may hold the best solution down the long road.

KEENE: Yes, but Tim Cook's stock options is not the public good.

ROSE: The question of the regulation of capitalism in a way that is beneficial economically, but also sustainable politically and socially is going to be that question of the mid 21st century.

LACQUA: Gideon, do you think any of these companies would self regulate for real?

ROSE: Yes, just like Martin Shkreli will self regulate.

LACQUA: It's respectively look?

ROSE: Yes, we can count on the tech companies to self regulate just like we can count on the pharmaceutical companies to provide low-cost medicines for everybody without regard to jacking up things when they have a cash monopoly like it ever been (ph).

LACQUA: All right, perfect. So, we do a little bit of, you know, that's a no. But why not? If you listen to the rationale of them regulating, it's either you regulate or you don't survive as people stop using you because you don't, you know, they don't trust. This -- they make money out of trusts, they don't make money out of selling drugs.

ROSE: Yes, in the long run. And in the short run, you make money by increasing your share of things, right. We have a president right now who is ignoring the entire cost of a global trade war to get some short term minor advantage in trivial little issues.

So, that kind of thinking if it can apply to the president of United States and the entire Republican Party, it also applies to individual private sector company managers. So we can't rely on them to be responsible for the entire global community down the road.

KEENE: Gideon, thank you so much. Your most important issue, I really mean this folks how dumb I am on our World War Web and I've to read it cover to cover. I can't say enough about it.

We're going to come back. John Ryding of RDQ Economics to dive once more into the independence of your selected central bank and then an important conversation with Gerard Cassidy on Fortress diamond, Fortress Moynihan in your neighborhood bank.

(BREAK)

KEENE: John Ryding with us with RDQ Economics and Gerard Cassidy joins from RBC Capital Markets and both of them have leaved every moment of this crisis. John, let me start with you as you go back and you look at where we are, can you say we're out of the crisis and it's a distant memory?

RYDING: We're out of the crisis and unfortunately it's a distant memory because by -- it become a distant memory, it's the way that some of the mistakes we make. But the difference between now and then is the degree of bank capital.

I think the system is much better buffered ad that's a positive. I think the unfortunate thing is in the re-regulation phase, some of the powers of the Fed intervened have been diminished sort of length of last resort which in the end is key when we get enterprises those -- some of those length of last resort facilities that powers been clipped.

But, yes, it's 10 years on, banks are well capitalized and this is when we make the mistakes that sow the seeds for the next problems.

KEENE: And Former Fed Official and Economist John Ryder, now we go to the trenches of securities analysis here. Do you agree that our banks are stronger and more resilient to the surprises that can come from 2006 and on to 2007?

GERARD CASSIDY, HEAD OF U.S. BANK EQUITY STRATEGY, RBC: Absolutely Tom, what we've seen the banking industry has been recapitalized quite romantically. We haven't seen levels of capital like this in decades.

I would also point out what the Federal Reserve did though was they pushed the risk outside the commercial banking system. It is now in the shadow of banking industry. That's where the risk lies.

So when the next crisis comes, we're not going to JPMorgan or Bank of America or Citigroup have the problems that they had last time. But I do worry about the hedge funds, the mutual funds, all the other outside, the traditional-commercial banking industry, those are the folks that could have the real problems.

LACQUA: John, where do you think the next crisis will come from? Is it going to be from Asia, is it going to be away from the financial sector?

RYDING: Well, I think in all things, the source of the crisis suppose to what the crisis is becomes financial policy, monetary policy that's too lose. I still think we have lax monetary policy that leads to over leverage, that leads to capital flow into asset classes that it shouldn't be.

But the system is being tested. What's happening in Turkey and the global ramifications, that's an interesting test because we thought emerging markets is one area that's going to be overleveraged. But, I don't see that so much as a systemic issue in the same way that (INAUDIBLE) turned out to be systemic issue back in 2010.

So, capital is an important buffer to hold back those crises. But raising interest rates is the best way to avoid getting into it.

KEENE: It's exceptionally time with John Ryding, thank you so much for being with us today. John Ryding on Fed independence, he's with RDQ economics. Coming up, a really important chart with Gerard Cassidy, we'll that next. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

KEENE: It's just a simple chart with Gerard Cassidy to look at here. And Gerard, what I want to talk about, forget about the Bull market like Fortress Diamond and maybe back here is a Harris and like here's a great malaise. How does any bank institution avoid a 15 year churn? What do you do to avoid that?

CASSIDY: Tom, I think that this is a phenomenal chart to have a go back as far as you have it and you do show the two great up legs. But there is that period that you point out this malaise. I think what it is, today, the banks are more focused than ever on shareholder return. During that malaise period, it was the recovery coming out of the 1990 downturn, but then you had the tech implosion in 2001. So those two periods affected the malaise that you identified.

KEENE: Who into -- your universe and even bank on the cover, I understand the game. Who is the one that uses technology best? Who's the technological leader in the Cassidy world?

CASSIDY: I would say that you have to identify probably our top banks, including bank of America and JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo. Citigroup I would put in there as well. So, our biggest banks are not only spending the most money, they are also becoming the most tech savvy. They're embracing it. They know the digitalization of banking is the future.

LACQUA: Gerard, are there concerns that actually some like Facebook or Amazon or someone else will go into banking?

CASSIDY: I would say that we don't really have to worry about that at this time. And the reason being there was a large moat around commercial banking. If you want to take the deposits and make loans, you have to have a banking license. I'm not -- I don't believe that Facebook, Google, or any of these companies want to become a bank holding company because you will be regulated by the bank regulators which would then lead to a much lower stock multiple. So right now, the moat is very difficult if impossible to cross.

LACQUA: We love talking about banks. We talk about capital ratios, we talk about you know, the thick (ph) and all of that, but actually who's the bank that's talking to millenials and is that the next frontier?

CASSIDY: You know, it's interesting because the millenials are a very important part of the banking system and all the banks are trying to reach out with to them.

I was with U.S. bank core yesterday in Boston and it was very clear to me that this company is reaching out and through their payment system, to millennials because think of Venmo or Uber, that's the first introduction many of these millenials have to the banking system is through payments where many of us, Tom and I and folks first time we ever got in touch with the bank was with the passbook savings account. That's not the way in many of millenials do it anymore.

So, I would say the big banks JPMorgan and Bank of America, Regional Banks like PMC and U.S. bank are doing very good job reaching out to the millenials.

KEENE: Work very quickly here, when does branch banking finally throw in the towel? tail? I mean you go buy and nobody is them.

CASSIDY: Tom, it's amazing what's happening.

KEENE: It is amazing.

CASSIDY: It truly is. And we have some data to show you that the branch banking peak, the year the Apple introduced the iPhone. So, over the next ten years I would suggest to you but probably there was another third of the branches easily.

KEENE: A third, very good. Gerard Cassidy thank you so much and we'll continue this discussion. I'm thrilled to say with Mr. Ferro on Bloomberg Radio here in a moment.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5T39-H311-JB20-G4HJ-00000-00Gideon Rose, John Ryding, Gerrard Cassidy interviewed on BB TV2018-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTGideon Rose, John Ryding, Gerrard Cassidy, Francine LacquaNEWSInternational082183cb.550Gideon Rose, John Ryding, Gerrard Cassidy interviewed on BB TVTom Keene

Gideon Rose, John Ryding, Gerrard Cassidy discuss economics

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

35 minutes

(BREAK)

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: This is a wonderful hour, Gerard Cassidy to join us later on banking. We've got this incredibly important issue from Foreign Affairs. We'll get to that with Gideon Rose here a bit, but all of that is pushed aside by the President's comments in the last 24 hours on Fed independence.

We are thrilled to bring you this morning John Ryding of RDQ Economics. He is truly an expert on the Fed with his public service to the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve System.

John, how independent is the Federal Reserve this morning?

JOHN RYDING, CHIEF ECONOMIST, RDQ: eight says independent it was yesterday or last year or four or five years ago. In a similar way to the Supreme Court, obviously the President can influence the Fed by his nominations. And his nominations to the board have been strong.

Richard Clarida who you know very well is just an excellent choice for the Fed vice chair and I think his confirmation, you know, will go thread fairly soon.

So, we all know the President and his tendency to tweet one something or speak about something or complain about something. And maybe that's just because -- it's just the second time he's done this. It's not the normal protocol, but I don't think it influences Fed policy. But anything, the Fed may be more inclined to take a marginal action to raise rates.

And I don't think the decision to raise rates this year in September, December, you know, or even close decision. So I think two more rate hikes and we'll see by December the Fed policy was influenced.

KEENE: The team around him, David Malpass who you worked with for years at Bear Sterns. Mr. Kudlow and others, Secretary Mnuchin, did they have a voice to staunch the President's intentions whether someone politically sees them as good or bad?

RYDING: Well, they obviously have a voice. But, you know, we do have a President who at times can lash out or say things and there are also competing voices and obviously, you know, the biggest area of that is in the trade area where you've got, you know, Peter Navarro on one side of very protectionist trade agenda and Larry Kudlow with, you know, remains a free market guy. But he knows there a lot of, you know, China in particular being not a good actor on foreign policy --

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Right, John?

RYDING: -- tariffs and free trade, you know, the President's taking actions against that.

LACQUA: Right. And John, for the moment, the President and his administration think that they're winning the trade war. Will China make them pay for it? Will they make them pay for it next to or closer to the midterm elections? And what would that do to big block buster U.S. companies?

RYDING: Well, Francine, nobody wins in a trade war. I think, you know, one of the almost universe if (ph) we propositions amongst most economists are the, you know, trade war's tariffs, they are welfare reducing on all sides.

So, it's not that I think that President Trump is a protectionist, it's that he thinks that tariffs because China has much larger exports to the U.S versus U.S. exports to China has more to lose. And therefore, by taking action and bringing them to the table and try and make progress in the same way that we had the start of a dialogue with the E.U.

So, I think if isn't trade war, it's not just the U.S. that pays. It's China that pays and we have to see how this plays out. I can't say I'm comfortable with it, but it's not that, you know, China can unilaterally damage the U.S. It would damage itself in the process.

LACQUA: Right, Gideon, do you think the U.S. cares?

GIDEON ROSE, CHIEF EDITOR, FOREIGN AFFAIRS: So, I go with everything John just said, except the President not being a protectionist. And from -- as a social scientist, what I find absolutely fascinating about the situation is I cannot remember a previous era in which we all sat around trying to predict what the government of the United States would do when the President of the United States, is it war with his own administration.

So we have no real models are precedent for understanding what happens when the government administration, the deep state, everything goes on and does its basic stuff as John was just talking about, the professional technocrats do their stuff, but then the guy at the top of the whole system who supposedly running things for the benefit of the country and the world and in sequence coordinating all the stuff goes off on a completely separate path and undermines his own administration actions.

Whether it's in the justice department, or whether it's in the economic policy department or whether it's in the security department. And so, we actually end up doing what John just said which is discounting the President's words, but then trying to figure what actually is going to be U.S. policy. So, we don't know.

KEENE: Right, I'll just tell you on this book here in a bit on the World War Web with Gideon Rose. It may be the issue ever for them. But right here, I'm going to hold this up, the unrestrained presidency within Gideon Rose's new effort. And within that on IR, but it can be on John's economics as well, the unconstrained presidencies because the legislatures is given up. Where is the legislature to push back against this debate on Fed independence?

ROSE: Well, so --

KEENE: Still nowhere.

ROSE: So, essentially, everything in U.S. politics has become subject to a partisan lens, right. You have Democrats and Republicans, the Republicans have aligned themselves at this point completely with the President who's is the head of their party of the leader office, and essentially now there is no Republican Party except on something, it's essentially Trump. And what Trump -- but he can't do anything.

So the question is, where does the President focus his attention in his discretionary powers? And then what happens with the rest of the government when they're doing the Donald Reagan cleaning up after the elephant phase? How does that all play out and what is the net result? We don't know.

KEENE: Lots tot talk about here with John Riding and Gideon Rose. This is an important segment on the World War Web here in a bit.

(BREAK)

KEENE: John Ryding with us of RDQ Economics. John, how many times has the Fed raised rates? Help the President here. You mentioned two rates earlier, but how many times do they raise rates through 2019? Were there?

RYDING: I think another four times in 2019. I mean --

KEENE: Two plus four equals six.

RYDING: Well, yes, two in 2000 and the rest of 2018 and four next year. I mean, look behind, you've got a charts on the real Fed funds rate if I'm looking at your wall correctly. And that's still negative which means to say that the inflation rate's still higher than the short-term interest rate. And that's normally consistent with accommodated conditions.

The equity market is within half a percent of record high. I don't see where we've had any tightening, reduced accommodation by the Fed with the rate hike so far.

KEENE: You have been the leading voice in market economics on the idea that higher rates is a good signal for this American economy. Can you say that right now with the debt that's coming on, the deficits that's coming on?

RYDING: Look, absolutely. I mean, you know, on the one hand and you had guest in your previous how you were talking about the yield curve and the flattening of the yield curve. You know, long term interest rates still remain very low. And monetary policy isn't about conducting interest rate policy to keep the cost of servicing the debt down.

Monetary policy is about maintaining stable prices and full employment as the Fed's mandated to and it's actually doing a pretty good job of doing that. But long-term, if inflations were to get out of hand and long term interest rates were to go up, that would be a lot more damaging for funding costs from the U.S. debt than the Fed rate hikes.

LACQUA: John, do you worry about where the U.S. economy is in, you know, the cycle effect, that late cycle and that there's a huge divergence with what, you know, BOJ are doing, ECB is doing?

RYDING: Well, in terms of where we are in the cycle, I was a lot more worried in 2016. In 2016, we're seeing a macroeconomic profit squeeze in the U.S. of the kind of magnitude that signaled a potential recession problem ahead. That's a far more important signal to me than the yield curve.

We had the corporate tax sculptures (ph) and reforms are absolutely essential for reinvigorating corporate America. And now we've seen pre- text macro-profit margins widen.

Now, that may be a problem down the road with inflation. And productivity of growth rates are too low, but in some ways with the way the stock markets moving, with the way it looks like corporate profits are shaping up in the second quarter, it may be that we had a growth recession in 2015, 2016 and we may be coming out of that with stronger growth. The problem is how much slack this was we saw the life in the labor market at a 3.9 percent unemployment rate?

But so I've been surprised at how many people we have drawn in. And now, it does seem that the U.S. economy is bring in people, more marginal people in terms of education and so on into labor force for a while.

KEENE: John Ryding with us who will return in the next half hour on the Central Bank.

Coming up, Gideon Rose will talk about the Web, look later today on Bloomberg Surveillance on Tesla, on governance. John Coffee, Professor Coffee of course with Columbia. This is Bloomberg, stay with us.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Let's get back to Gideon Rose of Foreign Affairs and John Ryding of RDQ Economics. John, when you look at China, I just don't believe there's not a slow down. I guess the question is how the authorities deal with it. It's by stimulating the economy so they stabilize it.

RYDING: Well, the angst say slow down from what rates. So China has been growing 6.5, seven percent at least in their efficient numbers. And if you project that out on compound growth rates and that kind of growth rate cannot be sustainable over a multi-decade period. The China has to slow eventually to the more normal global growth rate as China runs out of the ability to move population from the agricultural sector into the industrial sector.

So, I think we get too hung up on what China is growing at 6.7 percent or 6.5 percent or, you know, the reality is what China needs to reorientate scope (ph) economy away from being a primarily investment economy to more of a consumer economy. And that might end up being a healthier growth rate and development for the global economy then China simply growing at a faster pace with undertaking a lot of directed investments.

LACQUA: Gideon, how would you view Chinese politics right now and how bad it actually impacts the economy? If you can you hear me? Can you hear me?

ROSE: All right, a second, I can't hear you.

LACQUA: No, no one can hear me. Tom, translate for me.

KEENE: Well, we've got some audio problems going on right now. I mean, I look into the China and I look the -- well, we've got some on (ph) and we'll talk to Francine I guess is what we're going to do here across the transatlantic.

LACQUA: Can you hear me?

ROSE: Yes, I can hear you now Francine, sorry about that.

LACQUA: OK, I'm also hearing myself in Dolby stereo. Gideon, I was asking about Chinese politics and how Chinese politics actually influences the economy.

ROSE: So, it's actually a great question because what the Chinese actually understand I think far better than their Anglo-American counterparts is that the growth rates and the economic dynamism of the society and the progress toward on economic matters is situated within a political and social context. And so, what the Chinese government is trying to do is not just manage its growth rate and its economic policy, but also manage the entire polity of China in order to preserve the leadership of Xi Jinping and preserve stability within China and increase Chinese power.

And that broader context is actually really important because that's the kind of attention, not just to economic policy alone, but to the broader context of economics, society, and politics that economic policy makers in the west have basically intended to lose sight of which is producing a system in which there's a lot of push back and turmoil and people are getting that response (ph).

KEENE: We're going to have to leave it there. We'll get our audio straighten now and we thank you for being with us. With John Riding and Gideon Rose, please stay with us, this is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

KEENE: With us is Gideon Rose, he is of course the Editor in Chief of Foreign Affairs. Gideon, congratulations on this. Let me get right to it. The internet has lost its promise. Discuss.

ROSE: So, thank you very much for your kind words about the issue. Basically, think of this as a four at play. In the first act, the United States government creates the fundamentals of what we'll now call the internet.

KEENE: Right.

ROSE: The communication's network and a bunch of corporate (ph) of stuff - -

(CROSSTALK)

ROSE: In act two, the United States government pairs with and partners with the private sector to develop this. It makes the infrastructure generally public and then allows private sector actors to develop all sorts of applications and so forth. This is the golden age of the internet in 1990's and things like that.

Act three, this starts to fray because the system goes on autopilot. And what happens is the large private tech companies take over large portions of the internet and become a sort of oligopoly running things on their own, government regulators really don't really get involved and the interne takes on its own life.

And during chapter three, the act three, various people start to push back against the problems with the internet. The Chinese try to succeed in a cyber sovereignty in their own sphere. The Europeans try to do regulations with GDPR. The Indians try to build a new internet from the ground up on more populist public good basis. And the Americans sit around wondering, can we control the tech companies? But Americans are so embedded in an Anglo-American view of liberal capitalism in which the government lets the private sector do its stuff that American policy has allowed the internet to create problems and now other people are stepping in to fix those problems.

KEENE: You really explained, then who has the power here? As you go chapter by chapter brilliantly, is it shining with the power or is it European regulatory structure that has --

ROSE: So the great question is we don't know who's going to have the power in act four. Because what happened in act one and two was the U.S. government created the infrastructure and turned it over to the private sector to help run. And in act three, we end up getting a lot of push back. And right now, you have governments like China, you have regional regulators like those in Europe, you have private sector companies like big tech, you have the citizens in general and nobody knows who is going to control the commanding heights of the digital economy.

Like for example, data regulation, who is going to get to keep and control and monetize the data? The individuals? The companies? The governments?

KEENE: Yes, but this is (INAUDIBLE). You mentioned commanding heights which is of course Daniel Yergin in his classic book on the 90s on the 20th century. Capitalism, there were two wars in the middle of Dan Yergin's commanding heights. What's going to be the warfare equivalent of this technology in our society?

ROSE: So, it's not going to be warfare in terms of geopolitical conflict between the major powers. What's going to happen is there was a common American sponsored liberal open order of the internet. Somewhat parallel to the globalization order and American officials move that forward to get all the benefits, but they forgot that the destruction part of created destruction creates pushback and people resist. And what you're seeing now in China, in Europe, in India even in the U.S. is people reacting against an unfettered private sector dominated internet but no one knows how to reestablish control because you don't want kill the goose that's laying the golden eggs.

So, what's happening right now is the question over the future control of the internet. It's not necessarily just going to be what it was in the last couple of decades which is, the United States debating whether or not to allow tech companies to have control over things.

Now, other global players are in fact going to be an important to this.

KEENE: Then how do you respond to the news just in the last 24 hours Apple limit x number of apps to China. I mean with their new chapter on China, they're making the rules, we're not. And even Tim Cook, Chief Operating officer of Tesla down Tim Cook has to vow to China.

ROSE: So what I feel about this is it's a little bit like the economic nationalism in other areas that we're seeing, right. Globalization races forward, it produces lots of wonderful things, lots of creative destruction and turmoil, but it also produces pushback and problems for people inside major developed western countries which causes them to want to put breaks in the process.

Take -- the fact is the Chinese are doing the same thing with the internet and just like American economic nationalist and populists and British wants and up places elsewhere want to hide off their economies from the globe and establish sovereignty, so the Chinese are trying to do the same thing for the internet.

LACQUA: Right, but we're talking about the different things, right. Gideon, on the one side, it's like cybersecurity and I guess, you know, the cyber race on who will have supremacy between China and the U.S. The other one is simply who is in the third act. It could be regulators, right. And this is Europe. Europe is leading a forefront regulation on automated (ph) passes pushback against it, but when it comes to data protection, these are the new people in town.

ROSE: Yes, but it's actually there are several competitors trying to do the same thing and we don't know which way of controlling the problems is going to win out. The European approach is regulation for the whole system, OK. The Chinese approaches secession from the system. Cyber sovereignty eventually the goal of that is to create essentially a splinternet in which there's a general public internet but the Chinese have build their own platforms, their own systems in 20 years in effect it'll be much more of a Chinese dominated internet than American dominated one.

The Indians want to reengineer the whole thing from the ground up. Fascinating article by Nandan Nilekani from emphasis abut what the Indians are doing in internet policy, maybe the most impressive and interesting of all the different approaches even though we don't hear much about it. And basically United States we're still wondering what to do because we don't basically have the conceptual ability to direct companies the way the government wants. And so, for the public ones.

LACQUA: OK. Talk to me about regulation because there's a great article in the latest edition of Foreign Affairs written by Helen Dixon saying regulate to liberate, can Europe save the internet? Can it?

ROSE: Well, so this is the great question. We tried to present a fair picture of this whole big debate. It's going forward on the future. So the lead piece in the package is by Adam Siegel talking about the transition of power from United States to China. Helen Dixon's article expresses the European approach which is no, it doesn't have to be the U.S. approach or the Chinese separate one, we can regulate it. Nandan Nilekani talks about the Indian one. We also have a number of different pieces on specific challenges of cyber security.

You should look at the European approach, the Chinese approach, the Indian approach and the American approach as variance of the same thing. Now that we've unleashed the wonderful creative destruction of digital technology, how do we keep it going forward in a positive way while controlling the social and political effects of all of this creative destruction?

LACQUA: Would these nations ever come together, Gideon? I don't know if whether it's a plaza accord for the internet. But, you know, that's the kind of idea.

ROSE: So, if people like John Ryding were controlling this stuff, then the answer would be yes because there's an obvious benefit for people to come together in a collective action coordination solution to read the benefits of a coordinated policy with central regulation.

But the problem is right now we have a tied international politics in the United States and elsewhere which is going inward rather than collective and I think the answer is we're moving towards a splinternet more than we are towards a new revelation.

KEENE: I love -- can we steal that words splinternet you get a royalty on that.

ROSE: It's not mine but it's a favorite --

(CROSSTALK)

KEENE: Here's the New York Times today folks, I'll read it for you. Russian hackers broaden the tax to consumers. First of all, I've got to make some news here with the counsel and foreign relations hack by Russians as well in this article?

ROSE: Like everybody else, we're constantly fished and attacked by various different actors. But that's just -- the Russians don't bother me as much. The Russians are like Butch Cassidy on the Sundance kid harassing the railroad.

KEENE: OK, who's the Katherine Losse (ph) of the World War Web? That's a Butch Cassidy.

ROSE: If the Chinese were going to be building a whole new railroad. So, we're worrying like E.H. Harriman in the Union percent (ph) of railroad about who's stealing our little -- we're worrying about who's stealing our safe. The Chinese are going around buying up the land and wanting them changed and developing engine technology 20 years from now, we're going to be running on Chinese trains and we're going to be wondering how did that happened.

KEENE: OK, then what is -- Francine's wonderful question about how do we get together on this, where is the unifying force particularly given the fractious politics our president's having with our allies?

ROSE: Karen Lornbluh and Michele Flournoy and Michael Somare have pieces in the article, in the package telling you what the United States should do and there are a lot of things.

Again, I would look to the Indian approach of the internet as a public good that may hold the best solution down the long road.

KEENE: Yes, but Tim Cook's stock options is not the public good.

ROSE: The question of the regulation of capitalism in a way that is beneficial economically, but also sustainable politically and socially is going to be that question of the mid 21st century.

LACQUA: Gideon, do you think any of these companies would self regulate for real?

ROSE: Yes, just like Martin Shkreli will self regulate.

LACQUA: It's respectively look?

ROSE: Yes, we can count on the tech companies to self regulate just like we can count on the pharmaceutical companies to provide low-cost medicines for everybody without regard to jacking up things when they have a cash monopoly like it ever been (ph).

LACQUA: All right, perfect. So, we do a little bit of, you know, that's a no. But why not? If you listen to the rationale of them regulating, it's either you regulate or you don't survive as people stop using you because you don't, you know, they don't trust. This -- they make money out of trusts, they don't make money out of selling drugs.

ROSE: Yes, in the long run. And in the short run, you make money by increasing your share of things, right. We have a president right now who is ignoring the entire cost of a global trade war to get some short term minor advantage in trivial little issues.

So, that kind of thinking if it can apply to the president of United States and the entire Republican Party, it also applies to individual private sector company managers. So we can't rely on them to be responsible for the entire global community down the road.

KEENE: Gideon, thank you so much. Your most important issue, I really mean this folks how dumb I am on our World War Web and I've to read it cover to cover. I can't say enough about it.

We're going to come back. John Ryding of RDQ Economics to dive once more into the independence of your selected central bank and then an important conversation with Gerard Cassidy on Fortress diamond, Fortress Moynihan in your neighborhood bank.

(BREAK)

KEENE: John Ryding with us with RDQ Economics and Gerard Cassidy joins from RBC Capital Markets and both of them have leaved every moment of this crisis. John, let me start with you as you go back and you look at where we are, can you say we're out of the crisis and it's a distant memory?

RYDING: We're out of the crisis and unfortunately it's a distant memory because by -- it become a distant memory, it's the way that some of the mistakes we make. But the difference between now and then is the degree of bank capital.

I think the system is much better buffered ad that's a positive. I think the unfortunate thing is in the re-regulation phase, some of the powers of the Fed intervened have been diminished sort of length of last resort which in the end is key when we get enterprises those -- some of those length of last resort facilities that powers been clipped.

But, yes, it's 10 years on, banks are well capitalized and this is when we make the mistakes that sow the seeds for the next problems.

KEENE: And Former Fed Official and Economist John Ryder, now we go to the trenches of securities analysis here. Do you agree that our banks are stronger and more resilient to the surprises that can come from 2006 and on to 2007?

GERARD CASSIDY, HEAD OF U.S. BANK EQUITY STRATEGY, RBC: Absolutely Tom, what we've seen the banking industry has been recapitalized quite romantically. We haven't seen levels of capital like this in decades.

I would also point out what the Federal Reserve did though was they pushed the risk outside the commercial banking system. It is now in the shadow of banking industry. That's where the risk lies.

So when the next crisis comes, we're not going to JPMorgan or Bank of America or Citigroup have the problems that they had last time. But I do worry about the hedge funds, the mutual funds, all the other outside, the traditional-commercial banking industry, those are the folks that could have the real problems.

LACQUA: John, where do you think the next crisis will come from? Is it going to be from Asia, is it going to be away from the financial sector?

RYDING: Well, I think in all things, the source of the crisis suppose to what the crisis is becomes financial policy, monetary policy that's too lose. I still think we have lax monetary policy that leads to over leverage, that leads to capital flow into asset classes that it shouldn't be.

But the system is being tested. What's happening in Turkey and the global ramifications, that's an interesting test because we thought emerging markets is one area that's going to be overleveraged. But, I don't see that so much as a systemic issue in the same way that (INAUDIBLE) turned out to be systemic issue back in 2010.

So, capital is an important buffer to hold back those crises. But raising interest rates is the best way to avoid getting into it.

KEENE: It's exceptionally time with John Ryding, thank you so much for being with us today. John Ryding on Fed independence, he's with RDQ economics. Coming up, a really important chart with Gerard Cassidy, we'll that next. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

KEENE: It's just a simple chart with Gerard Cassidy to look at here. And Gerard, what I want to talk about, forget about the Bull market like Fortress Diamond and maybe back here is a Harris and like here's a great malaise. How does any bank institution avoid a 15 year churn? What do you do to avoid that?

CASSIDY: Tom, I think that this is a phenomenal chart to have a go back as far as you have it and you do show the two great up legs. But there is that period that you point out this malaise. I think what it is, today, the banks are more focused than ever on shareholder return. During that malaise period, it was the recovery coming out of the 1990 downturn, but then you had the tech implosion in 2001. So those two periods affected the malaise that you identified.

KEENE: Who into -- your universe and even bank on the cover, I understand the game. Who is the one that uses technology best? Who's the technological leader in the Cassidy world?

CASSIDY: I would say that you have to identify probably our top banks, including bank of America and JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo. Citigroup I would put in there as well. So, our biggest banks are not only spending the most money, they are also becoming the most tech savvy. They're embracing it. They know the digitalization of banking is the future.

LACQUA: Gerard, are there concerns that actually some like Facebook or Amazon or someone else will go into banking?

CASSIDY: I would say that we don't really have to worry about that at this time. And the reason being there was a large moat around commercial banking. If you want to take the deposits and make loans, you have to have a banking license. I'm not -- I don't believe that Facebook, Google, or any of these companies want to become a bank holding company because you will be regulated by the bank regulators which would then lead to a much lower stock multiple. So right now, the moat is very difficult if impossible to cross.

CASSIDY: You know, it's interesting because the millenials are a very important part of the banking system and all the banks are trying to reach out with to them.

I was with U.S. bank core yesterday in Boston and it was very clear to me that this company is reaching out and through their payment system, to millennials because think of Venmo or Uber, that's the first introduction many of these millenials have to the banking system is through payments where many of us, Tom and I and folks first time we ever got in touch with the bank was with the passbook savings account. That's not the way in many of millenials do it anymore.

So, I would say the big banks JPMorgan and Bank of America, Regional Banks like PMC and U.S. bank are doing very good job reaching out to the millenials.

KEENE: Work very quickly here, when does branch banking finally throw in the towel? tail? I mean you go buy and nobody is them.

CASSIDY: Tom, it's amazing what's happening.

KEENE: It is amazing.

CASSIDY: It truly is. And we have some data to show you that the branch banking peak, the year the Apple introduced the iPhone. So, over the next ten years I would suggest to you but probably there was another third of the branches easily.

KEENE: A third, very good. Gerard Cassidy thank you so much and we'll continue this discussion. I'm thrilled to say with Mr. Ferro on Bloomberg Radio here in a moment.

urn:contentItem:60H4-92K1-DY1R-B4CK-00000-00Gigantes tecnológicas en el banquillo2020-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:03ZLexisNexisGigantes tecnológicas en el banquilloEl MercurioABSTRACT

No solo el factor competencia, sino también el control de datos y su impacto en la democracia son aristas del debate.

FULL TEXT


Un interesante debate se llevó a cabo esta semana en el Congreso de Estados Unidos, a raíz de presentaciones de los líderes de las cuatro principales empresas tecnológicas de ese país. La audiencia de las máximas autoridades de Google, Apple, Amazon y Facebook frente al Comité de Competencia de la Cámara de Representantes se da en el contexto de investigaciones acerca de cómo ellas -conocidas como las "Big Tech"- podrían estar desarrollando conductas anticompetitivas en los mercados.
La discusión acerca de estas empresas es consecuencia del tamaño que han alcanzado, así como de la naturaleza de sus negocios. Ellas basan su modelo en economías de red, donde el mayor alcance en términos de consumidores y proveedores favorece su posición competitiva, al tiempo que les permite desarrollar ventajas de costos. Esta tensión, presente en varias industrias, se observa con claridad en aquellas ligadas a la economía digital, en que el manejo de datos y el acceso a millones de clientes constituyen uno de los elementos diferenciadores más importantes frente a la competencia. Así, una vez alcanzada cierta escala, podrían tener un comportamiento monopólico.
El debate regulatorio en esta materia es creciente, pero todavía los académicos y los gobiernos están ideando estrategias óptimas. En parte, la dificultad se debe a que en este tipo de negocios el referido componente de economías de red es muy sustantivo, dificultando la coexistencia de alternativas. Por ello, el esfuerzo competitivo debe estar puesto en mantener viva la capacidad de desafiar a las empresas existentes, evitando la introducción de barreras a la entrada. Especial importancia tiene el manejo de datos: parte de su ventaja competitiva -y quizá el corazón de su modelo de negocios- radica en el acceso a miles de millones de datos y transacciones, que permite conocer el comportamiento de las personas y con ello ofrecer servicios atractivos.
Pero la dimensión de competencia no es el único aspecto a resaltar de la relación entre los gigantes tecnológicos, las personas y el Estado. Como muestra la presentación ante el Congreso, el manejo de los datos y la capacidad de afectar las comunicaciones y la democracia, los debates en torno a la censura y los aspectos geopolíticos que el poderío tecnológico conlleva son temas centrales. De hecho, una parte de la disputa entre China y Estados Unidos dice relación con la ventaja que el control de empresas tecnológicas y de datos provee.
La capacidad de censurar comunicaciones, influir en la información a la que tienen acceso las personas o distribuirla a los usuarios de acuerdo con criterios desconocidos son dimensiones que subyacen a su quehacer. Por ello, en lo venidero, tanto la discusión estrictamente competitiva como el dominio sobre la información y la opinión pública serán los aspectos decisivos en la dinámica de estas industrias.

urn:contentItem:5X29-7FN1-JD3N-51FF-00000-00Gig economy in crosshairs after growth era2019-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisWSJPg. 21Gig economy in crosshairs after growth eraEliot Brown

The tech backlash has come for the gig economy.

The California bill passed last week that threatens to make drivers for ride-hailing companies into employees rather than independent contractors is the latest move by regulators and courts around the globe that could curtail companies like Uber Technologies and Lyft and food-delivery businesses like DoorDash.

New York City earlier this year instituted a minimum wage for drivers of $US17.22 ($25.04) an hour after expenses, among other regulations, the first in the country. There are efforts in several countries in Europe to reclassify drivers as employees, including the UK, where an appeals court ruled in favour of employment status, pushing the final say to the top court.

Taken together, the moves show that a decade after companies like Uber rocketed to popularity by offering low-cost, on-demand services, governments are pushing back, demanding many of the same labour protections and other regulatory requ-irements the companies avoided in devising their business models.

When Uber and other gig-based companies like TaskRabbit started, consumers were initially delighted by the convenience and novelty. Their employment model - independent contractors aren't necessarily paid by the hour and don't have benefits like health insurance or unemployment insurance - helped the companies stay nimble and undercut incumbents like taxis that can be burdened by city pay regulations.

Workers could drop in and out as they liked. But as the services have grown and become ubiquitous, complaints have increased.

At the moment when Big Tech began losing its lustre in Washington, the novelty factor of the ride-hailing companies began to dissipate. Even as the services still enjoy broad popularity with consumers, constituent complaints in cities and states began piling up over some of their effects like congested streets and low driver pay.

"A lot of that shininess has worn off," said Meera Joshi, who headed the agency that regulates ride-hailing and taxis in New York City and oversaw the minimum-wage requirement for Uber and Lyft.

"You see the same identical recurring issues around the world - they're around congestion, driver pay environmental impact," she added. "In New York, a lot of this happened quicker." Given the growth of the sector - Lyft alone has said more than two million people drove for it at some point in 2018, or more than 1"per cent of the US workforce - other cities and states are expected to follow.

"California is not happening in a vacuum," said Bradley Tusk, a political consultant and venture capitalist whose Tusk Ventures was an early investor in Uber.

"The politics in state government right now is trending left," a problem for the companies given that Democrats have been pushing added labour regulations on tech, he said.

The moves threaten to add significant costs for the gig economy, which extends beyond Uber and Lyft to a host of delivery companies like DoorDash and Instacart, whose delivery bikes and cars now dot urban streets around the globe. Almost none of these companies is profitable, and Uber and Lyft in particular haven't identified clear paths to profitability.

Their stocks have struggled since their market debuts this spring. Uber has fallen nearly 25"per cent since its IPO, and Lyft is down around 35 per cent. Analysts at Morgan Stanley estimate Uber and Lyft's California driver costs could go up 35 per cent.

The companies have said that measures like California's aren't what most drivers want. Economics will force them to change their business models and decrease worker flexibility if drivers are classified as employees, they say.

Still, both companies say they will continue to work with governments. A Lyft spokesman said the company has long "worked with regulators to find solutions that benefit drivers and riders and support innovation".

Uber, Lyft and other firms including DoorDash are still pushing for a deal that would exempt them - one in which they would offer concessions like a benefits fund and a measure that gives drivers the ability to collectively negotiate with several employers.Should that fail, they plan to look to voters. The three companies promised earlier this month to spend at least $US90 million combined to fund a ballot initiative to reverse the effects of the bill.

urn:contentItem:5Y7B-0FN1-F11P-X4NN-00000-00Gilead Sciences Stock at Cusp of New Uptrend2020-02-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisGilead Sciences Stock at Cusp of New Uptrend

Gilead Sciences, Inc. (GILD), the third largest biotechnology stock on the U.S. exchanges, may have completed a multi-year bottoming pattern, setting the stage for an uptrend that could reach the lofty heights posted in the middle of the last decade. That's good news for long-suffering shareholders as well as blue-chip biotech investors who have watched their portfolios underperform broad benchmarks in recent years.

Similar stories are playing out across the market landscape, with iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology Index Fund ETF (IBB) now perfectly positioned to mount 2019 resistance and head toward the all-time high posted in July 2015. This is unexpected, to say the least, in an election year that will shine an unfavorable spotlight on the pharmaceutical industry and its pricing practices. It's entirely possible that investors are already looking past November, expecting a second Trump administration to back away from new regulations.

Gilead Sciences came public at a split-adjusted 69 cents in 1992 and entered a downtrend that posted an all-time low at 20 cents in 1994. The subsequent uptick reached a new high in 1995, underpinning an uptrend that eased into a rising channel in 1999. The rally was unaffected when the internet bubble broke one year later, continuing to post steady gains within the channel into July 2008, when it topped out at in the upper $20s.

The stock posted a 38% decline during the economic collapse but failed to bounce into the new decade, unlike the majority of the recovering stock universe. It broke the 2008 low in 2010, finding support in the mid-teens, and tested that level successfully 13 months later. This bullish action completed a double bottom reversal, establishing an uptrend that attracted intense momentum buying interest in 2013.

The rally posted exceptional gains into the end of 2014, topping out at $117 and failing a breakout attempt above that level in 2015. Aggressive bears then took control, carving a decline that cut the stock's price in half into the 2017 low at $63.76. The subsequent bounce failed in early 2018, yielding a final sell-off that undercut the 2017 low in December. The stock has been testing that level for more than a year while the long-term pattern has carved a massive double bottom.

Price action reached 50-month exponential moving average (EMA) resistance for the first time since October 2018 last week, triggering a reversal, but an uptick in buying volume suggests a successful assault on this barrier in coming weeks. That event would set off preliminary buying signals, but it could be months or longer before the stock catches the undivided attention of Wall Street analysts and investors now chasing FAANG and other big tech stocks.

The on-balance volume (OBV) accumulation-distribution indicator entered an accumulation phase in June 2017 and just reached the level posted when the stock topped out in 2014. This volume activity is generating a major bullish divergence, predicting that price will play catch-up in coming months. An OBV uptick above the red line would be especially bullish, indicating that institutions are quietly loading up on shares in anticipation of higher prices.

The rally into February mounted the 200-day EMA between $65 and $66, marking a price level that needs to be held at all costs because the stock has failed the past seven attempts to clear this barrier. As a result, there's considerable risk in buying the current pullback, but a bounce that exceeds the Feb. 7 high at $71 should generate rapid upside into the October 2018 high near $80 and finally lift the slumping monthly stochastic oscillator into a sustained buy cycle.

The Bottom Line

Chronic laggard Gilead Sciences may enter a new uptrend in coming months, catching the majority of market players by surprise. 2020 Global Data Point.
