urn:contentItem:5WFD-G2J1-JCBJ-K3J8-00000-00GILTI: "MADE IN AMERICA" FOR EUROPEAN TAX UNILATERAL MEASURES & COOPERATIVE SURPLUS IN THE INTERNATIONAL TAX COMPETITION GAME.(global intangible low taxed income)2019-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:54:04ZLexisNexisPg. 271GILTI: "MADE IN AMERICA" FOR EUROPEAN TAX UNILATERAL MEASURES & COOPERATIVE SURPLUS IN THE INTERNATIONAL TAX COMPETITION GAME.(global intangible low taxed income)Better, G. Charles

I. INTRODUCTION 272 II. A STATESIDE VIEW: GILTI'S ORIGINS & RELIANCE ON "INTANGIBLES"AS EXCESS PROFITS 278 A. Origins of US Taxation of Excess Profits (G1LT1) 278 B. GILTI 281 C. The Intangible Economics Behind GILTI 284 D. Excess Profits 288 290 III. EU/OECD MEASURES TO "COMBAT" TAX COMPETITION 293 IV. INTERNATIONAL TAX COMPETITION: NATIONAL WELFARE & UNILATERAL INCENTIVES 299 V. THE TAXMAN'S DILEMMA: US UNILATERAL ACTION AND COOPERATIVE SURPLUS 306 VI CONCLUSION 312

I. INTRODUCTION

The "Tax Cuts and Jobs Act's" (TCJA) international provisions have been a source of confusion and criticism in both the United States and in Europe. Early reactions to the law and its international provisions have highlighted technical issues, (1) potential violations of international agreements, (2) and purported adverse effects. (3) The tax policy debate on the merits of TCJA and its international provisions has just begun. At the same time, U.S. political discourse regarding international taxation has shifted from debating the merits of the TCJA to defending U.S. firms against the threat of unilateral "digital" taxation. (4) In Europe, the TCJA is increasingly a source of inspiration and consternation as countries grapple with how to reform international tax rules for a digital age. (5)

Many EU member states have expressed heightened interest in international taxation through the prism of "digital" taxation. (6) While the OECD's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project is wrapping up, BEPS's capstone "Digital Economy" action item remains a final initiative. (7) Current OECD and EU responses to the "digital" economy in BEPS and through unilateral measures mark the culmination of an almost decade long effort to plug loopholes in international tax regimes designed for a pre-digital age. (8) But will multilateral action on "digital" taxation come quickly enough? Some countries such as the United Kingdom and France seem unwilling to wait for multilateral action, unleashing a political and tax policy maelstrom befitting the digital age. (9)

Confronting the current upheaval in international tax policy, how does the TCJA's Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income (GILTI) provision--a global minimum tax on excess profits--fit into the larger debate about international tax avoidance, "harmful" tax competition, and taxation of the "digital" economy? (10) Far from rolling in a U.S. Trojan horse, GILTI offers developed resident economies (particularly EU member states) a critical tax instrument to combat base erosion and profit shifting to low-tax jurisdictions. (11) As a residence-based global minimum tax, GILTI is a tax tool "Made in America" for European tax.

GILTI does for profit shifting and base erosion what FATCA did for financial information exchange and tax evasion. (12) GILTI provides a globally significant baseline around which other countries can implement defensive tax measures for resident firms. The OECD and EU might bemoan GILTI's unilateral character. (13) But behind the boogeyman of arrogant American unilateralism, GILTI stands out as a critical tax tool for countries wishing to foster beneficial competition on productive economic factors and efficiencies. (14) Notwithstanding empty ideological appeals to multilateralism from multinational bodies like the OECD, global cooperation is not inherently in tension with unilateral sovereign conduct. (15) As with FATCA, the "Made in America" medicine might be distasteful to EU member states inclined towards multilateral efforts built on consensus building. Yet the United States' ability to facilitate cooperative multi-state action through a unilateral strategy with cooperative potential is precisely what gives GILTI its potency. (16) For countries seeking to protect and recoup government subsidies for innovation, GILTI's medicine is far superior to the disease of veiled and ineffectual multilateralism on display in BEPS' empty attempts to "combat" harmful tax competition. (17)

Rather than perpetuate trans-Atlantic hostilities while Europe and the OECD consider the "digital" economy, the U.S. tax and business communities must explain how GILTI promotes beneficial competition on productive economic factors, discourages base erosion and profit shifting by U.S. multinationals (MNEs), and provides cover for other countries to modernize international tax rules consistent with longstanding principles of tax territoriality. (18) Political developments in the European Union and OECD suggest that EU member states need not feel guilty about leveraging a GILTI-esque minimum tax tool to combat the challenging issues facing international taxation in the digital age. (19) Indeed, Germany and France have proposed a GILTI-esque minimum tax as part of a multilateral OECD proposal to confront challenges in taxing the "digital economy"--"a kind of BEPS 2.0" that utilizes U.S. unilateral action to facilitate international cooperation in combatting tax avoidance. (20)

At the heart of the controversy over GILTI, "Digital Taxation," and the larger BEPS project is a debate about the propriety and benefits of tax competition. While tax competition is a controversial concept among economists and tax lawyers, (21) recent scholarship provides a framework to talk productively about tax competition. (22) This paper draws on the theory of tax competition and language of international tax neutrality to argue that international tax policy must be viewed through the lens of "national welfare" when considering strategic incentives and, thus, positive predictions about nation state behavior in the international tax competition game. Viewing tax competition and GILTI's global minimum tax through the prism of game theory yields important insights into the potential of unilateral U.S. action to alleviate global collective action problems.

An important question in evaluating GILTI is whether it enables potential cooperative behavior among developed economies through signaling and minimum standards by a sovereign with "pricing" power to set global rate and base terms for MNEs. In short, is GILTI a harmful unilateral measure that undermines cooperative efforts in the OECD and EU? Or, is GILTI like FATCA-a veiled if unsolicited gift for developed economies? This paper answers these questions and highlights the potential of a global minimum tax on excess profits to promote international tax reform in a digitized economy while retaining foundational principles of tax sovereignty.

Part II introduces GILTI and the origins of the TCJA's shift to current taxation of excess profits; it also defends GILTI's reliance on intangibles to define excess profits. Part III introduces the EU and OECD's efforts to combat base erosion and profit shifting through multilateral initiatives--like BEPS--as well as the debate about "digital taxation." Part IV introduces theories of tax competition and international tax neutrality benchmarks to establish "national welfare" as the appropriate descriptive and normative framework for evaluating international tax policy within a multi-sovereign tax competition game. Part V applies game theory to the tax competition and "digital taxation" debates to show how GILTI's resident based global minimum tax liberates developed economies to compete on productive factors and combat base erosion and profit shifting.

II. A STATESIDE VIEW: GILTI'S ORIGINS & RELIANCE ON "INTANGIBLES" AS EXCESS PROFITS

A. Origins of U.S. Taxation of Excess Profits (GILTI)

The TCJA moved the U.S. international tax systems away from a worldwide regime with limited foreign credits and unlimited deferral of foreign income to a territorial regime with current taxation of excess profits. The U.S. system has always operated along a worldwide/territorial spectrum. The "hybrid" character of the U.S. system (exemption with defensive measures or worldwide taxation with deferral and limited crediting) makes it hard to categorize per se, but in general, the TCJA moved the United States closer to the dominant territorial approach taken by OECD nations. (23) From the perspective of global structural harmonization in international taxation, the U.S. move towards territoriality marks some improvement over prior U.S. law. The United States is unique, however, among OECD countries in adopting a worldwide minimum tax on resident shareholders' excess profits.

The TCJA introduced a minimum tax on foreign derived excess profits (GILTI). (24) Pun surely intended, GILTI is the U.S. resident shareholder global minimum tax on foreign derived excess profits. The ideas of eliminating foreign income deferral and taxing excess profits through a global minimum tax are not new to U.S. tax policy. A resident-based global minimum or excess profits tax was present in proposals from former House Ways and Means Chairman David Camp almost a decade ago. (25) Around the same time, President Obama's corporate tax reform proposals recommended "treat[ing] as IP income any income that reflects an 'excess return.'" (26) Indeed, a major theme of President Obama's international tax reform proposal was ending deferral of foreign income and targeting excess profits earned through income shifting to foreign low-tax jurisdictions. (27) One proposal from Chairman Camp even suggested "combining current U.S. taxation of any CFC's foreign IP income taxed at a foreign effective tax rate less than 13.5% with a patent box at a 15% rate for all foreign intangible income of a domestic corporation (including royalties)." (28) Sound familiar? Utilizing a metaphor used to describe the GILTI/FDII regime, Chairman Camp "describe[ed] th[is] alternative as combining 'the carrot of an 'innovation box' and royalty relief with the 'stick' of a current... inclusion for intangibles-related income of CFCs in low-tax jurisdictions.'" (29)

Notwithstanding the rushed and opaque legislative process that defined the TCJA, GILTI is not a novel creature from the tax policy lagoon. (30) In fact, GILTI is consistent with prior U.S. reform proposals from across the political spectrum. (31) As one commentator quipped,

"there are no new ideas in either fashion or taxation." (32) The TCJA's international provisions drew on existing reform proposals for good reason--a global minimum tax was central to prior bipartisan international tax reform proposals. As President Obama argued in 2012 "no American company should be able to avoid paying its fair share of taxes by moving jobs and profits overseas... from now on, every multinational company should have to pay a basic minimum tax." (33)

A global minimum tax allows sovereigns to recapture resident benefits that enable domestic firms to exploit excess returns in foreign markets. (34) Apple's profits on its newest iPhone are attributable in part to the foreign markets in which the iPhone is manufactured as well as the final location of sale. (35) But as Apple advertises, Apple products are "Designed by Apple in California." (36) In its branding, Apple proudly recognizes the legal, human, and physical infrastructure in California and the United States that allow initial designs and engineering "in California" to produce spectacular excess profits around the world. (37) While global profits are properly allocable to an array of jurisdictions based on traditional principles of transferpricing, excess profits belong in the host country that enables "design" and innovation through subsidies and direct investment in productive economic factors. Ultimately, resident country sharing in resident firm foreign excess profits promotes beneficial competition among resident economies around productive factors with potential global spillover benefits to non-resident economies.

B. G1LTI

Global Intangible Low Tax Income (GILTI) is certain income that must be included in the gross income of a U.S. shareholder in a

Controlled Foreign Corporation (CFC). (38) GILTI is subject to a minimum tax on income that exceeds a presumed "normal" ten percent rate of return. GILTI is thus generally subject to a 10.5 percent minimum U.S. tax for income derived from a CFC. Depending on foreign source rates, a limited foreign tax credit renders a variable rate on GILTI from 10.5 to 13.125 percent. (39) Nominally, GILTI applies to "intangible" income. By statute, however, intangible income is not in fact income from accounting intangibles. Instead, "intangible" income for GILTI purposes is income in excess of a deemed "normal" rate of return.

A U.S. shareholder in a CFC must annually calculate her GILTI. (40) The GILTI income base is the excess of "net CFC tested income" over a "net deemed tangible income return." (41) To calculate "net CFC tested income," a U.S. shareholder calculates the excess of (1) the aggregate of her pro rata shares of all her CFCs' "tested income" over (2) the aggregate of her pro rata share of all CFC's "tested losses." (42) Basically, "tested income" is net income not already subject to U.S. tax and "tested losses" is excess allocable income. (43) "Net deemed tangible income return" is the excess of (1) 10% of the aggregate of U.S. shareholder pro rata share of "qualified business asset investment" (QBAI) of every CFC, over (2) certain interest deducted in arriving at "tested income." (44) QBAI is based on an average (over four quarters) of the CFCs aggregate adjusted basis in 'specified tangible property' that could be depreciable and is used in trade or business of the CFC. (45)

Specified tangible property is tangible property used to generate tested income. (46)

If you skipped the prior paragraph, don't feel GILTI. The rule is technically complex. The intuition and objective, however, are simple. GILTI implements a minimum tax on the foreign profits of U.S. CFCs in excess of a deemed "normal" return. Because the GILTI base is calculated in relation to 'tangible' specific property, the net GILTI income reflects excess profits in relation to the tangible property used to generate that income. A ten percent rate might seem arbitrary. Some have argued that the deemed 'normal' (ten percent) rate reflects legitimate expectations for returns on tangible investment and, thus, that excess profit is properly attributable to exploitation of intangibles. (47) At the same time, a presumed ten percent rate might not account for high-risk/high-return ventures like pharmaceutical development, which often produces outsized returns in particular years while cross-subsidizing non-profitable but socially beneficial investments. (48) As a tax policy tool, GILTI's deemed rate of return carries the common benefits and drawbacks of a blunt rule. The most obvious benefit is the simplicity of a bright line rule to combat profit shifting. The most obvious drawback is GILTI's potential to incentivize U.S. firms to locate tangible investments in low-tax jurisdictions to soak up low foreign tax rates.

Once a U.S. firm's GILTI income is determined, additional U.S. tax is attributed to the foreign CFC. (49) If a U.S. shareholder has a GILTI inclusion, it can receive a limited foreign tax credit (FTC) equal to eighty percent that applies to its "inclusion percentage" times its "tested foreign income taxes." (50) Basically, the U.S. shareholder receives eighty percent of the foreign tax paid by the CFC reduced by the ratio of excess profits. If a firm has a high ratio of tested income to its tangible asset base (QBAI), the FTC will be reduced in proportion to that amount. Only U.S. domestic corporations are eligible for an FTC on GILTI income. (51)

C. The Intangible Economics Behind GILTI

"America's economy is shifting further towards intangibles" is the cogent proclamation of The Economist. (52) GILTI relies on a concept of intangibles broadly defined. In contrast to the relatively narrow accounting concept of intangibles, GILTI is predicated on a presumptive "normal" (ten percent) rate of return. (53) In reality, GILTI's "intangibles" taxation is thus taxation of "excess profits." In economic terminology "excess profits" is synonymous with "rents"--profits above the rate of return necessary to justify an investment under corporate finance theory. (54) In theory, excess profits in maturing market economies might be expected to result from investment in intangibles. For example, the marginal profitability of foreign investment is limited for many commodity products as global labor and input prices equalize. (55) If firms seek profits in excess of normal rates of return, they need to build a better mousetrap--or better mousetrap production process. Intangibles, in the form of supply chain efficiencies, technical know-how (firm knowledge), and intellectual property are the inputs that allow firms to build a better mouse trap and, thus, earn excess profits at home and abroad. To appreciate the "intangibles" twist in GILTI, it is, therefore, essential to understand the rise of an intangibles economy in the developed world. (56)

Aspects of modern developed economies are sometimes referred to as the "digital" economy. (57) Despite the popular emphasis on the digital aspects of modern economic development, the centrality of intangibles extends well beyond digitization and information technology. In fact, intangibles are at the heart of productivity and profits in a wide variety of "traditional" economic sectors, including manufacturing. (58) Nevertheless, investment in intangibles is underreported and underappreciated because intangibles investment is frequently recognized as an operating expenditure rather than capital investment. (59) Off the balance sheet, computers and the internet are just the tip of the intangibles iceberg. (60) Moreover, the shift from tangible to intangible investment "isn't primarily about information technology." (61) A myopic focus on the "digital" economy, thus, misses the significance of intangibles investment to productivity and profitability across an array of sectors in developed economies. (62) Tax policy must take notice of these developments because intangibles are at the core of global excess profits.

Economists Jonathan Haskel and Stian Westlake provide a typology to categorize the intangibles economy. (63) Intangible investment consists of: 1) economic competencies; 2) innovative property; and 3) computerized information. "Computerized information" is the most familiar. (64) Software and database development are two dominant areas. "Big Data," "Data Analytics," and the "Cloud" are further variants of "computerized information" and what is often colloquy understood as the "digital economy." "Innovative property" is a second category that consists of activities directed at information discovery or creative production, e.g. research and development, artistic composition, design and other product development. Both "computerized information" and "innovative property" are protected under traditional intellectual property law, i.e. patent, copyright, and trademark. The final category, "economic competencies," consists of firm specific training, market research, branding, and organizational capital, such as business process knowledge. "Economic competencies" are sometimes protected under intellectual property law as trade secrets. (65) On a firm balance sheet, economic competencies are recognized as "goodwill" since they represent a residual between the net asset value and firm enterprise value. As the above categories reflect, information technology is just one among varied forms of intangible investment.

A narrow focus on information technology as the lynchpin of modern economic growth misses the wide array of sectors that exploit intangibles to realize excess profits in the global economy. (66) Simply put, there is more to the "digital" economy than computers and data. EU member states such as Germany seem to realize as much. (67) Absent, however, from the EU debate about "digital taxation" is a full appreciation for how the "intangibles" economy extends well beyond information technology/ (18) European policymakers must look beyond the hype of "Big Tech" and "Big Data" to the real factors driving productivity and profitability in the EU and around the globe. (69)

Accordingly, EU and OECD efforts to revitalize tax tools for the modern economy should orient themselves around a broad GILTI conception of intangibles as excess profits in order to share in revenues from resident firm exploitation of foreign markets. (70) Just as the iPhone is "Designed in California," there are products designed in Milan, Munich, and Manchester that depend on resident EU member state subsidies offered with respect to productive factors like education, legal, and physical infrastructure. EU member states must remember the centrality of intangibles to excess profits as they transition from "targeting" digital taxation to shaping sustainable and productive rules of international taxation in an increasingly intangibles driven global economy.

D. Excess Profits

To evaluate GILTI's taxation of excess profits through a broad conception of intangibles, the link between economic intangibles and excess profits must be established. The following analysis defends "excess profits" as an object of international taxation, discusses the comparative costs and benefits of traditional innovation incentives, and concludes with an overview of the international tax competition landscape for innovation incentives.

Taxing profits is efficient because "pure profits are worth claiming even when reduced by a tax bill." (71) Rents in excess of normal returns are economic surplus. Like normal profits, this surplus is shared between a firm and its resident government based on the relative market power of the firm and its resident government to set and adhere to base and rate terms. A resident sovereign's taxing power is limited most fundamentally by the threat of exit: the ability of a firm to change its residence through inversion or reincorporation. (72) Viewed independently, taxation of excess profits might be seen as a disincentive to resident firms since GILTI like taxes increase the resident sovereign's potential share of resident firm excess profits. But when an excess profits tax like GILTI enables a regime of partial exemption (territoriality), the net effect can be to increase the attractiveness of domestic corporate residency. To start with, excess profits taxation can provide countries revenue to pay for resident-based tax subsidies. Moreover, GILTI only kicks in when foreign income is subject to a low foreign source rate.

It is important to distinguish "normal" returns from excess returns in evaluating the importance of competitiveness to resident firms in foreign markets. (73) If a tax system, such as worldwide taxation without full crediting of foreign source taxes prevents U.S. firms from competing for investment in foreign opportunities for normal returns (because the U.S. after-tax rate of return exceeds the after-tax rate of foreign producers), the U.S. firm has foregone an opportunity for 'normal' returns that can be achieved elsewhere. (74) Excess profits above a 'normal' rate present a different story. (75) A U.S. tax system that prevented U.S. firms from competing in foreign markets for excess returns would reduce national welfare understood as a combination of U.S. tax revenue and profits attributable to U.S. shareholders. If a U.S. firm loses out to a foreign firm in realizing an opportunity for excess profits abroad, the economic surplus is not realized by a U.S. person and is, thus, unavailable for sharing between the firm and sovereign.

The opportunity cost of missing out on foreign excess returns is a strong justification in moving to a more territorial international income tax. Whether conceptualized as the taxation of excess profits or a global minimum tax, GILTI allows the United States to capture part of the benefits to U.S. firms of exploiting foreign opportunities for excess profits. Taxation of excess profits is, thus, a mechanism for sharing in resident firms' exploitation of foreign excess profits while also enabling resident firms to realize foreign profit opportunities through a shift to partial exemption of foreign profits above a minimum tax rate. Last but not least, a resident-based global minimum tax allows resident sovereigns to recapture subsidies conferred on resident firms and, thus, fund future productivity enhancing benefits afforded to resident firms.

E. Traditional Intangible/Innovation Incentives

GILTI enables resident tax benefits and neutralizes some of the appeal of the foreign-source locational incentives available as traditional "innovation" incentives. While GILTI is not itself a locational incentive, its general applicability to resident shareholders has an indirect effect on the comparative tax benefit of foreign and domestic innovation subsidies. Because GILTI is a minimum tax on foreign source income, the comparative economic value of domestic and foreign subsidies varies depending on whether a foreign subsidy triggers GILTI income. Consequently, the incentive effects of GILTI's minimum tax must be viewed within the larger global tax benefit marketplace for mobile "innovation" income and investment. Innovation incentives in the U.S. and EU generally take three forms: 1) tax benefits (credit/deduction) for research and development (R&D); 2) manufacturing incentives, and 3) tax benefits for IP source income (patent boxes) (discussed in Part III). (76)

The TCJA did not disturb the U.S. R&D incentive. (77) Since GILTI applies to foreign source income, the R&D credit is not impacted directly by GILTI. However, since GILTI has the potential to lessen the comparative benefit of foreign innovation incentives, e.g. foreign patent boxes, GILTI might increase the incentive for U.S. domestic companies to engage in domestic R&D. (78) A major limitation of the U.S. R&D credit is that it is not refundable. (79) Despite this potential weakness, the TCJA preserved a defensible locational innovation incentive in the U.S. R&D Credit, (80) and further increased the marginal benefit of U.S. R&D for domestic firms. (81)

Locational incentives sometimes take the form of manufacturing subsidies. (82) While modern economic terminology (and tax policy) often relies on a rigid dichotomy between "traditional" and "innovative" technologies, the reality is more complex. (83) Many global production efficiencies rely on complex supply-chains and organizational knowledge. (84) While intangibles are important to manufacturing, the case for direct locational incentives for "advanced" manufacturing is less clear cut. (85) One justification for manufacturing incentives is tax competition--the need to attract and maintain manufacturing activities. (86) Despite general political support for such measures, as a matter of tax policy, manufacturing-specific economic incentives are not generally believed to be economically efficient. (87) Set against the international tax competition landscape, the argument for U.S. manufacturing incentives is even weaker because locational incentives are limited under the Treaty for the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). (88)

EU member states have resorted to second-best policy tools like patent boxes in part because of EU law limitations on locational incentives. (89) In the face of limitations on locational incentives, EU member states have adopted sub-optimal tax incentives like patent boxes. Instead of encouraging productive factor competition--a significant goal behind limitations on locational benefits--patent box regimes further exacerbate base erosion and profit shifting. A tax incentive purported to increase "innovation" activity in fact undermines competition by European countries to offer an optimal package of productive factors.

III. EU/OECD MEASURES TO "COMBAT" TAX COMPETITION

Unilateral U.S. measures such as GILTI can mitigate collective action problems that multilateral initiatives fail to resolve. An essential premise of this thesis is that multilateralism is not working--at least not on certain international tax issues. This section diagnoses the problem of failed multilateralism through a description of the BEPS initiative on "harmful" tax competition. As part of that discussion, patent boxes, the predominate European incentive for "intangible incentives" are introduced to frame the incentives and strategies of nation states in the international tax competition game simulated in Part V.

The OECD's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project represents an effort to combat tax avoidance through multilateral agreement on general rules of international taxation. (90) The backbone principle of the BEPS project is to foster a locational nexus in international taxation. Under the locational nexus principle, taxation of profits is aligned with the location of real economic activity. Despite the declared success of BEPS, a review of Action Item 5 shows that some purported BEPS successes depend on prior unilateral initiatives more than the multilateral BEPS process itself. Moreover, EU law limitations have prevented the OECD from fully endorsing a standard consistent with its preferred tax policy principle. The failures exhibited in BEPS Action Item 5 provide evidence consistent with game theoretical predictions about the challenges of multilateral action when there are dominant incentives to defect from cooperation.

BEPS Action Item 5 ("Action 5") produced three major outputs under its self-identified principles of coherence, substance, and transparency. (91) On substance, Action 5 implements a substantial activity requirement through a "nexus" principle for qualifying income under a preferential tax regime. On transparency, Action 5 implements compulsory exchange of information for all rulings that could give rise to base erosion or profit shifting concerns. On coherence, Action 5 reviewed all extant OECD preferential regimes and required modification and future compliance with the new BEPS "substantial activity" standard. Although the inquiry into "Harmful Tax Practices" (Action 5), focused on three principles (substance, transparency, and coherence), it yielded one major yet counterintuitive output: a formula for designing an OECD compliant patent box. (92)

A patent box is a back-end preferential tax regime for intellectual property (IP) related income. (93) Patent boxes are sometimes referred to as "innovation boxes" since they are often open to IP beyond patents. Patent boxes are a controversial tax incentive and form of tax competition because they tend to promote base erosion and profit shifting of mobile IP income. (94) In contrast to front-end R&D incentives, which provide tax benefits when expenses are incurred, patent boxes reduce the tax liability for earned income from qualifying IP. (95) In principle, both front-end and back-end regimes can incentivize the location of real economic activity, but the efficacy of any tax benefit regime depends on its ability to prevent strategic taxpayer behavior. Defenders of patent box regimes claim that they incentivize development of productive industry through prospective investment in research and development of intangibles. Despite this justification, absent locational limitations on qualifying income, patent boxes can also promote "harmful" base erosion and profit shifting. (96) In theory, therefore, patent boxes might easily constitute harmful tax competition and should be limited by anti-abuse rules that confine the strategic attribution of income to patent box jurisdictions or the transfer of IP to patent box regimes after receipt of front-end tax subsidies in another jurisdiction. On the surface, BEPS purported to limit patent boxes consistent with its overarching principle of "locational" nexus--a belief that tax rights should align with the location of economic activity. In practice, however, BEPS endorsed a watered-down limitation on patent boxes that effectively provided a compliance manual for designing an OECD sanctioned preferential tax regime.

BEPS Action Item 5 endorses a "substantial activity" standard through a "nexus" approach to qualifying income for tax benefits under preferential tax regimes. (97) "Substantial nexus" qualifies income in a patent box according to expenditures by a single entity located in the patent box jurisdiction. (98) The "nexus" ratio is determined by qualifying expenditures, which serve as a proxy for real economic activity in the patent box jurisdiction. (99) A subtle but significant element of the "substantial nexus" standard is that it permits two differing standards for defining qualifying expenditures. (100) Because of EU law limitations on locational benefits, the predominate standard looks to the location of the single entity incurring expenditures. (101) The alternative standard, acceptable for countries not subject to EU law or similar limitations on locational benefits, allows qualifying expenditures to be calculated based on the jurisdiction (i.e. location) of activities related to the expenditure. (102) In what some have deemed the "Luxembourg Effect," EU law limitations thus resulted in a suboptimal global minimum standard. (103) While BEPS purported to implement a "better" global standard through multilateral consensus, it instead provided a sub-optimal rule (considering tax competition effects) necessitated by the domestic law limitations of leading members of the OECD's multilateral body.

At the heart of the BEPS debate about the "substantial nexus" standard was a political divide among OECD member states concerning the "harmful" effects of patent boxes. (104) Not surprisingly, whether a given incentive is "harmful" often rests in the eye of the beholder. Countries that offer low-tax incentives for IP through "patent boxes" do not find these regimes "harmful" (or at least they hope they're not). In contracts, countries with resident firms that might shift income or R&D spending to low-tax countries offering incentives correctly perceive patent boxes as harmful. Consistent with these conflicting, if simultaneously accurate, perspectives on "harmful" tax competition, Germany, a country without a patent box, led a coalition in the OECD to limit patent boxes. (105) The German coalition was opposed by a coalition led by the U.K., which itself promotes a patent box. In the end, horse trading produced a "modified" "substantial nexus" standard that represents as much a political compromise within the EU on tax competition as a bona fide reform of international tax standards. (106) At least with respect to preferential regimes, it's hard to argue Action 5 represents any reform at all. Instead of scrapping a primary vehicle for base erosion and profit shifting, Action 5 exacerbates the professed illness by prescribing a compliance manual for OECD approved patent box incentives.

Action 5 represents a failed multilateral effort to combat base erosion and profit shifting. Instead of producing a superior global standard through multilateral negotiation and consensus, the OECD settled on a sub-optimal rule motivated in part by EU law limitations. The political backstory to the modified nexus standard further exposes the veiled multilateralism of certain aspects of the BEPS project. Behind the shroud of multinational collaboration, two national power players (U.K. and Germany) negotiated a truce that received an institutional stamp of multilateralism from the OECD. Is institutional OECD approval not ultimately a signal multinational consensus? No, it is not! Cooperative behavior does not necessarily imply actual benefit to cooperating parties. (107)

The failure of a single multilateral effort does not necessarily doom the multilateral process in international tax. Indeed, the transparency prong of Action 5 has been lauded as a success story for multilateralism. (108) In contrast to efforts at reforming preferential tax regimes, the tax competition landscape for bank secrecy (and thus exchange of financial information) had undergone a monumental shift prior to the BEPS project. Viewed historically, however, even the purported multilateral success of Action 5's transparency initiatives depended on prior unilateral U.S. measures regarding compulsory exchange of information for global financial institutions.

The Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is U.S. domestic legislation that requires the exchange of banking information from financial institutions that operate within the U.S. banking system that relates to foreign account ownership. FATCA is a unilateral U.S. measure aimed at combatting a problem plagued by collective inaction--tax evasion through abuse of bank secrecy and non-exchange of taxpayer information by non-resident financial institutions. While FATCA is unilateral in form, it proved multilateral in effect, precipitating bilateral and multilateral efforts to combat illegal tax evasion. (109) While EU politicians and banks initially reacted with outrage over FATCA's unilateral approach and purportedly "extraterritorial" requirements, European leaders ultimately came to appreciate that FATCA provided a "unique opportunity to move from a series of bilateral agreements to multilateral agreements" on exchange of taxpayer information. (110) FATCA provided European countries cover to negotiate a multilateral agreement in an area plagued by ineffectual bilateral measures. (111) As the FATCA backstory elucidates, multilateral efforts on information exchange had crystalized before BEPS started, much less delivered on, its Action 5 outputs. As this timeline suggests, BEPS' transparency related "reforms" largely incorporated prior EU multilateral initiatives made possible because of, not in spite of, U.S. unilateral action. (112)

The cooperative potential of a unilateral measure like FATCA does not undermine the importance of subsequent multilateral agreement. With GILTI, it remains to be seen whether other resident countries will recognize the cooperative potential afforded by GILTI and implement similar forms of minimum resident taxation of foreign source benefits. What the FATCA history makes clear, however, is that the multilateral process itself did not precipitate the global tax policy success on compulsory exchange of financial information. Instead, the FATCA backstory to BEPS suggests that subsequent multilateral agreement and cooperation was enabled by prior U.S. unilateral measures. GILTI offers a similar opportunity for second stage cooperative action. (113)

IV. INTERNATIONAL TAX COMPETITION: NATIONAL WELFARE & UNILATERAL INCENTIVES

Traditional normative principles of international tax policy rest on assumptions about global welfare based in neo-classical trade theory.' (14) In contrast to the cooperative surplus available under international trade theory, in which national welfare is maximized through elimination of barriers to trade with shared gains from comparative advantage, the international tax arena is defined in part by adversity. (115) Adversity need not imply hostility as an adverse game can be resolved through strategic cooperation.

International tax policy is often evaluated under competing norms of capital export neutrality (CEN), capital import neutrality (CIN) (a.k.a. "savings neutrality"), capital ownership neutrality (CON), national neutrality (NN), and national ownership neutrality (NON). (116) In domestic tax policy, an ideal point is posited at some intersection of the competing norms of efficiency and equity. In international tax policy, an ideal point might also reside at some intersection of these various neutrality norms. The challenge in both the domestic and international contexts is to identify that ideal point. For a variety of reasons, there is no prevailing consensus. (117) Moreover, as in the domestic context, attempts to maximize a single norm might create double-distortions that offset the benefits of maximizing any one of the preferred CxN neutrality benchmarks. (118)

The principle flaw in the international tax policy neutrality framework is that it is predicated on maximizing global welfare. The players (national sovereigns) in the international tax competition game are not interested in global welfare. Nation state policymakers (the tax competition players) are responsive to the welfare of their national constituencies. (119) Because global welfare is not an accurate description of the strategic incentives of tax policymakers, it is not very helpful in analyzing the constraints and objectives of national policymakers in crafting international tax rules in a policy landscape subject to tax competition. (120) Rejecting the "global welfare" premise of the neutrality benchmark frameworks does not require abandoning the terminology of international tax neutralities. (121) A politically descriptive model of international tax competition, i.e. a positive model of political behavior based on the real world incentives of international tax policymakers, can be formulated using the traditional neutrality benchmarks. Although the international capital neutrality concepts have traditionally been deployed under a framework that seeks to maximize global welfare, these same concepts can equally be applied to maximize a concept of national welfare based on the strategic interests of national constituencies.

National welfare in a positive model of international tax competition consists of a combination of the interest of "American firms" and the U.S. "marketplace." Michael Knoll introduced these two concepts of the "national" market to categorize U.S. debate about the tax "competitiveness." (122) Knoll shows that two distinct conceptions of "competitiveness" in international tax policy are grounded in different conceptions of domestic industry. (123) In one case, competitiveness focuses on U.S. resident firms; in the other, competitiveness focuses on the domestic market, which includes domestic and foreign firms in the U.S.:

The two conceptions of competitiveness... have different implications for how taxation affects competitiveness. In addition, the two conceptions of competitiveness have different implications for how the domestic industry is defined and for the mechanism through which taxation affects competitiveness. The first conception of competitiveness focuses on how taxation affects the ability of firms to compete in different locations. Thus, the first conception of competitiveness defines a state's industry by the total output (both domestic and foreign) of the companies based in that state. In contrast, the second conception of competitiveness focuses on how taxation affects the ability of states to attract investment and labor. Thus, the second conception of competitiveness defines a state's industry by the total output of that industry in that state without regard to the nationality of the producing company.

The political debate around tax competitiveness has pitted these conceptually distinct concepts of welfare against one another. In fact, both concepts affect national welfare and are, thus, linked to the incentives of national policymakers in the international tax competition game. Nevertheless, depending on the definition of domestic industry, and thus the related concept of national welfare, different tax neutrality benchmarks take on varying degrees of importance.

The first conception of domestic industry refers to "American" firms that are tax residents in the U.S. Under the "American" firm conception, CON is important. CON promotes what economists refer to as competitive neutrality--a system in which the total tax on a particular investment is the same no matter the residence of the taxpayer. (124) Traditionally, the welfare effects of ownership neutrality were perceived to be minimal, but recent economic research has led to increased appreciation of the economic consequences of violating CON. (125)

The second conception of domestic industry refers to the U.S. economic "marketplace." Under the U.S. "marketplace" view, CEN is important. CEN promotes what economists refer to as locational neutrality--a system in which the total tax on investment should be the same regardless of whether a taxpayer invests in their resident state or in a foreign state. Locational neutrality implies that a firm should be indifferent between retaining its capital for domestic investment or exporting its capital for foreign investment.

The international tax competition game modelled below presumes that political actors attempt to maximize an ideal combination of both concepts of national welfare discussed above. Policymakers might discuss competitiveness by focusing only on a particular concept, e.g. "bringing jobs home," promoting a national champion, or "helping our companies compete overseas." Despite potentially narrow rhetoric, public choice theory predicts that where interest groups have an interest at stake, as both domestic and foreign producers in the domestic market do in shaping domestic adoption of international tax rules, these groups (assuming sufficient political access and organizational ability) will communicate the economic stakes to policymakers. Whether directly or as a result of political processes, "national" economic interests will thus be communicated to political representatives and percolate to policymakers. Proceeding on the assumption that policymakers thus have direct or indirect knowledge of a broad conception of national welfare (both Knoll's national firm and domestic market concepts), the international tax competition game assumes national policymakers will seek to best maximize their perceived national preferences in negotiating and adopting international tax rules. (126) Before proceeding to the tax competition game, a note about the concept of tax competition and how it differs from the market competition of industrial organization economics.

Tax competition generally "refers to competition between jurisdictions based on their corporate income tax systems." (127) In private markets, competition is widely presumed to be beneficial to consumers by lowering prices and preventing deadweight loss of monopoly or cartel prices. (128) There is not a similar consensus in public markets. The traditional "defense" of tax competition is rooted in part on a Tiebout model of interjurisdictional competition in which tax and benefits competition creates incentives to maximize taxpayer welfare by offering an optimal bundle of taxes and benefits. (129) Depending on the degree of transaction costs, labor and capital will gravitate towards the jurisdiction that maximizes its preferred combination of taxes and benefits. (130) Under the Tiebout model, as in the standard price model for private markets, competition is normatively good.

In private markets, competition leads to downward prices that benefit consumers and avoids deadweight loss. Under Tiebout's model, interjurisdictional competition leads to a superior diversity of tax/benefits regimes that support citizens and firms as the consumers of public goods. (131) On the producer side of the equation, the similarities between private and public markets diverge. In contrast to the revenue-oriented producers of private markets, sovereigns in public markets are concerned not just with tax revenue but also with general national welfare. (132) Tax revenue is an intermediary good necessary to provide final public goods. Indeed, the purpose behind many tax subsidies is substitution of tax revenue for future national welfare. For example, the purported objectives of many tax incentives on mobile income are not distributional, i.e. a wealth transfers to preferred forms of activity, but productive efficiency--encouraging productive activity that will have an economic effect in excess of the conferred benefit. Because private producers and sovereigns have differing welfare functions, the traditional "market" analysis of competition from private markets does not necessarily fit tax competition. In markets for public goods, governments are trying to maximize national welfare and are thus interested not only in the revenue they collect from producers, but also in the distributional impact that tax rules will have on both conceptions of the home market--the national firm view and the domestic market view. (133) Sovereigns want to ensure that resident firms can compete abroad while also ensuring the domestic market is attractive for investment. Tax competition is not purely an inter-jurisdictional game. (134) Taxpayers, specifically MNEs, participate in shaping and exploiting tax competition through tax avoidance. (135) Taxpayers with market power--the ability to influence prices in the market for tax and benefits--thus, influence tax rates and bases. Taxpayer "market power" on rate and base definition can be harmful to sovereigns in two ways. First, monopsony (buyer) power among MNE taxpayers can lead to suboptimal rate structures for sovereigns. For example, governments might engage in a "race to the bottom" on rate or base definition in order to capture revenue or retain economic activity. Second, MNEs can obtain tax benefits by operating across jurisdictions that are not available to solely domestic producers. (136) The national welfare of competing sovereigns in the tax competition game is reduced under both scenarios as compared with a scenario in which sovereigns cooperate to minimize MNE market power. In theory, therefore, sovereigns should cooperate. Arguably, that is a principle purpose of multilateral organizations like the OECD. Yet, cooperation need not always take the form of multilateral action and consensus building. Dominant incentives towards defection plague cooperative action in both private and sovereign cartels. An alternative model of cooperative action depends on a two-staged game. In stage one, a dominant player unilaterally commits to a strategy with cooperative surplus. At stage two, the remaining sovereigns have cover to engage in cooperative strategies without facing a credible threat of exit or avoidance from MNEs or resident firms with mobile income.

V. THE TAXMAN'S DILEMMA: U.S. UNILATERAL ACTION AND COOPERATIVE SURPLUS

Borrowing a framework from game theory, mobile source income tax incentives mirror a classic Prisoner's Dilemma in the international tax arena. (137) In the Prisoner's Dilemma, there is a dominant 'noncooperative' strategy for all parties (sovereigns in the tax context) to pursue individual (national) interest in a way that leads to suboptimal joint outcomes. The Prisoner's Dilemma plays out in the international tax context in the battle to provide source income benefits to mobile capital. In this context, governments have a dominant incentive to offer locational benefits on source income that steers mobile income (and possibly economic activity) to a particular jurisdiction. The foreseeable consequence of this individually rational action by governments is to forego the potential for joint maximization of revenue through a cooperative solution regarding international tax rules for mobile economic activity or property.

The typical solution for parties trapped in a collective action problem like the Prisoner's Dilemma with a dominant solution that is suboptimal is to convincingly communicate strategy to their counterparties. (138) In the Prisoner's Dilemma, the actors cannot communicate, hence the dilemma of taking sub-optimal action based on rational estimation of counterparty incentives. In the international tax arena, communication and cooperation is possible and can be accomplished through multilateral organizations like the OECD. Alternatively, unilateral action that credibly convinces counterparties that a player acting unilaterally will take a particular course of action can overcome a barrier to cooperation.

The traditional Prisoner's Dilemma contemplates that the prisoners are confined and unable to communicate. The Taxman's Dilemma is less restricted. The tax competition game is often staged, so parties can observe counterparty actions and adjust strategies based on counterparty action. If a counterparty sovereign knows or can accurately predict how a counterparty will act, she can rationally adjust her strategy to maximize her individual and joint welfare through a higher payoff strategy. If the same party were to act defensively (i.e. rationally pursuing a lower payoff strategy because she lacks knowledge of how her counterparty will act), she would undermine her own welfare as well as potential joint welfare.

In the real-world tax competition game, GILTI is a unilateral strategy that enables subsequent cooperative behavior. GILTI is unilateral because it is a domestic law response to the collective action problem of tax competition for mobile source income. GILTI has cooperative potential because as a resident-based global minimum tax, it reduces the marginal benefit for profit shifting among foreign jurisdictions by U.S. MNEs. As Mindy Herzfeld has argued, "by removing the incentives for U.S. multinationals to engage in tax planning that reduces their blended foreign tax rate to below 13 percent, the United States has essentially agreed to prop up the corporate tax regimes--and hence the tax bases--of high-tax countries." (139) GILTI is cooperative in another respect. In addition to reducing the incentive for profit shifting by U.S. MNEs, GILTI gives non-U.S. sovereigns some pricing power on tax rate and base terms. This is because GILTI imposes a quasi price-floor for global MNE rate and base terms by way of its limitation on foreign source tax benefits. (140) Because the marketplace for foreign source incentives for mobile income is dominated by MNE's, an effective minimum global rate on U.S. MNEs provides cover to non-U.S. sovereigns to match the U.S. price-floor without threatening the competitiveness of resident firms. (141)

The United States' outsized influence over MNEs gives it coercive power to affect global incentives for base erosion and profit shifting. (142) Because MNEs play a crucial role in the tax competition and tax avoidance games, the U.S.'s outsized influence on "market" rates for MNEs provides the U.S. with coercive power in the international tax competition game. (143) Returning to private market economics, the U.S. Treasury is a price-maker, whereas many European treasuries are price-takers in the competition for MNE global tax revenues. By setting a global minimum effective tax rate for MNE excess profits, the U.S. provides cover for other developed countries to impose similar defensive measures.

The potential of large resident economies to implement global minimum tax rates on foreign source income that cluster around a U.S. unilateral price ultimately enables beneficial competition with regards to productive factors. This final point is often overlooked. The true cooperative surplus from global minimum taxation is not that it allows resident sovereigns to recapture subsidies that enable excess profits--although this is a tremendous accomplishment. The true cooperative surplus of global minimum taxes on foreign source income is the potential for resident sovereigns to compete on productive factors rather than source tax rate and base definition.

The game theory behind the Taxman's Dilemma plays out in the real-world practice of international tax competition. In the tax competition game, a sovereign with strong factors of production, e.g. Germany, might like to adopt a global minimum tax. (144) Under a benefits rationale, Germany might believe that the ability of domestic (German) multinational automakers to earn excess profits abroad is driven by benefits (legal, educational, infrastructure) provided in Germany. To the dismay of domestic constituencies, Germany might be unable to realize its preferred tax policy (e.g. limiting EU patent boxes) because competing sovereigns (e.g. U.K.) in the multilateral process have rational individual incentives to defect and veto multilateral limitations on base erosion and profit shifting. (145)

Enter GILTI. Before a U.S. global minimum tax, even a large economy like Germany might have been hesitant to implement additional taxation on resident firms because of the threat of domestic firm exit or a reduction in competitiveness for domestic producers in the pursuit of foreign excess profits. Yet, once a sovereign with sufficient market power has credibly committed to resident based taxation of foreign source excess profits (as the U.S. has done with GILTI), other sovereigns have cover to implement similar defensive measures to capture excess profits and limit the benefits of profit shifting. Rather than thwarting cooperative solutions, U.S. unilateral action under these circumstances enables other sovereigns to pursue individually beneficial strategies with cooperative surplus. The ultimate surplus from this cooperative sovereign behavior is not just additional tax revenue for resident sovereigns. The golden egg of global minimum taxation of foreign source excess profits is a tax competition landscape that enables competition on productive factors like education, law, and infrastructure, rather than tax rate and base terms.

Staged cooperative action can be superior to a single-stage multilateral process in combating harmful tax competition because it respects tax sovereignty and allows jurisdictional diversity. Because a resident based global minimum tax is a domestic-law rule, adoption of GILTI like tax tools in Europe requires no compromise or negotiation among EU member states regarding design and distributional effects. Germany can enact a resident based global minimum tax without the threat of veto from Ireland or the U.K. (146)

Nor does a global minimum tax alter competing countries' tax sovereignty to set attractive rate and base terms for source and resident income. (147) EU member state adoption of a GILTI like tool undoubtedly entails distributional consequence for low tax jurisdictions that have benefitted to date from mobile income shifting out of high tax resident jurisdictions. (148) But resident based global minimum taxation does not preclude low-tax jurisdictions from competing for new productive activity based on a leaner and more efficient regulatory, tax, and tax-benefits offering to new or relocating firms.

In response to GILTI, low-tax jurisdictions will be forced to recalibrate whether they offer an ideal combination of productive benefits and tax incentives in a new tax competition world undergirded by global minimum effective rates for MNE income. The ideal mix of tax rates and benefits likely varies firm to firm and sector to sector. (149) Individual or cultural factors might further impact the ideal combination or rates and benefits for a particular jurisdiction. Viewed in light of Tiebout's emphasis on the benefits of interjurisdictional competition, global minimum taxation does not destroy the benefits of tax diversity. Just as the states in the United States compete in the provision of education, infrastructure, and law,

European countries can hope as the result of resident based global minimum taxation to engage in healthy competition for productive factors.

VI. CONCLUSION

Sovereignty and multilateralism have become buzzwords defining ideological battle lines in international relations. (150) International tax policy is a technical field that must skirt these ideological battles and avoid aligning with or being driven by simple theories of multilateralism or unilateralism. (151) While the OECD in BEPS initially took an ideological approach in arguing that cooperation stands in conflict with unilateralism, this paper shows how unilateral measures can foster beneficial cooperation in international tax policy. (152) As the FATCA/BEPS histories and GILTI parallels suggest, cooperative action is facilitated under certain circumstances through unilateral action with the potential for cooperative surplus.

Understood as a harmonized global tax rate, a global minimum tax might operate as the sword of a sovereign cartel without clear productive efficiencies. (153) GILTI takes a different approach. It does not attempt to impose or align on a global minimum tax rate by way of multilateral horse-trading. Instead, GILTI implements a resident based global minimum tax that enables productive factor competition while respecting traditional principals of tax sovereignty. GILTI thus allows competing sovereigns to set their own rate and base terms. GILTI merely limits the benefit that foreign source rates confer on resident foreign firms. (154) As a result, GILTI's resident based global minimum tax shifts international tax competition away from a cat and mouse game of tracking down and labelling "tax havens" or "harmful" tax competition. Instead, the hunt for "harmful" tax competition is replaced with a productive experiment among competing tax jurisdictions for the optimal array of resident benefits that allow resident firms to exploit excess profits at home and abroad. As EU member states and countries around the world seek to develop international tax policy for the "digital age," productive factor competition ought to be a primary goal. (155) By enabling resident sovereigns to share in excess profits, GILTI and other resident based global minimum taxes incentivize competition on productive economic factors. GILTI promotes productive factor competition while also retaining foundational principals of tax sovereignty that protect resident firms operating in foreign markets. (156) As some European countries have already come to appreciate, GILTI is a tax tool "Made in America" for European tax.

(100) The entity approach to "substantial nexus" is generally more restrictive than a locational approach. The primary restriction on the entity approach stems from limitations on qualifying expenditures from related party transactions and acquisitions of foreign income producing assets. For example, the entity approach does not recognize expenditures by a related party as qualifying expenditures, even if the related party is located in the jurisdiction providing benefits. Moreover, the entity approach does not qualify income related to the expense of acquiring foreign IP. In contrast, a locational approach to substantial nexus qualifies expenses related to income derived from foreign acquired IP and from R&D outsourced to a related party, so long as the acquisition and outsourcing occur in the jurisdiction offering the preferential regime. In short, the locational approach maintains many of the locational benefits associated with "old" patent box regimes while limiting the provision of benefits for purely foreign activities (e.g. managing foreign IP). The entity approach goes a step further by excluding expenditures that are both foreign to the jurisdiction (locational) as well as "foreign" (in the organizational sense) to the entity seeking benefits (e.g. related party transfer within a common jurisdiction).

(131) As Tiebout's title suggest, his is a "pure" theory of local expenditure. The model assumes perfect mobility, full knowledge for of voters, a large and diverse jurisdictional choice set. See Tiebout, supra note 129, at 419.

(132) Michael Keen & Kai A. Konrad, THE THEORY OF INTERNATIONAL TAX COMPETITION AND COORDINATION 42 (July 18, 2012), https://papers.ssm.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2111895.

(133) Positing national welfare introduces complexity in selecting a preferred international tax neutrality benchmark. Both the home firm view and home market view are reasonably encompassed within national welfare. When "American" firms are able to better compete for opportunities across the globe to allocate capital (CON), U.S. shareholders and employees of national firms benefit. Similarly, when all firms are able to compete with similar after-tax incentives for allocating capital in the United States (CEN), American workers and the American economy benefits from the spillover effects of foreign direct investment (FDI). Since different international tax policies (favoring CON vs. CEN) will have different impacts on different but equally defensible notions of national welfare, if s difficult to select a preferred neutrality benchmark unless one has a preferred conception of the home market.

(134) Some argue that the "term 'harmful tax competition' cannot be defined because the term has no intrinsic meaning" since it is used strategically by "politicians, policymakers, and academics to mask their normative preferences." See e.g. Faulhaber, supra note 22, at 58.

(135) Faulhaber, supra note 22, at 58 ("taxpayers, in the form of large multinational corporations, now have the market power to demand rate reductions, tax rulings, or the like from jurisdictions, which means that they are spurring on tax competition in order to distort the market in which they compete... If this is the case, then tax competition is not, as those who extrapolate from the Tiebout model to argue in favor of unfettered international tax competition would claim, just another version of market competition. Instead, in certain circumstances, international tax competition may be distorting market competition if it is taking place in the fonn of rulings or preferential regimes that allow certain taxpayers to shift the playing field in their favor against their market competitors.").

(136) See, e.g., Edward Kleinbard, Stateless Income, 11 FI.A. TAX REV. 699 (2011).

(137) See Shaviro, supra note 55, at 137-38. International tax treaties, in mediating double-taxation, also exhibit characteristics of a classical prisoner's dilemma. See also Dagan, supra note 107, at 167-68 ("The strategic outcome is that developing countries face a prisoner's dilemma: although the treaty regime is costlier for them in tax revenues than the alternative, they join it so as to benefit from the competitive edge it offers or, alternatively, out of fear that their competitors will join and have that advantage.").

(138) See Shaviro, supra note 55, at 137 ("If countries have internal political predilections to cheat too much (leading through contagion to bad long-term outcomes for all), then their treating a cooperative norm as valuable for its own sake might conceivably tend, over the long run, to improve their political decisions from a purely self-interested standpoint.").

(139) Herzfeld criticizes EU efforts to tax digital presence and its foreseeable distribution impact on large U.S. technology firms: Herzfeld, supra note 66, at 713 ("The failure of many high-tax European countries to recognize the benefits their corporate tax systems might receive from reduced profit shifting resulting from U.S. tax reform, and their continued insistence on taxing the digital economy, are more evidence that the supposed concern for fair taxation is largely about something else.").

(140) U.S. firms derive eighty percent of market value from intangible assets and own over half of the world's IP. Intangibles also play a significant role in foreign profits. As The Economist reports, "At the biggest 50 multinationals, 65% of foreign profits come from IP-intensive businesses such as tech and drugs." Sec Schumpeter column, supra note 52, at 74.

(141) See Faulhaber, supra note 22, at 58; see also Schumpeter column, supra note 52, at 74 ("The latest star firms rely on selling intangibles across borders.").

(142) U.S. coercive power over MNEs is analogous although not identical to its outsized influence over the global financial institutions. Cf. Grinberg, supra note 112, at 167 ("Unilateral coercive pressure of the type exercised by the United States in the FATCA story can succeed when the mechanisms credibly available to the acting state can impose sufficient coercive pressure to change the distributive calculus for other states. In the financial sector, the US market is sufficiently important to global financial institutions' business model, and the damage to the US public from excluding some foreign financial institutions sufficiently manageable, to make the withholding threat used by FATCA.").

(143) MNEs are active participants in tax competition and tax avoidance. Faulhaber, supra note 22, at 58 ("taxpayers, in the form of large multinational corporations, now have the market power to demand rate reductions, tax rulings, or the like from jurisdictions, which means that they are spurring on tax competition in order to distort the market in which they compete."); see also Mindy Herzfeld, The OECD Consults on a New Tax World Order, 93 TAX NOTES INT'L 704 (Feb 18, 2019) (citing Professor Reuven Avi-Yonah's suggestions that only the US, EU and Japan are essential parties to forming a tipping point coalition around any international tax reform because of the large proportion of multinational enterprises domiciled in these jurisdictions).

(144) Recent developments in the EU and OECD suggest that Germany and France might in fact desire a minimum tax tool. See Greive & Hildebrand, supra note 5.

(145) Ireland is a pertinent hold-up that thwarts multilateral efforts in the OECD and EU. However, the history of BEI'S Action 5 shows that even ostensibly "resident" economies such as the United Kingdom have strategic incentives to defect in targeting mobile source income through patent box regimes. See e.g. Dara Doyle, Irish May Face EU Tax Pressure in Return for Brexit Support, BLOOMBERG (Sept. 17, 2018), https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-17/irish-said-to-face-eu-tax-pressure-in-return-for-brexit-support; see also Padraic Halpin, UK's May Must Explain Why She Wants Brexit Delay-French Finance Minister REUTERS (Feb. 26, 2019),   https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2019/02/26/world/europe/26reuters-britain-eu-ireland-france.html (indicating that France is not pressing Ireland to drop opposition to unilateral member state action on digital taxation as a condition of support for Ireland in Brexit negotiations).

(146) For consideration on whether the EU should dispense with its unanimity requirement for direct taxation under article 115 of the Treaty for the Functioning of the European Union, see Robert Goulder, Should the EU Scrap the Unanimity Requirement, 93 TAX NOTES INT'L. 245 Qan. 14,2019).

(147) while a resident based global minimum tax respects source state sovereignty, a host state resident rule certainty has indirect effects on incentives for host state resident multinationals to shift mobile income to low tax jurisdictions. For some firms it might even change the residency calculus entirely. See Amanda Athanasiou, Irish Multinational Cites Corporate Tax in Move to U.S. 91 TAX NOTES INT'L 1160 (Sept. 10, 2018).

(148) According to a recent IMF Report "the [U.S.] corporate tax cut will strengthen incentives to report profits in the United States and can be expected to lead to profit shifting out of many countries." See Amanda Athanasiou, TCJA Will Deplete Multinational Tax Revenue Abroad, IMF Says, 91 TAX NOTES INT'L 417 (July 17, 2018), https://www.taxnotes.com/worldwide-tax-daily/tax-reform/tcja-will-deplete-multinational-tax-revenue-abroad-imf-says/2018/07/17/287vt ("'Even countries that remain above or below the U.S. rate may see a larger share of profits reported in the U.S./ including low-tax jurisdictions, the paper states. Though some jurisdictions' tax rates are still very low compared with the U.S. rate, not all profits can be shifted there and the relative cost of keeping profits in the United States has dropped, [the IMF Report] explains.").

(149) For a thorough discussion of the purported benefits of regulatory competition spurred on by tax diversity see Ruth Mason, When Are Tax Subsidies Illegal?, 69 AM. U. L. REV _, 27-28 (on file with author(forthcoming 2019).

(150) Farnaz Fassihi & Valentina Pop, U.N. Gathering Brings to Fore Clash Between Sovereignty and Multilateralism, WALL STREET J. (Sept. 24, 2018), https://w ww. wsj.com/articles/at-u-n-gathering-leaders-face-global-problernsand-contrasting-views-1537793248.

(151) See, e.g., id. (contrasting statement of EU delegation to U.N. General Assembly as "here to say that the multilateral approach is not dead. It has to be maintained" with statement from U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton "that in the U.S., 'we, the people, are sovereign,' adding that any attempt to infringe on the sovereignty of the nation constitutes an infringement upon the populace.").

(152) See, e.g., Saint-Amans, supra note 13, at 6:42 ("cooperation is much better than unilateralism, that's what I believe"); see also Herzfeld, supra note 143 ("in contrast to ideological lip service to multilateralism, a growing consensus in the tax policy community appreciate that "multilateralism isn't really necessary to develop a new world order [in international tax]").

(153) Some who push back on the global welfare framework of international tax policy question the benefits of minimum global tax tools. See TSILLY DAGAN, INTERNATIONAL TAX POLICY: BETWEEN COMPETITION & COOPERATION 224 (Cambridge Univ. Press 2018) ("[I]n pursuing multilateral efforts, international tax policymakers should proceed with caution. Cooperative efforts should avoid focusing - in the name of efficiency, justice or political sovereignty - on helping states sustain or perhaps increase their tax revenues by limiting tax competition, preventing a race to the bottom, or (even) requiring that states impose some minimum tax rate (so as to prevent a race to the bottom).").

(154) Even OECD tax chief Pascal Saint Amans has conceded that the implementation of GILTI partially undermines European member state arguments that U.S. technology businesses do not pay tax. See Pascal Saint Amans, OECD Tax Talks, at 4:45 (Oct. 16, 2018), http://www.oecd.org/ctp/tax-talks-webcasts.htm.

(155) Europe must avoid a "two-hemisphere" mindset that targets digital tax revenues earned in the EU while dismissing identical proposals from developing countries targeting European revenues around the globe. Pascal Saint Amans has labelled the incongruence in some EU perspectives on digital taxation as "a twohemisphere" approach. See Alan Rhode, US formally asks the EU to "ditch" digital tax, MNE TAX (Oct. 22, 2018), https://mnetax.com/us-formally-asks-the-eu-to-ditch-digital-tax-30738. (quoting Saint Amans: "[w]hile the EU wants to tax US tech companies with the digital services tax, the EU does not want China and India to use the same kind of revenue-based indirect levy on its own companies[.]").

(156) Id.
